name: Entrepreneurs Association of Yale International Students
address: New Haven, Conn  United States
mission: YEA aims to unite the Yale international community by creating a global platform for innovation in various fields, including healthcare, technology, and business. We offer educational as well as prospective career opportunities to support aspiring international innovators at Yale.
goals: YEA helps current Yale students achieve their career goals with a focus on the healthcare and biotechnology industry. In addition to creating a network for Yale students and alumni to share their ideas and seek partnership, YEA also connects them with prominent worldwide entrepreneurs, startups, and angel investors to pursue entrepreneurial success. Our organization is the first career-oriented and innovation-focused organization on campus explicitly targeting the international student community. With our expertise and resources, we bring in international venture capital resources and provide one-on-one mentoring to international students at Yale. We also offer legal consulting to international students who may be facing specific regulatory requirements and constraints when trying to pursue entrepreneurship in the United States and elsewhere.

name: 2020-2021 Peer Liaisons
mission: Peer Liaisons (PLs) are a select group of upper-level students at Yale College who help connect first-years to the wealth of support and programming based in the LGBTQ Resource Center, the University Chaplain’s Office, the Office of International Students and Scholars, the Afro-American Cultural Center, the Asian American Cultural Center, the La Casa Latino Cultural Center, and the Native American Cultural Center. Each PL program is run differently, but all are designed to help first-years who come from marginalized backgrounds feel supported and integrated into the Yale College community.

name: 2021-2022 Peer Liaisons
mission: Peer Liaisons (PLs) are a select group of upper-level students at Yale College who help connect first-years to the wealth of support and programming based in the LGBTQ Resource Center, the University Chaplain’s Office, the Office of International Students and Scholars, the Afro-American Cultural Center, the Asian American Cultural Center, the La Casa Latino Cultural Center, and the Native American Cultural Center. Each PL program is run differently, but all are designed to help first-years who come from marginalized backgrounds feel supported and integrated into the Yale College community.

name: Outdoor Climbing at Yale: A Student Organization
mission: The goal of OCAY is to foster a climbing-focused outdoor culture and community. In order to do this, OCAY aims to create a community of Yale students, faculty and staff who are already outdoor climbers, mountaineers or alpinists, and to provide safety workshops and other training opportunities for new and experienced climbers alike in a safe and controlled environment. In addition to on-campus events including workshops and social events, OCAY’s ultimate goal is to lead outdoor climbing trips where members can learn from each other. As OCAY is expressly focused on outdoor climbing, we can focus our resources on providing the highest-quality climbing workshops, events, and outdoor trips.
goals:
1. To organize outdoor climbing trips and workshops for University students, faculty, and staff.
2. To provide an outdoor climbing community for Yale University affiliates.
3. To offer Yale University students with little or no climbing experience the opportunity to learn how to climb outdoors from experienced climbers.

name: 22-23 First-Year Counselor Applications
mission: The First-Year Counselor Program was established in 1938 and has been ever since an intrinsic and essential component of Yale’s advising system for first-years. The program has evolved in many ways over the years, but the general purpose of the program has remained the same: to help ease the transition of incoming first-years to the academic, social, and cultural life of Yale College. Applicants are urged to seriously consider how serving as a counselor fits into their plans and obligations for senior year. They are also encouraged to discuss the prospect of applying for a position with their residential college dean. Heads of residential colleges, cultural center directors, and current first-year counselors may also be useful to consult. While the responsibilities of counselors are heavy, and the demands made on their time and energy are great, the opportunity to support students encountering Yale for the first time is profoundly important and uniquely rewarding. In the eyes of many first-years, no position at Yale is more significant; and for many counselors, no other job is more satisfying. This year, we will accept applicants who are set to graduate in the spring of 2023 OR the fall of 2023.

name: Peace and Dialogue Leadership Initiative
mission:
1.	To convey a nuanced understanding of the Israeli­Palestinian Conflict and the region as a whole by connecting high-level strategic dialogue with realities on the ground,
2.	To provide students with the tools necessary to think about the United States’ proper role in the U.S.-Israel relationship, its role in the Israeli-Palestinian relationship, and, more broadly, its role in the region,
3.	To foster civil­military understanding and dialogue,
4.	To provide an incisive look into Israeli society, culture, and politics, while simultaneously grappling with the unique security challenges facing both the U.S. and her allies in the region,
5.	To actively foster a community on college campuses interested in engaging with and discussing these issues.

name: 22-23 First-Year Counselors
mission: The First-Year Counselor Program was established in 1938 and has been ever since an intrinsic and essential component of Yale’s advising system for first-years. The program has evolved in many ways over the years, but the general purpose of the program has remained the same: to help ease the transition of incoming first-years to the academic, social, and cultural life of Yale College. Applicants are urged to seriously consider how serving as a counselor fits into their plans and obligations for senior year. They are also encouraged to discuss the prospect of applying for a position with their residential college dean. Heads of residential colleges, cultural center directors, and current first-year counselors may also be useful to consult. While the responsibilities of counselors are heavy, and the demands made on their time and energy are great, the opportunity to support students encountering Yale for the first time is profoundly important and uniquely rewarding. In the eyes of many first-years, no position at Yale is more significant; and for many counselors, no other job is more satisfying.

name: A Different Drum Dance Company
mission: A Different Drum is dedicated to providing a place for a diverse group of dancers to sharpen and broaden their technical abilities and to develop artistically as both dancers and choreographers.
goals:
1. Foster a community of supportive and committed dancers 
2. Help individuals grow as artists
3. Introduce individuals to a diverse array of styles and techniques
4. Give dancers an opportunity to not only move, but to create movement through choreography
5. Offer opportunities to perform and present work 
6. Specifically during the COVID-19 crisis, our goal is to maintain the tight-knit dance community we have during regular years at Yale and help each and every one of our members feel supported in their mental, physical, emotional, and artistic needs in whatever way we safely can

name: A Leg Even at Yale - An Undergraduate Organization
mission: Our objective is to raise awareness and strengthen peer support systems for all first-generation and/or low-income students at Yale. As a registered student organization on campus, A.L.E. will be open to all interested participants, regardless of their financial background. We intend to work alongside other student groups, dedicated faculty, and members of the administration to benefit the largest number of students possible.

name: Abdallah S. Kamel Center for the Study of Islamic Law and Civilization
mission: The Abdallah S. Kamel Center for the Study of Islamic Law and Civilization at Yale Law School brings prominent scholars of Islam to the Yale campus for public lectures, seminar discussions, visiting fellowships, and visiting professorships.

name: Accent Multilingual Magazine
mission: To produce Accent Multilingual Magazine once a semester.

name: Addiction Medicine Collaborative
type: School of Public Health Student Organizations
address:
47 College St
New Haven, CT 06510 United States
mission: The AMC is an interdisciplinary student organization among the Yale health professional schools that seeks to collaboratively enhance professional and public education concerning substance use; to promote and foster the interests of students, health professionals, and advocates for substance use assistance and recovery; and to encourage scholarly inquiry concerning substance use disorders as they impact health care professionals and the public that we seek to serve.

name: Adventist Campus Fellowship
mission: Our mission is to inspire Seventh-day Adventist Christian students and faculty members to be disciples of Christ and empower them to share the everlasting gospel on campus.

name: Africa SIG
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups
mission: The Africa SIG is a group of engaged students interested in the environmental challenges and opportunities on the continent. The purpose of Africa SIG is two-fold: (1) to serve as a forum for information exchange and research support for members; (2) to create opportunities on campus to engage with the vibrant culture of Africa. The SIG hosts and co-sponsors talks with scholars and practitioners, movie screenings, and cultural experiences to share the colourful traditions that have existed for centuries in Africa.

name: Afro-American Cultural Center
address:
211 Park Street
New Haven, CT 06511
mission:
Vision:
To foster a vibrant community of Black scholar-leaders and others who are committed to preserving and promoting the historical, cultural, intellectual and social movement traditions of the African Diaspora at Yale, in New Haven, and throughout the world.
Mission:
Established in 1969, the Afro-American Cultural Center (“the House”) has a rich history of serving as Yale’s home away from home for its Black student body and all campus and local community constituents who wish to learn about and celebrate the cultures and traditions of the African Diaspora.
The House facilitates its community members’ success in the areas of scholarship, leadership, service, and advocacy through advising, empowerment cultural enrichment, educational programming, social development, and career preparation.
goals:
Goals:
(Informed by the original goals of the House’s Founders and by the Final Report Consultation Committee on the Cultural Centers, Submitted 1 December 2014)
To provide an affirming space for students of the African Diaspora to develop solidarity, to find support and to build and express pride in their social identities
To support our students’ personal, academic and professional development as well as their sense of belonging at Yale through impactful advising, career preparation, and counseling
To offer opportunities through which anyone can learn about the robust legacy of Black accomplishments and societal contributions in addition to the rich diverse cultures that comprise the Diaspora
To engage the larger campus and local communities in pertinent Black historical and contemporary social issues and offer a platform to advocate around those issues
To foster a more accessible and culturally affirming campus environment through community building, intercultural exchange and social justice education;
To empower Black youth through effective programming and mentorship within the Greater New Haven community and beyond
To create meaningful connections amongst current Yale students, the Yale alumni community, and the Greater New Haven area through tailored programming and engagement

name: Heritage Theater Ensemble
address:
211 Park St
New Haven, CT 06511 United States
mission: The purpose of Heritage Theater Ensemble shall be to foster the development of Black theater in the Yale-New Haven community: to provide a forum for the expression of Black (and other minority) talent in all aspects of the performing arts and to generate and promote a collective, artistic consciousness within the organization. Similarly, Heritage Theater Ensemble's promotion of artistic endeavors within New Haven shall be a means of developing and sustaining Black (minority) arts as a means of politicizing art-production within the local community.
goals:
I vow to create a Heritage that ... 
Is open to all black people throughout the diaspora
Values intersectionality
Thinks critically about access
Doesn’t sacrifice joy for spectacle or spectacle for joy
Creates and maintains a home base for Black artists
Recognizes our personhood before and in tandem with our artistry

name: AFROTC Undergraduate Association
mission: We are committed to ensuring that all members have every opportunity to develop as young officers (for those who are AFROTC cadets), and as Yale students, mentally, morally, and physically. Often, the cost of required AFROTC events and training evolutions cannot be covered by official AFROTC unit funds, meaning that the cost is passed down to the cadets. We want to ensure that no cadet is ever limited in their training as future officers, and therefore we will strive to provide them with the resources they need. As an organization, the three main resources we provide are (1) an inclusive community for all members, (2) financial assistance for ROTC training activities, and (3) events that connect Association members with the U.S. Air Force, Yale AFROTC alumni, and the many resources provided by Yale University.
goals: To develop Air Force ROTC by subsidizing training and leadership opportunities.

name: AIDS Walk New Haven
mission: We seek to raise money for the major AIDS service organizations, including AIDS Project New Haven, Fair Haven Community Health Center, Cornell Scott Hill Health Center, Leeway, Liberty Community Services, New Reach, Planned Parenthood, and Yale Child Study Center. Because we are an all-volunteer organization, we are able to commit the maximum possible amount of funds raised to the fight against HIV/AIDS in New Haven. We seek to Increase public awareness and promote prevention through advocacy by uniting as a community to speak out about the need for greater HIV/AIDS prevention and treatment resources. Every business, school, and individual that participates in and contributes to the AIDS Walk will be actively helping more children and adults understand the importance of HIV education, prevention and treatment in the greater New Haven area. We seek to unite the Yale and New Haven community against stigma, apathy and infection. AIDS blurs borders, crosses class lines and unites races in suffering. It truly is everyone's problem, and so we invite you to be a part of the solution.
goals:
We seek to raise money for the major AIDS service organizations, including A Place to Nourish your Health, Guardian Health, Fair Haven Community Health Center, Cornell Scott Hill Health Center, Leeway, Liberty Community Services, New Reach, Planned Parenthood, Community Health Care Van, and Yale Child Study Center. Because we are an all-volunteer organization, we are able to commit the maximum possible amount of funds raised to the fight against HIV/AIDS in New Haven.
Increase public awareness and promote prevention through advocacy by uniting as a community to speak out about the need for greater HIV/AIDS prevention and treatment resources. Every business, school, and individual that participates in and contributes to the AIDS Walk will be actively helping more children and adults understand the importance of HIV education, prevention and treatment in the greater New Haven area.
Unite the Yale and New Haven community against stigma, apathy and infection. In 2018, there were 10,560 people living with AIDS in Connecticut and over 1,300 people were living with AIDS in New Haven. We hope to bring the Yale student body and the greater New Haven community together to fight this epidemic. AIDS blurs borders, crosses class lines and unites races in suffering. It truly is everyone's problem, and so we invite you to be a part of the solution.

name: AIESEC
category: Cultural, Entrepreneurial/Business, International Affairs, Leadership, Service/Volunteering, Social
mission: AIESEC Yale is a student-run non-profit organization. Our main mission is to improve cultural understanding by facilitating international exchanges based around the UN Sustainable Development Goals. In the past, we have sent Yalies to Italy to help refugees, China and Argentina to teach English, and Peru to support a monkey sanctuary. We have also hosted international volunteers from India, Kuwait, Peru, and Egypt to work with local New Haven NGOs including CT Fund for the Environment, MakeHaven, and Common Ground.
goals: To promote cultural understanding and global student leadership by facilitating international volunteer and internship exchanges.

name: Alcohol and Other Drugs Harm Reduction Intiative
mission:
AODHRI is dedicated to reducing the various harms - physical, psychological, academic, and social - of drug and alcohol use among Yale undergraduates.
The remaining TIPS Bartending Trainings in Fall 2021 are full. You can add your name to the waitlist or individual events, or you can sign up to receive a notification when new trainings are made available here: https://forms.gle/iWAXALzzimt56NZG8.

name: Alexander Hamilton Society: Yale Undergraduate Chapter
mission: The Alexander Hamilton Society (AHS) is a non-partisan, not-for-profit, national organization that seeks to identify, educate, and launch young men and women into foreign policy and national security careers imbued with the Hamiltonian perspective of strong and principled American leadership in global affairs. Hamiltonians are united by a deep conviction, rooted in the history of the last century, that the world is a better, safer, and more prosperous place when the United States is willing and able to lead. Engaging citizens from all walks of life and at every stage in their careers, AHS seeds the ground for the future of American foreign policy.
goals: Host 4 speaker-events this coming year.

name: Allan Bloom Forum
mission: The Allan Bloom Forum is a student organization at Yale University which seeks to promote the public exploration of the ideas which have shaped Western culture through engagement with leading thinkers in the fields of public policy, diplomacy, journalism, and academia. The Forum is named after Allan Bloom, who was a Yale professor, philosopher, and classicist.

name: People, Equity, and the Environment Learning Community
mission: This LC helps students develop the skills they need to thoughtfully critique and improve the relationship between people and the planet, with a focus on deep-seated, systemic challenges. Emphasis is placed on the interplay among the environment, systemic social issues, and the emerging environmental justice movement.

name: Period @ Yale - A Student Organization
mission: Open up the conversation about periods in the community to highlight a spectrum of period experiences. We are also want engage with members of the New Haven community and try to provide for their needs related to menstrual health and hygiene.

name: Alliance for Dance at Yale College
mission:
As an umbrella organization we seek to unite the dance groups on campus, bring together the New Haven and Yale dance community and to work for more administrative support for dance on campus. We believe that there should be maximum cooperation within the campus dance community and that as the dance community grows it is important for us to work with the administration to accommodate their needs of rehearsal and performance space.
The Alliance for Dance at Yale is an umbrella organization which seeks to unite the dance groups on campus, bring together the New Haven and Yale dance community and to work for more administrative support for dance on campus. We book rehearsal space at Payne Whitney Gym for all undergraduate dance groups, and we host the Festival of Dance Groups during Opening Days for freshman. The Alliance automatically includes all members of dance groups on campus and is led by a board of directors who are elected by the larger membership each year. This board consists of 5 positions all of which may be held by 1 or 2 people: executive director publicity director treasurer outreach coordinator secretary Additionally a representative from each dance group who wishes to participate in ADAY activities will serve as a direct liason to the board and help in the planning and production of ADAY events. As an umbrella organization we seek to unite the dance groups on campus, bring together the New Haven and Yale dance community and to work for more administrative support for dance on campus. We believe that there should be maximum cooperation within the campus dance community and that as the dance community grows it is important for us to work with the administration to accomodate their needs of rehearsal and performance space. There are no membership requirements, though people wishing to hold office within ADAY must be currently enrolled undergraduates. Elections are held yearly in January. Interested candidate submit a candidate statement to the Alliance and are elected by majority vote.

name: Alliance for Diversity
mission: The Alliance for Diversity (AfD) coordinates efforts by affinity groups and all students interested in promoting diversity at YLS and improving the law school experience for groups currently underrepresented at this law school and in the legal profession.

name: Alliance for Southeast Asian Students
mission: The Alliance for Southeast Asian Students was formed in order to promote, examine and discuss the culture, economies and socio-political developments of Southeast Asian countries and their people along with fostering a close community of Southeast Asian students and those interested in Southeast Asia at Yale University. Each year, we embrace new Southeast Asians and other interested students, both undergraduate and some graduate, to our organization and host events open to the Yale public that encourage interest in Southeast Asia, events that include but are not limited to roundtable discussions, speaker events, food events and film events. Our mission is not only to represent our respective countries in the student body to the best of our abilities, mainly through active discussion in academic and social events at the university, but to encourage a better understanding of Southeast Asia and aid in publicizing Southeast Asian related events on campus to those who of the Yale public who might be interested.

name: Alpha Phi Fraternity
mission: The purpose of this chapter is the promotion of growth in character, of unity of feeling, of sisterly affection and of social communion among its members.  And we who are thus united are under a solemn pledge to lend a helping hand to one another.

name: Alzheimer's Buddies
mission: NAB functions by pairing college students with residents in local Alzheimer’s/dementia care facilities for weekly one-on-one visits.  These students work with both family members and staff to determine the best way to utilize their visits in order to learn more about the interests and lives of the residents, thereby forming connections that help combat the isolation often felt by residents in such facilities.  Additionally, NAB chapters in the past have helped educate campus communities about AD, launched music therapy initiatives, and performed clinical research studies.  For more information about NAB, please see www.alzbuddies.org.

name: Ambient Sounds Society
mission: We record ambient sounds around campus, reminding people of their home away from home.

name: American Cancer Society Club
mission: Our purpose is to assist individuals with cancer through fundraisers, legislative support, and more outlets. We will be associated with the American Cancer Society organization, assisting them in all ways that deem fit.

name: American College of Healthcare Executives (ACHE)
type: School of Public Health Student Organizations
address:
47 College Street
New Haven, CT 06510 United States
mission: American College of Healthcare Executives (ACHE) is an international professional society of 40,000 healthcare executives who lead hospitals, healthcare systems and other healthcare organizations. ACHE's mission is to advance our members and healthcare management excellence. Yale ACHE offers networking, education, and career development to students aspiring to pursue healthcare management roles at Yale SPH, SOM, Nursing, Medical School, and the PA program. In the past few years, there has been an average of 100 Yale ACHE chapter members. There will be a variety of ACHE events over the course of the year including speaker series events, chapter events, professional development events, and Connecticut/National ACHE events (CT ACHE Student Career Panel, ACHE Congress).

name: American Constitution Society for Law and Policy at Yale Law School
mission:
The American Constitution Society is the largest student group at Yale Law School. ACS@YLS aims to foster community-wide discussion over progressive issues in American law and provide a forum for all members of the Yale Law progressive community to pursue their interests, educate the wider community, and bring scholars and practitioners together to find the best way to effect progressive change.
Throughout the year, ACS@YLS hosts a wide variety of speakers from the public and private sectors, fosters student-faculty interaction through reading groups and workshops on progressive theory, and provides current students valuable tools for excelling in both law school and their legal careers.

name: American Medical Student Association
mission: We see opportunities to reshape medicine as future physicians. Our vision is a world where health care is accessible, medicine is affordable and systems support the diversity we see around us. We’re the next generation of physicians, leaders and change agents. Seventy years strong, with roughly 30,000 active members all across the globe, AMSA is a student-led, national association that exists to cultivate, inspire and inform medical students.

name: American Public Health Association (APHA) - Yale Student Chapter
type: School of Public Health Student Organizations
address:
47 College St
New Haven, CT 06510 United States
mission: Yale-APHA is the Yale chapter of the American Public Health Association, the oldest, largest, and most diverse organization for public health professionals across the world. The mission of Yale-APHA is to: 1) Foster professional and academic development of Yale School of Public Health students, 2) Develop relationships with undergraduate and graduate students with interests in public health and other allied-health professions and 3) Propagate the mission and goals of the American Public Health Association.

name: American Red Cross at Yale
mission: The American Red Cross at Yale seeks to serve as a local community service organization at Yale and in New Haven, providing aid on a more regional scale than its parent organization. We serve as an intermediary between the students and faculty of Yale University and the American Red Cross.  We host blood drives on the Yale campus, recruiting Yale graduate and undergraduate students as well as the broader community to donate blood and fulfill the Red Cross's local blood needs.

name: American Sign Language at Yale--An Undergraduate Organization
mission: ASLaY seeks to foster a community of diverse ASL signers of all abilities and backgrounds. We aim to provide a space for those interested in sign language to gather and to learn from one another. In addition, we seek to celebrate the beauty and poeticism of sign. ASLaY seeks to fill a gap in the representation of languages on Yale's campus. We try to advocate for more ASL opportunities on campus to further foster and develop a campus-wide appreciation of ASL.

name: American Studies Graduate Students
type: Graduate School of Arts & Sciences (GSAS) Administration

name: Amoriem Labs: Undergraduate Game Developers
mission: We are a group of students interested in programming, game design, graphic design, animation, and music composition working together to create indie games. We aim to develop creative small-scale games and learn about the game development process.

name: Anything But Christian
mission:
Anything But Christian would like to give a voice to non-Christians and Christian adjacents who want to explore different ways ministry can be represented through a non-Christian, non-colonial lens. 
We believe that God does not solely belong to Christianity and that it is necessary to learn from and explore religions and religious identities. We understand "theology" to be the study of the absolute, whether that be labeled God/Gods, Truth, Mother Nature, Ultimate Reality, Brahman, Emptiness, etc. We support societal, social, and educational equality for all religions and their embodied practitioners. We are open to dual belonging, pantheism, syncretism, and pluralism as long as it is practiced respectively and compassionately avoiding misappropriation. 
Our organizational events will focus on the not-solely-Christian and the non-traditional. This group will offer support and community to students who hold more pluralistic ideals.

name: Arab Students Association
category: Cultural, AACC Affiliate Org, AfAm Affiliate Org
mission:
Vision: To create an interactive forum on Yale campus, and promote the ASA's mission on other campuses across the  country, where members can explore and share all political, cultural, social and other aspects of the Arab world.      
Mission:
*To spread an understanding of the Arab world, its cultures, and current issues that affect the region.
*To bridge the various cultural gaps between the Arab World and the United States.
*To strive for the breaking down of stereotypes and the growth of a concrete and sincere representation of  the Arab world's diverse components. 
*To create a network and forum where Arab Student Associations across the country can collaborate and share resources.        
*To be a voice for the Arab population on campus. 
*To reach out to the greater Yale and New Haven community, making the ASA a campus-

name: Arnold Air Society
mission: To further the purpose, traditions, and concepts of the United States military and aerospace power by aiding in community awareness and to create a more efficient relationship among Air Force officer candidates, both within the Air Force Reserve Officer Training Corps and with members of Silver Wings.

name: Art Exhibition Students at Yale
mission: Our mission is to increase access to exhibition platforms for artists of all levels of experience.

name: Asia SIG
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups

name: Peristalsis Dance Group
mission: Peristalsis serves to bring light movement and dance classes to patients at the Yale-New Haven Hospital pediatric psychiatric unit.
goals:
-Increase membership size
-Employ a virtually-recorded movement model for the children at Yale-New Haven Hospital
-Become a Dwight Hall organization

name: SAYPH - PhD Group
mission: SAYPH Subgroup for PHD Students

name: Asian American Cultural Center (AACC)
mission: The Asian American Cultural Center (AACC) plays a key role in ensuring the development and enhancement of Yale University’s commitment to the Asian and Asian American community. The AACC seeks to build a dynamic Asian and Asian American presence at Yale, support student exploration of identity development, and empower them to take an active role in shaping their learning experiences. The AACC is committed to engaging the Asian and Asian American student body, Yale University, and the greater New Haven community in the learning and celebration of cultures, traditions, and issues related to the varied experiences of the Asian diaspora.
goals:
Vision
To cultivate a community of Asian and Asian American citizen scholars who are rooted in our shared histories and actively striving towards an anti-racist, equitable and just future for all. To co-create equitable learning environments that honor the wholeness of our community’s identities and experiences.

name: Asian American Health Advocates
mission: AAHA is made up of Yale undergraduates who are passionate about the humanistic side of medicine. With many of us as students pursuing careers in medicine, healthcare and public and global health, we recognize that our current healthcare system falls short in many ways. We want to analyze the ways in which various social determinants of health result in healthcare disparities, ultimately affecting the accessibility and quality of care for many minority groups.
goals:
- to raise awareness for health disparities in Asian American communities that are not reached by traditional public health campaigns
- to translate and disseminate accurate, up-to-date health information and encourage relevant dialogue within Asian American communities both at Yale and nationwide
- to cultivate a community of Asian and Asian American citizens rooted in our shared histories
- to actively strive towards equitable protection of health for all people of all backgrounds

name: Asian American Students Alliance
mission: AASA creates a community where students of the Asian diaspora feel empowered to explore their identity, both politically and culturally.

name: Asian Graduate Network - a Yale Graduate and Professional student group
mission: Asian Graduate Network (AGN) is a student organization whose mission is to build a lasting community amongst Yale graduate and professional students. We strive to do this through professional development opportunities, mentorship, coalition building, and collaboration with organizations both on and off campus. We welcome any community member to attend an event hosted by AGN and support us through our mission.

name: Asian Pacific American Law Students' Association
mission: The Asian Pacific American Law Students' Association (APALSA) serves the interests of its membership by fostering a community within the law school and strengthening ties in the broader Asian Pacific American legal community.

name: Asian Pacific American Medical Student Association
mission: We are an organization of Asian American and Pacific Islander American (APIA) medical students committed to addressing the unique health challenges of APIA communities through education, outreach, advocacy, and service, and to providing support, mentorship, and community for APIA students at the Yale School of Medicine.

name: Asian-ish
category: Cultural, AACC Affiliate Org, Cultural: Mixed Race
mission: The purpose of Asian-ish shall be to promote diversity, celebrate multi-racial and mixed Asian culture, and educate the student body about important cultural moments in multi-racial history. It is dedicated to creating a community, space, and conversations for students of mixed Asian descent and any other interested students.

name: Associate Research Scientist of Faculty Advisory Council
Association of Chinese Students and Scholars at Yale
mission: ACSSY is an independent, non-political and non-profit organization dedicated to the goal of promoting social, intellectual and cultural activities for Chinese students and scholars at Yale and for other interested members of the Yale community. It will also strive to provide opportunities and benefits for its members by facilitating the exchange of information between China and overseas Chinese students and by protecting the interests of its members on campus as well as in the United States.

name: Association of GamePigeon Enthusiasts
mission: The Association for GamePigeon Enthusiasts’s (AGE) mission is to bring people together and allow them a small break in their day by playing bite-size mobile games with their friends. The virtual format allows Yalies the freedom to play wherever or whenever in a low-stakes, friendly community.

name: Association of Native Americans at Yale, a Student Organization
mission: The Association of Native Americans at Yale (ANAAY) is a student-run political and cultural organization that empowers Indigenous students and advocates for causes throughout Indigenous communities in the Western Hemisphere.

name: Asterisk* Journal of Art and Art History
Persian Graduate Students and Scholars Association at Yale
mission: Persian Students and Scholars Association at Yale organizes cultural/traditional events such as Nowrooz (Persian New Year), Yalda. Such events are celebrated worldwide by various ethno-linguistic groups. This organization also helps its members to connect with other students and scholar and make a community.

name: Athletes in Action
mission: Athletes in Action (AIA) is a student-led sports ministry dedicated to building a community of fellowship founded in the loving character of Jesus Christ. We seek to reach out to students through large group meetings, fun activities, and individual connections. We welcome people of all backgrounds to explore the Christian faith. We meet weekly during the academic year and have Bible studies throughout the week, fellowship activities, and retreats throughout the year.

name: AYUDH
mission: AYUDH aims to empower our communities and ourselves through selfless service. We work closely with the United Nations 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development . The Yale chapter is open to everyone from any stage of life or background and meets to partake in volunteering activities, such as planting trees and serving meals at soup kitchens. We also explore the essence of compassion through discussions, invited speakers, and creative expression. Our initiatives for each year can be found at https://www.ayudh.org/initiatives-1.

name: Ballet Folklórico Mexicano de Yale - Undergraduate Organization
category: Performance: Dance, La Casa  Affiliate Org
mission: Ballet Folklórico Mexicano de Yale was founded in the fall of 1998 by a group of undergraduate students dedicated to the expression of Mexican culture and traditional folk dance. Since its founding, the group has had the privilege of performing at numerous cultural and educational events at Yale, throughout Connecticut, and elsewhere in the Northeast. As the only Mexican folk dance group on campus, Ballet Folklórico does not hold auditions. Our goals are both diverse and ambitious: while providing an outlet for the exploration of our heritage, we seek to enrich students’ cultural knowledge, and serve as a resource for greater Connecticut communities as well.

name: BC Student Alliance at Yale
mission: The BCSAY provides a home for students from the province at Yale through social, cultural and political events connecting them to home. The BCSAY hopes to connect Yalies from all walks of life both at home and at school.

name: BE2-Built Environment SIG
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups
mission: Towards a non-extractive architecture
benefits: Proposing events, acquiring funding, leadership opportunity
goals: Organizing events and workshops centered around the built environment

name: Being Well at Yale
mission:
To create and sustain a culture, community and environment in which wellness is a core value and measure of excellence at Yale. Building on the existing resources at Yale and guided by the Wellness Leadership Group, Being Well at Yale will engage and support the Yale Community in the progression towards healthier lifestyles through:
    Meaningful partnerships across the Yale community
    Integrated sources of wellness communication
    Healthier work environments
    Accessible programs
    Outreach and screening
    Self-assessment and personal health improvement plans
    Aggregate data gathering and outcome measurement
    Policy and environmental change

name: Berkeley College Orchestra
mission: The Berkeley College Orchestra is dedicated to the promotion of a musical presence on the Yale campus and the greater Connecticut area. To achieve this goal, the BCO provides a place for students to study and practice the performance of music without grades and seeks to foster a community of musicians with similar goals. To this end, BCO holds weekly rehearsals and three free public concerts during the school year and one educational concert for New Haven public school students.

name: Birding (SIG)
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups

name: Black Church at Yale
mission: Our mission is to Love God, Love People, and Serve the Nations. We will use our creativity, time and resources to create an Spirit-led atmosphere of worship for God every Sunday morning. We desire to build meaningful relationships within our church and throughout the greater Yale community. We aspire not only to serve inside the church with excellence, but to minister in the marketplace.

name: Black Graduate Student Network at Yale
mission: The Black Graduate Network (BGN) at Yale unites all graduate and professional students of African descent, regardless of their school affiliation for fellowship, networking opportunities and service. BGN is open to all members of the Yale Community. BGN also strives to support and supplement the political, social, and community efforts of other schools and departmental minority organizations.
goals: To offer community, fraternity, and support to Black graduate and professional students at Yale.

name: Persian Students Association at Yale
mission: To create a space on campus which allows students to engage and appreciate Persian culture through social events and learning opportunities, in addition to connecting with fellow Persians.

name: SAYPH- MPH HCM Group
mission: SAYPH Subgroup for HCM Students

name: Black Pre-Health Students at Yale - an Undergraduate Organization
mission: We are a student organization dedicated to inaugurating an empowering, educational, and preparatory environment for students across the African diaspora interested in pursuing a health-related profession. We incorporate the various branches of health and create an atmosphere that encourages critical conversation, community engagement, and a humanistic approach to medicine. Because of the historical oppression of Black populations in healthcare at large, we hope to increase the numbers of prepared Black leaders and healers in health advocacy and clinical settings.

name: Black Student Alliance at Yale
mission: The Black Student Alliance at Yale (BSAY) is a multi-cultural organization dedicated to enhancing the lives of Black students at Yale through political action, community action, and social events. Understanding that the world changes for the better through the determined efforts of concerned people, and that we are strongest when we are united, BSAY exists in order to create that unity and foster that change in hopes of furthering the cause of equality. As a student-run organization, BSAY is responsible for advocating for the students at Yale, taking political stands, and creating the sense of community necessary to unite students to work for positive change. On campus, we strive to meet the needs of the Black community by holding weekly meetings that are pertinent to the lives of Black students on campus and that create a supportive community for all Black students at Yale. BSAY strives create a safe and active community in order to adequately represent and respond to the Black community. This sense of community must come from both current social activities and from a sense of shared history and culture. Our strength comes from not only the collective struggle of our contemporaries but also the cumulative struggles of thousands who have sacrificed before us. Let us strive in our efforts so that we may fulfill the dreams of those who struggled before and brighten the futures of those yet to come.

name: Black Students for Disarmament at Yale
mission: Black Students for Disarmament at Yale is working against the violent and punitive institution of policing as we know it on Yale’s campus and beyond. Our organization has grown to include people of all races, backgrounds, cultures, etc, so even if you do not identify as black, we love to have you on our team!

name: BlackOut
mission: To provide community, camaraderie, and support for LGBTQQIAP+ (lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, questioning, queer, intersex, asexual, pansexual +) individuals of the African Diaspora. We aim to give them the space to engage and wrestle with the intricacies of race, most specifically Blackness, as it relates to the broader queer culture.

name: Brazil Club at Yale - a Student Organization
mission: Locally, we aim to bring together the Brazilian community of Yale College, composed of Brazilians students and any student interested in Brazil. We create opportunities for this community and its members to develop in social, professional and personal ways. From an outreach perspective, we believe in the privilege of being at Yale and in giving back to Brazil. We strive to expand our community by supporting Brazilian applicants and by embracing projects that lead to a positive impact in Brazil. We also believe in our duty to demystify, inform and create a better understanding at Yale of what Brazil is, in all its most diverse and rich aspects.

name: Bridges ESL
mission: Bridges ESL provides free English language lessons to adult learners in the Greater New Haven area. Tutors develop personalized lessons to help meet students’ language goals related to employment, education, citizenship, and daily life. Bridges ESL helps people acquire the English skills necessary to confidently navigate family, work, and community life in the U.S.

name: Broad Recognition
mission: Broad Recognition is a leftist, intersectional feminist publication at Yale. We are a radically progressive collective of friends, writers, and thinkers dedicated to understanding the way power impacts our communities. We seek to use our writing as a platform for understanding the world around us with the hopes of ultimately overturning the status quo. We dream of a world centered around communities of love instead of economies of capital.
goals: Provide reporting and cultural criticism from an intersectional feminist lens while working especially to uplift Black, Indigenous, disabled, and transfeminine writers.

name: Building Bridges
mission: Building Bridges was founded to involve college students in pooling educational resources and capital to teach disadvantaged children in China, to work with mainland Chinese youth, and to raise awareness among students everywhere about US-China relations.

name: Bulgarian Society
mission: The Bulgarian Society serves as a cultural organization for Bulgarian, Bulgarian American students, students from nearby Balkan countries and students interested in Bulgarian language, culture, and politics at Yale. It is committed to foster cultural, political and historical understanding of the Republic of Bulgaria on Yale campus. It serves the Yale College student body by developing programs and providing resources for those who are interested in Bulgaria-related non-profit works, internships and exchange opportunities.

name: Bulldog Brewing
mission: In College life, drinking is often tied up into partying. This obscures the rich history and creative experience behind some of the drinks we frequently enjoy. Bulldog Brewing would aim to make students reflect on their construction of alcohol, providing students with a space to invest their time, labor, and creativity. Throughout the semester, we would be coming together to create the initial batches of beer, bottle the beer after fermentation, and taste the beers after carbonation, taking attentive notes about the beer's notes, taste, color and more. Students will feel invested in the beer and see how alcoholic drinks are not merely just valued for their alcohol.

name: Bulldog Productions
mission: Bulldog Productions is a non-profit, student production company. All content produced is original content developed in-house by BP members and/or participating Yale Undergraduates. Its main priority, therefore, is to create organized and regular film content. This includes other responsibilities of a production company, such as distributing and promoting each film and submitting them to festivals when appropriate.

name: Bulldogs Racing
mission: Bulldogs Racing challenges its members to innovate at the intersection of automotive engineering and the modern startup. Together, we develop the skills needed to build and race top-tier vehicles as well as the confidence necessary to approach and solve the interdisciplinary challenges of the future.

name: Bulletin for Urban Studies at Yale – Student Discussion Group
mission: As cities continue to expand around the globe, the subject of urban studies is more important than ever before. In it, disciplines like Political Science, Architecture, American Studies and Environmental Studies form an intersection of diverse topics and ideas. As Yale's only active urban studies discussion group, The Bulletin for Urban Studies at Yale (“BUSY”) hosts a variety of events to promote, debate, and engage these issues. Events include: lecture series, field trips, film screenings, and more.
goals: The goal of BUSY is to foster conversation about urban spaces in and outside of New Haven. We hope create connections between members of the Yale Community through the discipline of urban studies.

name: Business and the Environment Learning Community
mission: Students who engage with this LC join a dynamic circle of scholars and practitioners who are thinking about the many opportunities and challenges for businesses in developing more sustainable approaches to meeting human needs.

name: Business and the Environment SIG
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups

name: C# Chinese Acapella
category: Cultural, Performance: Singing, AACC Affiliate Org
mission: C# is Yale's only Chinese a cappella group dedicated to exploring Chinese culture and language through music. Our group is comprised of undergraduate students and our repertoire includes a variety of Chinese pop and folk music as well as English songs inspired by Asian-American artists.
goals:
- To sing our favorite mando-pop bops!
- To share those songs both within our group and with the greater Yale community!
- To improve our singing ability while still having fun!

name: Cadence of Yale - Undergraduate A Cappella
mission: We are Cadence of Yale, Yale University’s newest a cappella group! At a school known for tradition, we aim to break the mold by being the first group dedicated to competition and active participation within the international a cappella community. We are also dedicated to using a cappella as a medium for storytelling, conveying emotion, and addressing mental health and sociopolitical issues. To borrow the words of Deke Sharon, we want to create “harmony through harmony” by making meaningful music for our audiences and ourselves. We mostly sing pop and alternative pop music (such as “The Ballad of Me and My Brain” by The 1975, “Darkness Keeps Chasing Me” by Grace VanderWaal, and “Reasons Not to Die” by Ryn Weaver), and we’re very excited to work with amazing arrangers like Matt Goldstein of the Vassar Devils while crafting our set! As a brand-new group, we can’t wait to cultivate our sound this year and show it to the world.
goals: To compete in the (virtual) ICCAs, to arrange new music, and to create a supportive musical community on campus!

name: Camp Kesem Yale, an Undergraduate Organization
mission: Camp Kesem is a nationwide community, driven by passionate college student leaders, that supports children through and beyond their parent's cancer.

name: Campus Girl Scouts
mission: Campus Girl Scouts (CGS) is a group of Yale students who lead a New Haven Girl Scout troop on Yale’s campus. Tapping into campus opportunities, resources, and mentorship, we create a powerful leadership experience to support girls of courage, confidence, and character who make the world a better place.
goals:
- To deliver empowering and compelling leadership development experiences to the next generation of female go-getters, innovators, and leaders in New Haven.
- To integrate traditional Girl Scout badge-earning programs with opportunities for cultural enrichment, civic engagement, athletics, and social advocacy on campus.
- To strengthen the link between Yale student life and the broader New Haven community.

name: Campus Resources - Administrators User Group for Yale Connect
mission: Provide a place for training, shared documents, turorials and info sharing for Yale staff who are administering their Yale connect sites in the Campus Resources Group type or bucket
benefits: learning cool tools to reach the Yale community, saving time for my office

name: Canadian Students' Association at Yale - An Undergraduate Organization
mission: The purpose of this organization is to organize events at which Canadians may convene and nurture relationships with their fellow country-people. It is also an opportunity to welcome non-Canadian Yalies who wish to learn more about Canada and its customs.

name: Capital Assistance Project
mission:
The Capital Assistance Project allows YLS students to provide substantive legal research and writing support for death penalty practitioners around the country. Students gain experience in capital defense and advocacy work while contributing to the anti-death penalty movement.
 Last year, CAP members worked on nine projects in partnership with The 8th Amendment Project, the Atlantic Center for Capital Representation, the ACLU Capital Punishment Project, the Center for Death Penalty Litigation, Reprieve, and the Southern Center for Human Rights.

name: Career Network for student Scientists and Postdocs at Yale
mission: The Career Network for student Scientists and Postdocs at Yale (CNSPY) was established to provide graduate students and post-docs with a platform to explore diverse career options and to build an extensive professional network of peers, career mentors, and faculty advisors. Our events allow our members to meet and learn from career mentors while building a community of peers. We aim to establish new avenues for collaboration, business ventures, and job opportunities while supporting an entrepreneurial environment among science trainees at Yale.
benefits: CNSPY recruits talented and motivated STEM graduate students and postdocs at Yale to drive the growth and development of our organization and to maintain our presence in the Yale Scientific Community as a core entity for career awareness and outreach. Team members engage in a variety of activities ranging from business development, communications and public relations, brand management, program management and event organization, while also recruiting career mentors and faculty advisors. These activities provide challenging opportunities for personal and professional growth and skill development and will allow you to build an extensive professional network of peers and mentors while having fun with a creative and collaborative team.

name: Catholic Law Student Association
mission: The Catholic Law Students Association (CLSA) is a group of Catholic law students offering a Catholic perspective to legal issues and a welcoming and supporting environment for all.

name: Cell Therapy Interest Group
mission: To educate and engage in dialogue on the development of cellular therapy, current therapy, and emerging research in academic, clinical, and commercial settings.

name: Center for Collaborative Arts and Media
category: Arts: Other, Arts: Visual Arts, Media/Technology
mission: The Center for Collaborative Arts and Media (CCAM) is Yale’s media laboratory for everyone. At CCAM we investigate intersections of art, science, and technology through research, programs, and exhibitions. A wing of Yale Arts, CCAM does not provide curriculum, but instead focuses on guiding students, faculty, and visiting artists in expanding and exploring all manner of projects.

name: Center for Continuing Education
address:
409 Prospect Street
New Haven, Conn 06511 United States
mission: The Center for Continuing Education at Yale Divinity School provides opportunities and resources for churches, clergy, and laity to foster the knowledge and love of God in their communities. The Center makes available the theological resources of YDS —events, lectures, programs, instructional resources, publications, and more—to enable and enrich ministry and lay learning. These resources are intended to support faith formation, religious education, and personal and professional enrichment.

name: Center for Engineering, Innovation and Design
address:
15 Prospect St
New Haven, CT 06511 United States

name: Center for Green Chemistry and Green Engineering
address:
370 Prospect Street
New Haven, CT 06511
mission:
The Center for Green Chemistry & Green Engineering at Yale is addressing some of the world’s most pressing challenges at the nexus of resource issues. Green Chemistry and Green Engineering represent the fundamental building blocks of sustainability and our chemists and engineers are creating the scientific and technological break-throughs that will be crucial to the future success of the human economy. The Center for Green Chemistry and Green Engineering at Yale works to stimulate and accelerate these advances. It is our mission to advance sustainability by catalyzing the effectiveness of the Green Chemistry and Green Engineering community. Our approach is multi-disciplinary, and our Center has affiliations with diverse groups and schools on the Yale campus. 
Specifically, we seek to accomplish four Key Objectives.
*Prepare a diverse next generation
*Advance Science
*Raise Awareness
*Catalyze Implementation
goals:
Focus areas for The Center:
Policy and Outreach
The Center engages in policy, communication, and outreach initiatives that raise awareness of and support for GC&GE. In this dialogue the Center engages with a wide network of stakeholders, including NGOs, industry, academia, and government, as well as local communities and the general public.
Education
A robust educational program is an essential element of the Center. Center activities are focused on educating undergraduate and graduate students in the principles and practice of GC&GE. The Center also serves the wider academic community by providing opportunities for faculty training and by developing and disseminating GC&GE curriculum materials.
International Partnerships
Green Chemistry & Green Engineering principles are rapidly spreading through both industrialized nations and the emerging economies. In all regions, the Center engages with the network of scientists, engineers, policy-makers, business people, and public health and environmental experts focused on sustainability science on behalf of the greater good.
Industrial Collaborations
GC&GE can only provide meaningful impact on the challenges of global sustainability when implemented on a large scale. For this reason, collaboration with industry is a key part of the Yale Center’s work. Direct engagement creates a dialogue that informs industry of the latest research breakthroughs in the field of sustainable science and technology. Likewise, such engagement informs academic researchers on industry’s most important concerns. This dialogue facilitates a direct line for implementation of these innovations.
Research
The Yale Center supports and advances research in Green Chemistry and Green Engineering (GC&GE), a critical component to building the community, designing and discovering innovative solutions, and achieving a sustainable future. The Center serves as a catalyst to both Yale and the greater Green Chemistry and Green Engineering communities for discipline-specific and cross-disciplinary research collaborations focused on key areas of GC&GE within science, technology, and policy for sustainability.
More details can be found here: http://greenchemistry.yale.edu

name: Center for International and Professional Experience
address:
55 Whitney Avenue, 3rd Fl.
New Haven, CT 06510 United States
mission:
The Yale Center for International and Professional Experience is a group of offices that work together, and with other academic advisers on campus, to support students throughout their four years at Yale as they make decisions about their academic plans and explore career options.
→ cipe.yale.edu
CIPE Offices:
 • Career Strategy (ocs.yale.edu)
 • Fellowships and Funding (funding.yale.edu)
 • Study Abroad (studyabroad.yale.edu)
 • Summer Session (summer.yale.edu)

name: Center for Language Study (CLS)
address:
370 Temple Street
New Haven, CT 06511 United States
mission: The Yale Center for Language Study supports and promotes the study of language and culture by fostering a community of practice for language instructors and teaching fellows and by offering diverse language programs across the university. The CLS is committed to innovation and excellence in language education, informed by current research, and to lifelong learning, both inside and beyond the classroom.

name: Central Americans for Empowerment at Yale - A Student Organization
mission: Central Americans for Empowerment (CAFÉ) at Yale aims to create a space for Central American students to come together and discuss and celebrate the diversity within the isthmus as well as aims for a voice through political and cultural education and advocacy for issues regarding Central America.

name: Chabad at Yale
mission: It is the mission of Chabad at Yale University to open the doors of Judaism to the Yale community. We strive to create a “home away from home” by providing a warm, diverse, and non judgmental environment for the exploration of the Jewish religion, culture, and heritage. Chabad at Yale serves the Yale community with unconditional love and concern for every person regardless of their background, knowledge or affiliation. Chabad at Yale creates a sense of community while cultivating the Jewish leaders of tomorrow.

name: Challah for Hunger
mission: Challah for Hunger is a group that empowers students to fight hunger nationally and in their own communities. We will bake challah, sell it, and donate the proceeds to a local nonprofit fighting hunger in New Haven.

name: Chi Alpha Christian Fellowship
mission:
ARTICLE I  - NAME
The name of this organization shall be Chi Alpha Christian Fellowship (XA) at Yale University. This will be the special name and acronym used to refer to our group on and off campus and among other organizations.
ARTICLE II - PURPOSE 
	The purpose of Chi Alpha shall be to develop the spiritual life and abilities of the students in relation to God, to each other, and to the world at large within a Pentecostal Christian context and in a manner consistent with the teachings of the Assemblies of God USA. Chi Alpha is open to all Yale undergraduate students and, though its name is Greek, it is not a fraternity or sorority. The name is a reflection of the National Chi Alpha Christian campus organization. As part of this mission, Chi Alpha seeks to introduce fellow collegians to an authentic relationship with Jesus Christ. Chi Alpha plans to do this through:
1.	Prayer - Communication with God.
2.	Worship - Expressions of thanks through word, music, and service.
3.	Fellowship - Community of students developing quality relationships.
4.	Discipleship - Learning about Jesus and following His example.
5.	Mission - Living a life that reflects our relationship with God in what we say and do.
Chi Alpha is a member of Yale Religious Ministries whose external Directors are Affiliated Chaplains of Yale University.

name: Child Psychiatry Interest Group/Cohen Mentorship Group
mission: The Donald J. Cohen Mentorship Program/Child Psychiatry Interest Group is sponsored by the Yale Child Study Center and designed to expose medical students to the field of child development and psychiatry. We strive to foster an interest in pediatric medicine and psychiatry through a variety of events, as well as through mentoring relationships with physicians in the Child Psychiatry Department.

name: China Hands Magazine
mission:
The US-China relationship is widely recognized as the most important bilateral relationship in the 21st century. The United States and China dominate the world in terms of economic output, military spending, and geopolitical influence. Leaders from both the US and China have endeavored to build a symbiotic relationship between the two countries. China Hands Magazine seeks to extend the project of strengthening US-China relations to students from both countries.
We see a dearth of student publications dedicated to promoting US-China relations on campuses in the US or China. In order to fulfill this mutual intellectual curiosity of students from both countries, we have built a platform for discussion and education about China-related issues and US-China relations.

name: Chinese Adopted Siblings Program for Youth
mission: Statement of Purpose: CASPY will cooperate with the Asian American Students at Yale to bring an enriching educational and cultural experience to adopted siblings from China in the community.

name: Chinese American Students Association
mission: The Chinese American Students Association is designed to facilitate a Chinese American community that educates the Yale University campus on anything and everything that involves Chinese Americans and Asian Americans today. CASA tries to further political activism for Chinese American and Asian American interests on campus, seeking to be not only reactive but also proactive in its search to further the Chinese American/Asian American political agenda. CASA is heavily involved with the Asian American Students Alliance / Political Action committee and works cooperatively with all the other organizations on campus in order to provide the optimal power and voice for the Chinese American community. In addition to nurturing political awareness concerning Chinese Americans, Chinese American Students Association also strives to promote social interaction and unity through numerous popular activities like hosting our annual Lunar New Year event, Cultural Show, mixers, and other social activities. CASA also plays a sizable role in organizing and driving many activities during Asian Pacific American month. Others include study breaks, karaoke nights and movie screenings. CASA also reaches beyond the Yale community by taking trips to New York's Chinatown, creating intercollegiate coalition with other CSAs such as Harvard's CSA and Columbia's CSC and inviting guest speakers to Yale. CASA also plays a role locally in New Haven, with a community outreach program seeks to encourage interaction between Yale and Chinese American children from the New Haven area.

name: Chinese Undergraduate Students at Yale
mission: Our mission is to create a community for Chinese undergraduate students at Yale and to promote Chinese culture on campus.

name: Chocolate And Confectionary Artisans Organization
mission: The purpose of CACAO is to advance interest in the fields of the culinary arts. Cultivation of appreciation of fine chocolate, a gourmet commodity, is learned skill and a key goal of the organization. Our members will develop a greater respect for chocolate as a food item that pervades communities and cultures across the world. A focus of CACAO is also to foster a deeper understanding of the larger implications of chocolate in the world: the history behind chocolate, the production of chocolate, the nutritional impact of chocolate, and the relevance of chocolate in culture. CACAO will highlight outreach and education; our goal to focus on sustainable methods will be accomplished by purchasing resources from suppliers with an understanding of fair advocacy in chocolate production and hosting events and activities that promote social awareness.

name: Choose Life at Yale - an Undergraduate Organization
category: Advocacy/Policy, Health/Wellness, Medical/Nursing/Public Health, Political, Science/Technology, Service/Volunteering
mission:
Article I: Statement of Purpose
Choose Life at Yale (CLAY) is an organization that provides a forum and community for Yale students who oppose abortion. CLAY upholds the dignity of human life through weekly meetings, discussions, campus outreach, special events, and other educational initiatives.
Additionally, CLAY provides support and educational resources for women in crisis pregnancy situations on campus and in the local area.
goals:
-To create a culture of Life on campus and beyond 
-To uphold the dignity of every unborn child and every mother 
-To educate students on causes of abortion, health risks, philosophical dilemmas, and financial support systems
-To serve mothers in the local community through volunteer service trips to St. Gianna's Pregnancy Resource Center
-To empower women to choose life!

name: Christian Union Lux
mission: The purpose of Christian Union at Yale, by God’s grace and power, is to create an environment that develops and nurtures mature spiritual leaders, preparing them to make a Godly impact in American society and in the world at large. The group will seek to promote greater awareness and understanding of the Holy Bible and Christian Faith in the Yale community by appropriate means such as speakers, Biblical courses and studies, book discussions, leadership training, community service, fellowship, and other activities. To this end, Christian Union at Yale freely associates with the regional ministry Christian Union.

name: Circle K International
mission: Circle K International (CKI) is committed to developing the leadership skills of university students through service and advocacy to nurture responsible citizens and leaders with a lifelong commitment to community service worldwide.

name: Circle of Women Yale Chapter
mission: The Circle of Women Yale Chapter is a Chapter of the global student-run nonprofit, Circle of Women, which facilitates access to secondary education for girls around the world through projects in partnership with local grassroots organizations.

name: CityStep
mission: We are a group of dancers, teachers, and people who love working with young people and come together twice a week to dance, laugh, and learn with our wonderful students. Our mission is to promote creative self-expression and mutual understanding through movement and creativity.
goals: Continue working with IRIS, the Integrated Refugee and Immigrant Services's after-school program, which services New Haven youth. We want to put on an end-of-the-year showcase in Spring 2022!

name: Class of 2026 Mid-Orientation Programs Leader Training
Classics Graduate Program
type: Graduate School of Arts & Sciences (GSAS) Administration

name: Climate Change Science and Solutions Learning Community
mission: Businesses, ecosystems, industries, societies, and political systems are all vulnerable to climate change. This LC focuses on the science of climate change and on investigating innovative, interdisciplinary ways to address it.

name: Climate Change SIG
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups

name: CLS Office & Staff
mission: The Yale Center for Language Study supports and promotes the study of language and culture by fostering a community of practice for language instructors and teaching fellows and by offering diverse language programs across the university. The CLS is committed to innovation and excellence in language education, informed by current research, and to lifelong learning, both inside and beyond the classroom.

name: Club 2 Soccer
mission: The formation of Club 2 Soccer was a response to the high demand of female soccer players at Yale. We are a club soccer team for women at Yale to practice soccer skills and play against other schools in a semi-competitive and relaxed environment. Our goal is to include as many people as are interested in playing the game, but not in an overly rigorous fashion.

name: Club Colombia
mission: Club Colombia is an organization seeking to unite Colombian students and friends of Colombia, offering both groups and the greater Yale community an opportunity to learn more about, and share the culture of, Colombia. This will be achieved through a combination of local, on-campus events, including movie screenings, Cultural Nights,mixers with other cultural groups, and typical Colombian dinners.

name: Club Geo
mission: The mission of Club Geo is to encourage community-building and facilitate informal peer-to-peer advising opportunities between undergraduate students of the Yale Department of Earth and Planetary Sciences. Club Geo hopes to host a variety of events including team-building activities and advising events in conjunction with EPS administration and the EPS graduate student organization, the Dana Club. These events include but are not limited to bluebooking sessions, hiking and camping trips, movie screenings, career panels, ice cream and coffee socials, and graduate school application workshops. In addition, Club Geo seeks to increase undergraduate attendance at the EPS lecture series, Colloquium, by organizing “chalk-talks” before or after the lectures.

name: Club of Argentine Students at Yale
mission: The Club of Argentine Students at Yale will first and foremost strive to advance Argentine culture within the Yale Community. The Club will provide an institutional framework to allow for regular gatherings of individuals from Argentina, and as those interested in its culture. Similarly, the Club will coordinate events including, but not limited to, guest speakers, Argentine art expositions, and film screenings. This cultural advocacy will provide a space for discussion and learning about Argentine culture amid the whole of the Yale community. Furthermore, the Club will provide orientation and support for incoming or prospective Argentine students to ensure their inclusion in the Yale community. Finally, the Club will establish institutional relationships with similar organizations in other Universities and other networks with similar purposes such as the Yale Alumni Club of Argentina.

name: Club Venezuela
mission: Club Venezuela is an organization seeking to support members of the Venezuelan community at Yale College. In addition to providing opportunities to share in our common heritage, Club Venezuela is looking to provide institutional support in fostering dialogue regarding the political and socioeconomic crises in Venezuela, including their implications on members of our community and beyond.

name: Code for Good
mission: Code for Good strives to empower students to use technology for social impact, whether that be through socially-minded hackathon entries, internships, or other personal projects.

name: Code Haven
mission: Our mission is to inclusively increase access to computer science among middle school students, regardless of previous interest.

name: Combined Program in the Biological and Biomedical Sciences (BBS)
type: Graduate School of Arts & Sciences (GSAS) Administration
address: New Haven, CT 06511

name: Commensality Club
mission: The commensality club will engage members of this community through multi-sensory food experiences and the fundamental act of communal dining.

name: Common Ground
category: Cultural, Religious/Spiritual, Social, Sports/Outdoors, Special Interest
mission: Common Ground is a student group at YDS that invites anyone and everyone to the shared work of caring for the earth, our common ground.

name: Communication and Consent Educators
mission:
The Communication and Consent Educators (CCEs) are a large, diverse group of undergraduates working together to foster a more positive sexual and social climate on campus.  We aim to end sexual violence by transforming our corner of contemporary culture into one where respect, mutuality, and mindfulness are the norms.  A safe campus is critically important, but we want even more – we want Yale to be a place where everyone can thrive.
Through workshops, trainings, and conversations, we help students identify troubled dynamics and develop skills for effective interventions; even better, we work on strategies for avoiding problems altogether. CCE teams also work (usually in collaboration with other student groups) to change the campus environment itself, reimagining traditional events and practices to maximize the opportunities for ideals to flourish.

name: Community Health Educators
mission: The mission of Community Health Educators is to empower members of the New Haven community with the skills, self-respect, and knowledge needed to make healthy decision about their bodies and their futures, and to train and support college students to educate members of the New Haven community about health issues.
goals: Community Health Educators (CHE) writes and presents health education workshops in New Haven public schools. CHE is comprised of Yale undergrads, providing a unique potential for peer-to-peer discussions. We present accurate, practical, and reliable information in a non-threatening, informal environment using language, examples, and activities that are relevant to students. We impart knowledge rather than dictate behavior, empowering students to make healthy decisions for themselves.

name: ConBio (Society for Conservation Biology)
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups

name: SAYPH- MPH Biostatistics Group
mission: SAYPH Subgroup for the Biostatistics Department

name: SAYPH- MPH CDE Group
mission: SAYPH Subgroup for CDE Students

name: SAYPH- MPH HP Group
mission: SAYPH Subgroup for HP Students

name: Contigo Perú
mission: Contigo Perú has as its primary goals the promotion of Peruvian culture at Yale and the creating of a space for Peruvian and Peruvian-American students, as well as those with an interest in the country. The club will do so through social events (gatherings, meals, parties, etc.) and cultural events (guest speakers, exhibitions, film screenings, gastronomical events, etc.). CPE intends to advance understanding about Peru and its culture, while helping students to navigate what it means to be Peruvian.

name: Contour A Cappella Group
mission: We are an A Cappella group dedicated to the adaptation and performance of modern Chinese music. We comprise of graduate and professional Yale students passionate about singing and arranging.

name: Council on Latin American & Iberian Studies - MacMillan Center
type: MacMillan Center for International and Area Studies
mission: The Council on Latin American and Iberian Studies (CLAIS) at The MacMillan Center  seeks to enhance the understanding of Latin America and the Iberian Peninsula through collaborative efforts focused on meaningful partnerships and exchange of ideas and academic research. The Council draws on the strengths of Yale’s pioneering departments of History, Political Science, Anthropology, and Spanish and Portuguese, among others, to offer a broad array of courses, cultural events, scholarly lectures, and academic research.
