CLAIS organizes several colloquia series, sponsors research abroad, coordinates outreach programs, convenes international conferences, and supports faculty activities and collaborations throughout Latin America and the Iberian Peninsula.

name: Crafternoons
mission: We want to give Yale students a weekly space to just relax and focus on crafts.
goals: Organize virtual hangouts for crafting and relaxing.

name: Crisis Text Line at Yale - A Student Partnership
mission: Mission: To recruit and train Yale students as Crisis Counselor volunteers, and to connect our Yale student body to a convenient, reliable, and anonymous mental health help resource for immediate student-related crises via text messaging.

name: Critical Care Medicine Student Interest Group
Cuban-American Undergraduate Students Association
mission: The Cuban-American Undergraduate Student Association, better known as CAUSA, was established in 2005 to serve the needs of both Cuban and Cuban-American students by providing an open forum on campus wherein to share and promote our common heritage. CAUSA also seeks to foster dialogue and raise public awareness pertaining to the social, political, and cultural issues affecting both the Cuban and the Cuban-American communities in the States and abroad.

name: Cultural Connections
mission:
With all of the opportunities available and people to meet over the next four years, coming to Yale is exciting - but the unknown may create a little anxiety for new students. Everyone looks forward to successfully adjusting to the Yale environment and culture so that they can call this place their second home. To aid in this process, the Cultural Connections program (CC) was designed to introduce first-years to Yale’s cultural resources as well as to explore the diversity of student experiences on the Yale campus, with emphasis on the experiences of traditionally underrepresented students and issues related to racial identity. For over 40 years, first-year students have participated in an exciting week of engaging activities intended to facilitate their transition to Yale alongside their peers, CC counselors, and many members of the Yale staff. Activities include discussions with faculty experts about ethnicity, nationality, and race; panels on academic expectations by faculty; presentations on campus life by students; and group visits to local points of interest such as the Yale College cultural centers, local and University museums and parks.
“Without CC, I wouldn’t know the Yale that I know. The CC community was my first home, and it will be always be the one I come back to.” - Esul Burton, YC 2020

name: Data4Humanity
mission: Data4Humanity’s mission is to create social impact through the use of data science and advanced analytics. With the rise of data collection methods and data analysis tools, data scientists have the power to make a real difference in solving society’s most pressing social challenges. The aim of the organization is to facilitate a collaborative environment where members have the opportunity to work together on impactful projects in areas such as public health, education, conservation, development, and human rights.

name: Davenport Pops Orchestra
mission: The Davenport Pops Orchestra strives to provide the undergraduate community with a unique venue for student musicianship, specializing in pops repertoire (Disney, Broadway, etc). We're committed to bringing a different flavor of music to the Yale campus and hope to reach a broader audience base. Our number one priority is to encourage the diversification of student talent on campus.

name: De Colores
category: Cultural, LGBTQ, La Casa  Affiliate Org
mission: De Colores’ mission is to create a safe space to explore the intersections of queerness, latinidad, and other aspects of identity. We want to foster a community of growth and love. We want to hold dialogues that build consciousness.

name: Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Incorporated
mission: Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Inc. is an organization of college-educated women committed to the constructive development of its members and to public service with a primary focus on the Black community. Our purpose is to provide assistance and support through established programs in local communities throughout the world.

name: Demos
mission: The purpose of Demos is to bring science education into the elementary schools that we serve. By providing hands-on demos that focus on the tangible and everyday scientific phenomena we experience, Demos hopes to make science an accessible subject for all. In addition, we hope to provide our volunteers with teaching experience and an opportunity to engage with the New Haven community through service.

name: Design for America at Yale
mission: Design for America (DFA) is an award-winning nationwide network of university students using design innovation for social good. We are part of the nationwide network that started at Northwestern University in 2009. DFA's mission is to provide students the opportunity to work on diverse interdisciplinary teams, where they learn to apply a human-centered design philosophy to solve real, complex problems alongside passionate community members. We encourage students to apply their vast skill-sets to create social impact in their local communities through design thinking. DFA desires to build a strong student community that allows each student the capacity to take on any challenge they encounter in the future.
goals: Composed of students of a wide variety of majors, DFA Yale seeks to bridge the gap between the different parts of Yale’s student body. We  build teams composed of undergraduate and graduate students with different skill sets and experience levels. It aims to foster a culture of design by introducing students to the concept and process of human centered design as a way of tackling societal problems and manifesting innovative change in the New Haven-Yale community.

name: Despierta Boricua, the Puerto Rican Student Organization at Yale
mission: Despierta Boricua aims to bring together members of the Yale community who in any way identify with the heritage of the Caribbean island of Puerto Rico in celebration of its culture, history, and traditions. Despierta Boricua shall also take an active role in promoting the causes of the Puerto Rican people both from the island and its diaspora through education and activism. As one of the founding organizations of La Casa Cultural Julia de Burgos, the Latino Cultural Center at Yale, Despierta Boricua also aims to promote the causes and interests of the greater Latino community at Yale.

name: Dimensions
mission: Dimensions is a student-run organization with the mission to inspire, celebrate and empower women and gender minorities in mathematics at Yale, and their allies. The first group to explicitly support the endeavors of women and gender minorities interested and involved in mathematics on campus, Dimensions will help to formally create and facilitate this community mathematicians. Dimensions offers a mentorship program, pairing graduate students, upperclassmen and lowerclassmen based off interests, as well as workshops, speaker events and organized meetings with professors.  All are welcome to public events sponsored by Dimensions.

name: Disability Empowerment For Yale: An Undergraduate Advocacy Group
category: Advocacy/Policy, Cultural, Health/Wellness, Political, Social, AACC Affiliate Org
mission: Disability Empowerment for Yale (DEFY) is Yale’s only undergraduate advocacy and affinity organization for students with disabilities. We work on behalf of the hundreds of students navigating their time at this University with a disability. Our membership includes Yalies with physical disabilities, mental illnesses, chronic illnesses, temporary disabilities, sensory disabilities, addictions & substance dependencies, and learning disabilities, and New Haven community members with these disabilities.
goals:
DEFY’s vision is to make Yale more accessible and welcoming to students with disabilities, both physical and mental, chronic and temporary.
Primary Goals
Start a Conversation: Bring to light the issues surrounding disability to empower students, faculty, and staff to understand what it means to live and learn with a disability at Yale and to make this community more inclusive.
Foster a Community: Develop a robust, intersectional coalition of disabled people and allies to advocate for the disabled community, create networks of support, host events, facilitate conversations, and invite experts and advocates to campus to raise awareness.
DEFY is fighting for
--An equitable University response to the COVID-19 pandemic
--Greater accessibility in Yale coursework, dining, transit, health services & extracurricular activities 
--An academic program for Disability Studies
--A cultural center for students with disabilities which uplifts the voices of our community, hosts disability-related initiatives and events, and furthers the social model of disability
--Improved resources for students with disabilities
--The continued success of the newly imagined DPMP and the pilot Disability Peer Liaison (PL) Program

name: Disability Peer Mentor Programming
type: Poorvu Center for Teaching and Learning

name: Disabled Law Students Association
mission:
The Disabled Law Students Association is a law student affinity group comprised of communities situated within a broad disability umbrella. Our community includes disabled students, neurodivergent students, students with learning impairments or non-traditional learning styles, deaf students, hard-of-hearing students, blind students, deaf-blind students, students with chronic illnesses, students with mental health conditions or emotional disorders, and other students who receive or would like to receive accommodations. 
We define our affinity group broadly, welcoming anyone who identifies as a member. Our aim is to foster a sense of community and increase the legal profession’s accessibility and cultural competency surrounding disability. We provide individualized support to our members in accessing accommodations and ensuring their needs are being met at the law school, in internships, and across other contexts. It is our hope that, through our organization, our members can support each other in navigating the legal profession.

name: Disciples of Christ Student Group
mission: The UCC/DOC group gathers to share in times of fellowship over luncheon discussions, dinner socials, worship, and community service opportunities. All are welcome.

name: Discover Yale Library
mission: Library programs, resources, and research support for Yale students

name: Pitches and Tones A Cappella
mission: Pitches & Tones was founded in 2011 as an a cappella group independent of all other singing groups and councils. We perform a variety of member-arranged songs covering a broad spectrum of genres, often coupled with innovative choreography. Our objective is to find creative, entertaining, and enriching ways to share our passion for music with audiences both at Yale and beyond. Giving back is also central to our members, and we often perform at several informal charity events each year.

name: SAYPH- MPH SBS Group
mission: SAYPH Subgroup for SBS Students

name: Distilled Periodical
mission:
I. Interdisciplinary Ethos: DISTILLED believes that innovations in science and technology give rise to ethical and political concerns that demand rigorous interdisciplinary  discourse. Articles published in DISTILLED must be opinion pieces centered around a policy-relevant issue. An original claim or argument must be made, backed by primary academic literature sources. Furthermore, some kind of solution or follow-up action(s) should be proposed or explored. 
II. Inclusivity: Contributing writers, editors, and other DISTILLED team members need no previous journalism experience -- any student passionate about interdisciplinary science and its implications for social and public policy can, throughout our extensive editorial process, work with other students, postdocs, and professors to develop ideas into articles rigorously supported by primary scientific literature.
DISTILLED strives to lower the barrier to entry of scientific publication and provide socially-oriented students of diverse backgrounds the resources and networks they need to develop their ideas into publishable essays.
III. Mentorship: As a campus-wide organization whose editorial team, authors, and readership unite undergraduate, graduate, and professional students from diverse scientific disciplines across Yale, DISTILLED has a unique opportunity to foster formal and informal communities of mentorship. Particularly, working on the publication and attending DISTILLED meetings and events affords undergraduate students the opportunity to meet more experienced student scientists and researchers, learn from their trajectories, and build mentoring relationships. More generally, by bringing together diverse students in shared work and space, DISTILLED is a hub for organic cross-disciplinary, cross-cohort community and collaboration.

name: Distilled: A Scientific Advocacy Publication - Graduate Division
mission:
I. Interdisciplinary Ethos: DISTILLED believes that innovations in science and technology give rise to ethical and political concerns that demand rigorous interdisciplinary discourse. Articles published in DISTILLED must be opinion pieces centered around a policy-relevant issue. An original claim or argument must be made, backed by primary academic literature sources. Furthermore, some kind of solution or follow-up action(s) should be proposed or explored.
II. Inclusivity: Contributing writers, editors, and other DISTILLED team members need no previous journalism experience -- any student passionate about interdisciplinary science and its implications for social and public policy can, throughout our extensive editorial process, work with other students, postdocs, and professors to develop ideas into articles rigorously supported by primary scientific literature.
DISTILLED strives to lower the barrier to entry of scientific publication and provide socially-oriented students of diverse backgrounds the resources and networks they need to develop their ideas into publishable essays.
III. Mentorship: As a campus-wide organization whose editorial team, authors, and readership unite undergraduate, graduate, and professional students from diverse scientific disciplines across Yale, DISTILLED has a unique opportunity to foster formal and informal communities of mentorship. Particularly, working on the publication and attending DISTILLED meetings and events affords undergraduate students the opportunity to meet more experienced student scientists and researchers, learn from their trajectories, and build mentoring relationships. More generally, by bringing together diverse students in shared work and space, DISTILLED is a hub for organic cross-disciplinary, cross-cohort community and collaboration.

name: Divinity Colloquium
mission: Our mission is to provide a forum dedicated to the fostering of collective academic conversation at Yale Divinity School. The Divinity Colloquium seeks to offer monthly sessions with a semi-formal yet low-pressure environment, during which students may present their work to an audience of fellow students. The Colloquium might take a form such as a discussion of a pre-circulated draft or a practice version of a conference talk. The ultimate aim of the Colloquium will be to provide a regularly convening venue wherein students may present their work to their peers while receiving suggestions, constructive criticisms, praise, and that overall collective academic experience that should define graduate school.

name: Divinnovation
mission: Divinnovation (a linguistic braiding of “Divinity” and “innovation”) is a YDS student-led partnership with the Tsai Center for Innovative Thinking at Yale (“Tsai CITY”). At Divinnovation, we believe that theology and faith-based imaginations are relevant to non-religious social and business practices. Conversely, we also believe that business mechanisms are relevant to the theological space and the broader world of ministry. Divinnovation seeks to develop alumni and cross-campus ecosystems to support the faith-based projects and social impact work of future leaders emerging from YDS. We also offer an interdisciplinary space where students can explore the intersections of theology and social entrepreneurship, law, business, and other non-traditional ministries.

name: DivOut
mission: DivOut is a fellowship of Yale Divinity School students, faculty, and staff of all sexual orientations and gender identities dedicated to the full and equal participation of gay, lesbian, bisexual, asexual, queer, transgender, genderqueer, and gender non-conforming people in faith communities and society. We are committed to care for one another, to seek justice for those who have been oppressed, and to work for the full inclusion of all people in the family of God. We provide materials on LGBTQIA issues and information to members of the community dealing with related topics. In addition to ongoing discussion groups, DivOut sponsors lectures, panels, worship services, and other educational, social, and cultural events.

name: DocComm SIG
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups
mission:
DocComm is the branch of the Student Affairs Committee comprised of and representing the doctoral (graduate and postdoctoral students) community:
1.	Mission: The Student Affairs Committee (SAC) is an elected body of active students at the Yale School of Forestry & Environmental Studies (F&ES). SAC is dedicated to facilitating communication and understanding among the F&ES student body, administration, and staff; advocating on behalf of the student body on pressing issues; supporting student interest groups and executing a limited number of official duties.
2.	Principles: SAC is designed to be a cooperative, non-hierarchical, transparent, and nimble body. SAC will not discriminate based on age, gender, marital status, sexual orientation, race, color, creed, religion, national origin, political orientation, or physical abilities, and will actively strive to combat discrimination in all its forms. SAC strives to include the interest of the F&ES community including current students, administration, staff, alumni, and the broader Yale and New Haven communities.
goals: We are a liaison between the YSE doctoral community and the larger YSE community, particularly faculty and staff. We aim to represent the views and needs of the doctoral community within YSE and foster a more cohesive and unified doctoral program.

name: Poorvu Center: Yale College Writing Center
type: Poorvu Center for Teaching and Learning
address:
301 York Street
New Haven, Conn 06511 United States

name: Doox of Yale
mission: Doox is here to make incredible music and have a great time. We perform for everyone we can to spread our music all around the earth!

name: DOWN Magazine
category: Cultural, LGBTQ, Publication, AACC Affiliate Org, AfAm Affiliate Org, NACC Affiliate Org, Cultural: Mixed Race
mission: The purpose of this organization is to amplify the diverse voices and interests of students of color at Yale, and to provide a safe space for those students to be their full selves. DOWN was born because of a dearth of excellent journalism covering the topics that matter to students of color at Yale. Our goal is primarily to provide that coverage. Our secondary goal is to provide a supportive space for students of color to challenge each other to become better writers, and to encourage and train new writers to help them find their voice. We achieve this goal through frequent writing workshops led by people like Mark Oppenheimer, Director of the Yale Journalism Initiative and various faculty members of the English Department at Yale.

name: Dr. Tschudi's Research Ethics and Responsibility EPH 600
mission: This course seeks to introduce major concepts in the ethical conduct of research and some of the personal and professional issues that researchers encounter in their work. Sessions are run in a seminar/discussion format. Prerequisite: doctoral student or postdoctoral status only.
benefits: Get credit for using the Yale Connect App to check into class every week!

name: Dwight Hall at Yale - Center for Public Service and Social Justice
address:
67 High Street
New Haven, CT 06520 United States
mission:
At Dwight Hall, we believe in change. We believe that change is possible and worth fighting for. And in these uncertain times, we believe change has never been more important. That is why we do everything we can to make social change a reality, and why we are dedicated to shaping those who will one day shape the world.
Founded by undergraduates in 1886, Dwight Hall at Yale is an independent, social-profit organization whose mission is to nurture and inspire students as leaders of social change and to advance justice and service in New Haven and around the world. As the Center for Public Service and Social Justice, Dwight Hall’s values include a commitment to the common good, compassion, diversity, growth and learning, partnership, critical reflection, and student initiative.
benefits: Thousands of Yale volunteers are trained to bring a community-centered approach to their service through 85 student-run member groups  and more than 100 individual fellowship and experiential learning opportunities that engage approximately two thirds of the student body each year in service and social justice activities, and promote community-based learning, innovative programming, best practices, and collaborative communication.
goals:
Program delivery is organized around three principles.
Engage: Forging trusted partnerships with New Haven neighborhoods, organizations, and agencies through community engaged service.
Grow: Developing students’ intellectual, moral, civic, and creative capacities to the fullest with experiential learning, internships, fellowships, mentorships, and trainings.
Advance: Supporting intergenerational community-building collaborative projects, and incubating innovative solutions that bring about lasting change in the New Haven community and around the world.

name: Dwight Hall Socially Responsible Investment Fund
mission:
By helping to manage the Dwight Hall endowment, we employ a modern approach to socially responsible investing (SRI) that aims to have a positive environmental and social impact while outperforming standard investment benchmarks. It is our hope that our portfolio will contribute to the success of Dwight Hall, inspire the creation of similar funds at other colleges, and make SRI both accessible and exciting to college students.
For more, visit bit.ly/dhsri-interest.

name: Dwight Hall Student Executive Committee
mission: To nurture and inspire students as leaders of social change and to advance justice and service in New Haven and around the world.

name: Dwight Hall’s First-Years in Support of New Haven
mission: Initiated in 2015, First-Years in Support of New Haven is an academic-year program for Yale College first-years to sustainably connect and consciously engage with the vibrant New Haven community. Our aim is to learn from the leadership and experience of community partners who dedicate their professional and personal lives to our shared city. We strive to foster open conversations about the changing New Haven/Yale relationship and engage in sustainable service that will continue throughout each student's time in New Haven.

name: Dzana Dance
category: Cultural, Performance: Dance, AfAm Affiliate Org
mission: Dzana exists as a means for different African cultures to interact and be showcased to the greater Yale community through dance.
goals: Our goal this year is to expand our impact online and through social media in order to introduce the diverse nature of African dance to Yale

name: Economic Considerations of Nature (ECON) SIG
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups

name: Ecosystem Management and Conservation Learning Community
mission: Students engaged with this LC build a knowledge base and develop skills they can use to help steward and conserve ecosystems, ensuring that human and nonhuman species can coexist across landscapes.

name: Eli Whitney Student Society
mission: The Eli Whitney Student Society (EWSS) consists of the Eli Whitney students at Yale and aims to serve their collective academic and social interests as non-traditional undergraduates.

name: Elm Campus Partners - Apartments for Yale Students & Affiliates
address:
1140 Chapel Street, Suite 201
New Haven, CONN 06511 United States
mission: To strengthen communities through our management of inviting public and private spaces, our exceptional customer service, and our financial stewardship.
benefits:
Elm Campus Partners, LLC  is proud to provide property management services on behalf of Yale University. We hope our web site www.elmcampus.com will make your transition to New Haven and your experience living here a better one.  All properties under our management are owned by Yale University.
We offer a variety of customer support services, including on-line maintenance requests. If you do not find what you are looking for, give us a call at (203) 776-4466 or send us an  e-mail and we will do our best to answer your questions.
To view available apartments, please complete our free rental  application on our website.
Welcome to Yale University and New Haven!

name: Elm City Echo
mission: The Elm City Echo aims to promote awareness of homelessness and displacement by giving contributors a community-oriented platform to amplify their voices and experiences. The Echo empowers individuals through the process of sharing while centralizing creators’ voices. Since 2011, student volunteers have worked with individuals experiencing extreme poverty and homelessness to record and publish the prose, poetry, and artwork. Each collaboration begins with volunteers visiting one of our community partners (Columbus House or Fellowship Place) to facilitate the storytelling process. Once a semester, we publish the pieces in a literary magazine that is freely distributed around New Haven.

name: Emerging Biomedical Scholars at Yale
mission:
The Yale School of Medicine has a mission to “Educate and inspire scholars and future leaders who will advance the practice of medicine and the biomedical sciences.” These scholars pursuing advances in the biomedical sciences are spread across departments at the School of Medicine, the School of Arts and Sciences, and Yale-New Haven Hospital. They span a range of professional levels, including medical and graduate students, medical residents and post-docs, early-career investigators, and tenured professors. There are few mechanisms to unite this community of scholars and to bridge the horizontal boundaries of discipline and the vertical boundaries of professional hierarchy. Emerging Biomedical Scholars at Yale aims to provide a unique, unifying service to this broad community. Its mission is to:
1) Serve as a hub to foster professional and social interactions across departments and stages of professional development, in order to facilitate scientific synergies and exploration and professional mentorship.
2) Serve as a central clearinghouse of useful information and resources for a wide range of biomedical scientists, including: core facilities and technical expertise, training in skills such as grant and fellowship writing, other opportunities for education and career development, and means to help promote sustainable work/life balance.

name: Emerging Majority Students Association
type: School of Public Health Student Organizations
address:
47 College St
New Haven, CT 06510 United States
mission: The Emerging Majority Students Association (EMSA) is committed to creating and fostering a sense of community among minority/underrepresented students and students interested in the promotion of diversity and inclusion at YSPH. Our three-fold mission is to: 1) serve as a platform for voicing the concerns and interests of minority students at YSPH, 2) promote a multicultural, professional, and academic environment that enables us to address the health issues of minorities in the field of public health with an emphasis on the New Haven community, and 3) collaborate with admissions toward raising the level of underrepresented minority/underrepresented student recruitment, admission, and retention at YSPH.

name: Energy and the Environment Learning Community
mission: Students engaging with this LC examine issues related to energy systems and technologies, policies, and economics — helping them to build a knowledge base they can use to assess the problems posed by both traditional and emerging alternative energy sources.

name: Energy SIG
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups
mission: The Yale School of the Environment Energy Student Interest Group works on a variety of fronts to increase opportunities and knowledge of the energy sector at Yale. Our activities include hosting guest speakers, running workshops, organizing field trips, and providing networking opportunities for students focused on the nexus between energy and the environment. In addition, we work closely alongside faculty to expand the number of energy-focused course offerings at YSE and to bring in experienced industry professionals as guest lecturers.

name: Engender
mission: The members of Engender fundamentally believe that our university's—and our country's—greatest strength is its abundant diversity. The vast array of experiences and talents possessed by Yale's student body is a central element of Yale's effect on its students through its curriculum and on the world through its research. While committed to celebrating success stories of inclusion at Yale and elsewhere, Engender also hopes to identify and work to overcome the remaining barriers to equal access and inclusion for women, students of color, and LGBTQ students at Yale and across the country. As Yale and some other educational institutions take increasingly strong stances in favor of equal opportunity in official university contexts, Engender hopes to complement these efforts by cultivating inclusive social spaces on and off campus to integrate all students into the fabric of the Yale community.

name: The Tory Party
mission: Debate society. Member of Yale Political Union.

name: Engineers Without Borders- Yale College Student Chapter
mission: The Mission Statement of EWB-Yale Student Chapter is to help carry out the mission of EWB-USA by developing and implementing its own sustainable engineering projects in disadvantaged communities. Other goals include: 1) gaining practical engineering experience 2) find unique engineering solutions for developing nations 3) to create relationships between Yale students and members of developing communities.

name: English Conversation Groups
benefits: Join us on Zoom for a daily conversation to check in, connect with other international students, and practice your English conversational skills. The Zoom calls take place Monday through Friday from 12:30-1:30 PM, and are facilitated by a volunteer several days throughout the week. *This group is only open to Yale Affiliates.

name: English Language Program
address:
370 Temple Street
New Haven, CT 06511
mission: The English Language Program, part of Yale’s commitment to internationalization, supports academic communication and the cultural and professional development of the Yale international community. Offering a program centered on assessment of needs, advising, instruction, and consulting, it draws on the expertise of its instructors and staff, as well as a network of English language resources across Yale.

name: Environmental Data Science at Yale (EDSY) SIG
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups
mission: EDSY is a student-led organization passionate about GIS, remote sensing, AI, and conservation tech.

name: Environmental Education Collaborative
mission: Established in April of 2019, EECO is Yale’s first student organization dedicated to inspiring a generation of environmentally-conscious individuals by teaching K-12 students in New Haven. EECO builds strong relationships with local schools and community organizations by developing and teaching place-based curriculum, as well as by leading field trips in New Haven and implementing sustained environmental education projects to reinforce students’ learning in the classroom.
goals: To achieve our mission, EECO members teach a series of weekly lessons during the school year that focus on environmental issues relevant to New Haven. Lesson plans are designed by members based on a curriculum outline that is developed by leadership in line with the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS), adopted by Connecticut in November 2015. This year, due to COVID-19, we are creating online educational materials that can be shared with students virtually.

name: Environmental Film Festival at Yale
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups

name: Environmental Justice at Yale SIG
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups
mission: Environmental Justice at Yale (EJAY) is committed to creating a space for students to advocate for and discuss issues of environmental justice at any scale. We are a collaborative group that works to push Yale, the School of the Environment, and our community to be more inclusive and equitable by addressing issues of EJ.
goals:
Advocate for the continued inclusion of EJ and critical frameworks in academic spaces.
Create informal spaces and events to engage with EJ discourse and decompress.
Connect YSE students with external organizations and other student groups working on issues of justice.

name: Environmental Leadership and Training Initiative
mission: We train and support people from all sectors and backgrounds to restore and conserve tropical forest landscapes using strategies that support biodiversity and livelihoods.
benefits:
The Environmental Leadership & Training Initiative (ELTI) is a capacity development program of the Yale School of the Environment (YSE). ELTI trains and supports people from all sectors and backgrounds to restore and conserve tropical forest landscapes using strategies that support biodiversity and livelihoods. Since 2006, ELTI has trained over 7,800 leaders throughout the tropics.
Students can engage with ELTI in a variety of ways including student internships, seminars and field trips, and summer research at ELTI sites in the tropics. We also invite you to engage with us for connections to our vast global network of partners and alumni, to access our extensive educational resources on tropical forest landscape management and to learn more about our 10+ years of experience working on capacity development.

name: Environmental Media and Arts SIG
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups

name: Environmental Policy Analysis Learning Community
mission: This LC helps students gain a deeper understanding of the foundations and methods of policy analysis, including how to evaluate their strengths and weaknesses and how to apply these frameworks to a broad range of environmental and resource management issues.

name: Perspectives: The Yale Journal on Israel and Palestine: An Undergraduate Publication
mission: Perspectives: The Yale Journal on Israel and Palestine: An Undergraduate Publication is an initiative intended to create an inclusive, positive space for engagement with issues pertaining to Israel, Palestine and the region. By welcoming a diverse group of individuals and perspectives into this literary forum, we aim to cultivate and expand healthy and open dialogue on these issues on campus and in the Yale community. Submissions to the Perspectives: The Yale Journal on Israel and Palestine may be academic papers, personal essays, perspective pieces, or artistic contributions. All contributions are required to be respectful in their treatment of other students, perspectives, and demographic groups. Submissions will be evaluated by the Editorial Board and reviewed for publication.

name: Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation Interest Group
Episcopal Graduate and Professional Students Fellowship at Yale
address:
305 Crown St.
New Haven, CT 06511 United States
mission: To provide graduate and professional students at Yale with inspiring worship, to cultivate amongst them a transformative community, and to nurture in them a passion for service and justice.
goals: ECY is run by and for college students and young adults, and our goal is to offer you a community in which you can grow to know, love, and serve God in whatever ways give you meaning and strength for your journey. Wherever you are on your journey, whoever you are, and whomever you love, you are welcome. For ECY, radical inclusion is God’s idea behind creating the wildly diverse human race, so we welcome all of God’s children “from every tribe, language, people and nation,” as well as from every gender expression, sexual orientation, race, ethnicity, immigration status, and economic background.  We seek to support all young people – undergraduates, graduate students, and young adults – as leaders of the Episcopal Church, both lay and ordained.

name: Equity in the Job Search - an annual event for Graduate students, Postdocs and the Yale Community
mission: The Equity in the Job Search Symposium is an annual symposium that provides practical, hands-on workshops to assist graduate students and postdocs at all stages of the STEM job search. We integrate this career advice with data-driven discussions of gender bias to expand the conversation of gender bias to a larger population. The guiding principle behind the symposium is to overcome bias for all. We aim to impart to our participants the idea that everyone benefits from more inclusivity.

name: Estamos Unidos Asylum Project
mission: The Estamos Unidos Asylum Project pursues the advocacy of immigrant rights issues on campus and through a volunteer trip to the U.S.-Mexico border. Students assist attorneys in helping immigrants at the southern border seeking asylum and serve as local and on-campus advocates for immigration issues.

name: European Horizons
mission: The Yale Chapter will hold weekly meetings with members chosen from the Yale student body. These meetings will include think tank activities such as discussing possible policies that European governments or the European Union could implement in response to current events and crises. We will provide students with a platform to publish work pertaining to the European Union and European politics. The Yale Chapter will be responsible for organizing the European Horizons regional conference at Yale this year. This organization will hold speaker events open to the public, and will endeavor to include other like-minded organizations to bring the experts in the European field together. Through these series of activities we aim to have real impact on the state of the European Union and produce material that will be published in the European Horizons Journal, and other publications.
goals: European Horizons' main goal is to became a policy incubator and a mentor on policy writing to young students globally. European Horizons' goals are to bring together students with world leaders of today to discuss global issues and write policies in response to these issues.

name: European Studies Council
type: MacMillan Center for International and Area Studies
address:
34 Hillhouse AveRm 242
New Haven, CT 06511 United States
mission: The European Studies Council at the MacMillan Center promotes innovative research on Europe’s past and present in the context of regional and global interactions. The Council collaborates with schools and departments throughout Yale to support faculty, students, and visiting scholars by sharing their interdisciplinary expertise on European affairs with the broader public. The Council aims to foster a wider understanding of Europe as both a place and an idea, reflecting the evolving nature of the region and its network of connections throughout the world.

name: Evangelical Fellowship
mission: The Evangelical Fellowship strives to nurture spiritual disciplines, fellowship, and Spirit-led worship among the entire YDS community. Weekly meetings include prayer and intercession, contemporary worship, and brief reflections from students. We invite the YDS community to join us as we seek to encounter the presence of God in our daily lives.

name: Every Vote Counts
mission: The objective of Every Vote Counts at its core is rooted to this two-fold mission: more people should vote and the active voting population should reflect our nation’s demographics. To this end, our organizational divisions and offerings are tripartite. In our legislative policy and advocacy division, we oppose advances of gerrymandering and support pro-voter legislation that enhances fair districting. Next, through voter registration, social campaigns, and distribution of best practices, we hope to leverage technology along with comprehensive analysis of the practices of high turn-out nations in order to bolster robust voter engagement. Finally, we advocate at the local level in our Civic Education division through outreach to local high schools in our community and engage in civic education workshops for those approaching the voting age. Every Vote Counts is not affiliated with a political party, but essentially is a member organization of concerned citizens.

name: Expressive Arts Therapy
mission: Our group aims to facilitate expression through integrative, multimodal art processes, allowing for personal growth and transformation. We hope to allow patients with cancer, Alzheimer's, and other chronic conditions the ability to showcase their journey through different art forms, including paintings, drawings, and mixed media collages. Our group will also participate in an ongoing global project, Hope Made Visible, which features flags in a variety of art media that express patients' strengths, fears, wisdoms, and expressions of hope.

name: Fair Haven Tutoring
mission: The purpose of this organization is to provide tutoring services to low socioeconomic status, English language learner and minority youth at Fair Haven Elementary School in order to improve their skills in the key areas of math and literacy in which they are struggling

name: Fans of the New England Patriots
mission: The Fans of the New England Patriots is a club dedicated to providing a space for Patriots fans at Yale to watch games, talk about the Patriots and feel comfortable supporting their team amidst a sea of haters. We come together to break down the brilliant decisions of Bill Belichick, reminisce on the GOAT Tom Brady and appreciate the continued success of the Pats.
goals:
Recruit a new class of first-years
Types of events will vary depending on if there is an NFL season

name: Federalist Party, The
mission: To resist the errors of the age and to promote among ourselves the tempering of taste, the ennoblement of custom, the correction of judgment, the cultivation of virtue, and the perfection of friendship.
goals:
The Federalist Party is a conservative debating society and a member of the Yale Political Union. Our debates tend to address issues of particular interest to American conservatives, including economics, religion, family, culture, foreign policy, and—true to our name—federalism. Our Party pays homage to the original Federalists—Hamilton, Madison, and Jay—and to their astute perception of human nature and good governance as illustrated in the Federalist Papers. These men understood that laws and norms may change with the times, but arbitrary intervention in the process is a short and nasty route to social caducity. When a people begin to think that they can improve society infinitely by incessant alteration of the legal and moral order, nothing remains settled, and every dear attachment, every right, and every bit of property are endangered.
The ladies and gentlemen of our Party hail from many backgrounds and schools of thought but are bound together by a shared pursuit of the truth. You will find that the friendships forged in that pursuit are neither geographically nor temporally bound as we are always seeking to know not merely what is most efficient, fair or equal, but what is right and good. Outside of debates Federalists spend time together over meals, toasting sessions, movie nights, basketball games, and other impromptu gatherings. We also host several conservative guest speakers throughout the year.

name: Fellowships and Funding

New Haven, CT 06510
mission:
Education at Yale takes place inside classroom, library, laboratory, and far beyond. Yale and outside funding options can help make it possible to pursue something amazing which you might not be able to do otherwise. Find support for research, study abroad, public service, unpaid internships, and self-designed projects, in New Haven and around the globe. Postgraduate fellowships support independent projects, graduate study, and much more.

Demystifying the world of money management — from credit cards to budgets to taxes, being a student comes with its own set of financial hurdles.
Explore and learn how to take ownership of your financial life.
finlit.yale.edu

name: FIRST at Yale - A Student Organization
mission: FIRST at Yale serves as a community of students dedicated to supporting FIRST. For Inspiration and Recognition of Science and Technology (FIRST) is an international robotics competition for K-12 students that aims to teach professionalism and cooperative competition through hands-on engineering. Yale is home to hundreds of FIRST alumni, and the FIRST at Yale organization was founded in 2017 to give these alumni a home to continue FIRST's mission as well as welcoming new members to the FIRST community. FIRST at Yale members help mentor teams, provide support and a professional network, volunteer at competitions, and more.

name: First Generation Professionals
mission: First Generation Professionals at Yale Law (“FGP”) seeks to provide a safe and welcoming space for Yale Law School students who are the first in their families to pursue a professional degree - primarily serving those who come from lower-income and working class backgrounds - to discuss and assist each other with their concerns as they navigate the environment of Yale Law School. We advocate for policies that better meet the needs of our members and seek to foster a broader conversation about class at the Yale Law School. Finally, FGP acknowledges and embraces our membership’s diversity and differences in all forms, including those of age, color, disability, ethnicity, gender identity or expression, geographic or national origin, political ideology, race, religion, sexual orientation, and veteran status.

name: First Love Yale - An Undergraduate Organization
First-Year Outdoor Orientation Trips
mission:
Freshman Outdoor Orientation Trips (FOOT) is an orientation program of backpacking trips for entering Yale freshmen led by two upper class leaders.  Students hike along trails to enjoy the views, cook simple meals, and set up tarps under the stars.  Freshmen hear about college life first-hand from older students.  However, much more is accomplished—students learn skills that have immediate practical use, they are challenged physically to reach goals and mentally to endure hardships, and learn they can accomplish more than they thought. Students come together and form a tight bond of lasting friendships, and they create a close group that supports them during the oncoming years. 
Goals of the leaders are to create an atmosphere of trust and inclusiveness, and to ensure the safety and well being of each freshman.  It is the mission of FOOT for students get in touch with themselves and the great outdoors in the wonderful wilderness of the Northeast.  In addition to the focus on freshmen, FOOT is a proven leadership training program for its leaders.  After undergoing our leader training sessions and leading trips, FOOT Leaders can apply the skills they have learned to almost any situation or career choice that involves problem solving, critical thinking and empathy for others.

name: Flyte Scholastics at Yale
mission: Flyte is an organization of Yale undergraduates committed to providing academic support and guidance to underprivileged students in New Haven. It is Flyte’s objective to empower these students with academic tutoring, SAT/SSAT help, and college preparation.

name: Food SIG
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups
mission: Sustainable Food & Agriculture SIG aims to educate the YSE and larger Yale student body on the environmental issues and challenges of agriculture, and to highlight the agricultural ecosystem as an important component of ecosystem studies and management. It is also our goal to help students, staff, and faculty make the connection between the academic and the personal facets of agriculture, by illustrating how and where the food they eat is produced. The group works actively with local farmers and producers, as well as international agricultural and food system issues.

name: Forestry Club (FC)
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups
mission: Forestry Club, as the hub of student-led community building at the Yale School of the Environment, creates memorable experiences that embody our core principles of community, inclusivity, sustainability, and leadership.

mission: Building on over a century of leadership in forestry and land conservation, this LC helps students gain the knowledge base they need to work collaboratively across environmental disciplines to manage forests in a way that respects the land and one another.

mission: Hosted at Yale University, the Graduate Conference in Religion and Ecology reflects a desire to provide a space for students to engage in dynamic, interdisciplinary conversations across curricular boundaries, and strives to connect ethos with ethics, and ethics to applicable practicality.

name: Gilder Lehrman Center for the Study of Slavery, Resistance, and Abolition
type: MacMillan Center for International and Area Studies
mission: The Gilder Lehrman Center for the Study of Slavery, Resistance, and Abolition is part of the Whitney and Betty MacMillan Center for International and Area Studies at Yale University. Since its founding in 1998, the Gilder Lehrman Center has been dedicated to the investigation and dissemination of knowledge concerning slavery and its legacies across all borders and all time, from the distant past through the present day. The Center fosters improved understandings of the role of slavery, anti-slavery, and the lasting harms of slavery in the functioning of the modern world. Through fellowships, workshops, public programs, and digital resources, the Gilder Lehrman Center supports scholarship, public history, and public education.

mission: The mission of Girls in Science is to instill a sense of confidence and curiosity toward the diverse sciences in young women, to build lasting mentorship relationships, and to work with the New Haven Public Schools to create opportunities for exploration for the students.

name: Girls on the Run
mission:
We see a gap in school systems nationwide in the way that girls are taught about their bodies. By teaching young girls to appreciate their bodies for the power and strength of which they are capable rather than what they look like, we hope to create a foundation for a lifetime of positive body image, high self-esteem, healthy relationships, as well as a love of running. 
We also hope that this organization will help break down some of the "bubble" between Yale and New Haven by promoting an extracurricular activity that goes beyond academics and partners with young girls in New Haven as positive female role models.

name: Global Surgery Interest Group
mission:
For a very long time, surgery was not included in the discussion of how healthcare could be improved worldwide, especially in the most remote corners of the earth. Only recently has surgery been brought to the table, being called the “forgotten step-child” of global health by Paul Farmer and many others. At the very core, global surgery is "a field that aims to improve health and health equity for all who are affected by surgical conditions or have a need for surgical care, with a particular focus on underserved populations in countries of all income levels, as well as populations in crisis, such as those experiencing conflict, displacement, and disaster.” Important to this effort is all aspects of surgery, including anesthesia, OB/Gyn, and nursing.
​
Currently, 5 billion people around the world do not have adequate access to basic surgical care. Worse yet, the disparity in surgical care is stark, with the poorest 30% of the world receives only 3-6% of operations, whereas the richest 30% receives almost 75%. 17 million people die and 77 million DALYS are lost each year because of this, greater than HIV/AIDS, malaria, and TB combined. Our global economy could lose 21 trillion dollars between 2015 and 2030, with 12.3 trillion lost by low- and middle-income countries, so the lack of surgical care worldwide is also a significant detriment to the progress of humanity. 2.2 million more surgeons, anesthetists, and OB/Gyns (SAOs) and an investment of $350 billion dollars is needed to prevent this from happening, with a goal to raise the operative volume of countries to 5,000 per 100,000 population, meaning an increase of 143 million more surgical procedures per year. It can be easy to get lost in the numbers, but ultimately, health is a human right, and no one should have to live with a condition that would have been treated had they been born somewhere else.
​
So the bigger question becomes how we address this need for surgical care. In the past, this has almost exclusively involved efforts such as week-long surgical missions and the provision of money/resources in order to acutely work on the problem. However, the field has evolved with the creation of the Lancet Commission on Global Surgery, which called for a more in-depth analysis. Their major report from spring 2015 outlined an approach through investigation, innovation, and implementation, pointing out that research, technology, and capacity-building efforts were necessary to advance the field. In addition, they did a thorough economic analysis which showed that upscaling the number of surgeons and operations alone will not work - an economic approach that helps decrease catastrophic health expenditure for patients and their families is necessary. As the Lancet Commission encompasses almost 110 different countries, efforts have now been set on working at the highest level - with governments, health ministers, and financial officers - to enact changes in policy and infrastructure for whole countries to improve people’s access to surgical care.
​
Ultimately, whether you are interested in surgery/anesthesia/OBGyn, global/public health, economics/finance, policy, technology/engineering, education/empowerment, statistics/research, or any combination of these, you have a very significant contribution to make to this growing field. And no matter how young or old you are, no matter how little or how much you can contribute, your involvement in global surgery is incredibly necessary and valuable.
*Reference: Meara, J, Leather A, Hagander L, et al. Global surgery 2030: Evidence and solutions for achieving health, welfare, and economic development. Lancet. 2015;386:569-624.

name: Good Life Center
mission: Our mission is two-fold: to empower students with evidence-based skills for fostering mental, physical, social, and emotional well-being, and to cultivate a campus culture that promotes wellness as a fundamental, accessible human right. We all deserve to be, feel, and do well at Yale.
benefits:
Due to public health & safety regulations, the physical GLC space will be closed for group reservations, events, and workshops during the fall semester. However, we will have lots of virtual wellness programming to keep you occupied! 
We offer a wide variety of programming that broadly focuses on physical and mental health education. In the fall, for example, we will host a "sleep well" series, meditation groups, workshops about how to use your study space for fitness, mental health empowerment workshops, speakers who will talk about things like the intersection between racial trauma & well-being, and more! Keep an eye out for the GLC newsletter to register.
Beyond workshops and events, you can also schedule a 30 minute one-on-one wellness check-in by emailing alexa.vaghenas@yale.edu. Please don’t be afraid to reach out! The GLC is here to support you during this challenging and unusual time.
goals:
In general, the GLC strives to educate students about the importance of self-care, as well as to help cultivate community, solidarity, and student resilience.
This year, however, the GLC is also committed to helping students create meaningful social connection amidst the socially isolating COVID-19 pandemic.

name: Grace Hopper Coalition of Students in Technology
mission: This organization was founded in order to carry the spirit of the Grace Hopper Conference throughout our daily academic and professional lives. We hope to help empower woman and minority students to pursue careers and graduate degrees in technology by connecting them with professional networks, recruiters, mentors and funding to attend the Grace Hopper Conference in October.

name: Graduate Student Assembly
mission: The Graduate Student Assembly is an elected body of Yale students in the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences. The Assembly’s goals are to identify the needs and concerns of graduate students, consider possible solutions, and present these to the Dean and other administrators. We also discuss, propose, and advise on possible changes to Graduate School policy proposed by the administration. The assembly provides a means for communication and deliberation both among graduate students and between graduate students and other members of the Yale community.

name: Graduate Student Disability Alliance
mission: The Graduate Student Disability Alliance (GSDA) is an affinity group for graduate and professional students who are situated within the disability umbrella. The primary function of the Graduate Student Disability Alliance is to create a sense of community among graduate students with disabilities, advocate for members of our community, foster a sense of belonging on campus, and support our members while they navigate graduate school and beyond.

mission: The mission of the Graduate Student Jazz Fusion Clinic is to provide a space for graduate student musicians to develop their jazz fusion playing through improvisational jams and meet others with similar interests.
goals: The JFC will host monthly jams for members.

The purpose of this club shall be:
1. To reduce the environmental impact associated with a school campus.
2. To engage and mobilize people around conscious living and environmental issues at Yale and in the New Haven area.
3. To use school campuses as a palette for modeling real-life solutions to sustainability challenges.

name: Green Haven Prison Project
mission: The Green Haven Prison Project meets with a group of prisoners dedicated to self-improvement at the Green Haven Correctional Facility. Every other week we have a shared seminar with the prisoners discussing current issue of political or personal interest.

name: Greenhouse Botanical Club
mission: The Greenhouse Botanical Club aims to provide a platform for members of Yale University to learn plant science but also have fun. Members will have the chance to learn plant propagation techniques and learn about plant collections at Marsh Botanical Garden. Moreover, we hope to influence undergraduate students to get involved in plant science in the future.

name: Groove Dance Company
mission: Groove Dance Company was founded in 2002 by a group of dancers who wanted to showcase a variety of different styles and to have fun exploring the world of dance together. We have evolved into a company that combines passion for all types of dance with a dedication to professionalism and technicality. Our mission is to communicate the joy of dance; we do this through our biannual performances for the Yale community as well as through dance education.

name: GSAS Graduate Professional Experience (GPE) Fellowship
type: Graduate School of Arts & Sciences (GSAS) Administration
mission: The GSAS Professional Experience (GPE) Fellowship is an exciting new initiative by the Yale Graduate School of Arts and Sciences that offers Ph.D. students the opportunity to work on meaningful projects in administrative offices across the university. This program is designed to expand opportunities for doctoral students to strengthen their professional skill set and broaden their career exposure by working with experienced administrators outside of their academic programs. In turn, by hosting a fellow, offices across Yale can take advantage of the diverse array of skills that Ph.D. students offer to advance their programming and projects.
goals:
Career Exploration:  Through a GPE Fellowship, you can gain exposure to academic administration as well as many professional roles found in organizations outside of academia, including: user experience research, exhibit design, journalism, corporate sustainability, finance, fund-raising, diversity initiatives, curriculum design, and event planning.
Mentoring:  You will have a unique opportunity to work closely with host mentors, many of whom also have PhDs, and may be able to participate in job shadowing and meetings with other members in university administration.  Through conversation and observation, you will expand your understanding of diverse functional roles, professional workplaces, and career transitions.
Skills Development:  If you would like to expand your professional skill set, the GPE Fellowship is for you!  Host organizations are looking for graduate students to help them with: Strategic planning; research; project management; program design and execution; communications; data analysis; best practices assessment…and more!

name: Italian Society of Yale Students and Affiliates
mission:
A. To bring together the members of the Yale Community interested in Italian culture with the purpose of creating a network and promoting Italian culture within Yale as well as fostering a sense of community and facilitating intercultural exchanges.
B. To work with other Italian Societies of international academic institutions and with other graduate and undergraduate organizations within Yale.
C. To maintain a connection with alumni members of the Society in order to establish a network among former and current members, especially in connection with the Yale Club of Italy.

name: Japanese Association of Students and Scholars at Yale
mission: The purpose of Japanese Association for students and scholars at Yale is to connect all Japanese and Japan-affiliated people on campus. Our group consists of people from academia, government, industry, or non-profit organizations, and will provide an opportunity to a network with different backgrounds.

name: Pi Beta Phi Sorority
mission: The mission of Pi Beta Phi Fraternity for Women is to promote friendship, develop women of intellect and integrity, cultivate leadership potential and enrich lives through community service.

name: Pick-Up Soccer Club - for Graduate and Professional Students
mission: To generate a friendly environment for pick-up soccer on campus.

name: Korean Graduate Student Association at Yale
mission:
Korean Graduate Student Association at Yale is an active organization on campus with around 150-200 members. Our purpose is to help Korean and Korea-interested graduate students navigate opportunities and communities around campus. 
The purpose of the organization is to enhance the network and the academic and vocational cooperation among the Korean graduate students at Yale, and to provide social, cultural and educational functions for Korean graduate students as well as the general student body at Yale. We also serve as as a liaison among Korean Associations in the New England region and we seek to promote the network with other associations at the university and the community.

name: Kpop Dance Society at Yale - a graduate and professional student organization
mission: KDSY is a Kpop dance society at Yale. We hope to encourage interaction and collaboration with other dance groups on campus and make KDSY a reflection of Yale's diverse and creative environment. Also, allowing students of all cultural and dance backgrounds to participate in bringing the variety, skill, and vibrancy of Korean dance to the stage.

name: Ludi et Veritas - Board Game Club  for Yale students and affiliates
mission:
Ludi et Veritas is a boardgaming group at Yale with the goal of getting people together to play board games. We meet regularly to play and teach board games that promote the social interaction, intellectual stimulation, and just plain fun that comes out of unplugging from our busy lives.
Our current membership composition is:
5% Undergraduate students
70% Grad/profesional students
20% Postdocs/faculty 
5% Family of the above

name: New Haven Science Fair Program - for Graduate Students
mission:
The goal of the New Haven Science Fair Program is to work with students and teachers from New Haven Pre-K through Grade 12 classrooms, to help them carry out investigative hands-on science fair projects in order to promote skills in critical thinking, the scientific process, and science communication.
The program now engages about half of the population of the New Haven Public School system (over 8,000 students) and almost all of its schools (43 schools), utilizing more than 200 volunteers for mentors and judges each year.

mission: PROSPER (Peers for Resilience, Openness, Support, Perspective, Empowerment and Relationships) is a Graduate and Professional (G&P) student-run organization dedicated to fostering honest, moderated, educational and peer-supportive spaces to help inspire, connect and empower students to rise to the challenges of G&P education.

mission: The Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies Working Group invites faculty to share their projects – often works-in-progress or recent publications – with graduate students and faculty on Mondays, from 5:30-7:00 PM, WLH 309, with a light dinner served. Works typically are pre-circulated one week in advance and then the guest offers framing remarks prior to an open discussion of the piece.

name: Yale Graduate Student Debate Association
mission: The Yale Graduate Student Debate Association is now open! Join our community of debaters from across Yale for our biweekly debates on critical issues and monthly speaker training workshops. If you've ever wanted to debate or have years of debating experience this is the group for you. See you at our next event!

name: Yale Office of Career Strategy (OCS) - GSAS & Postdocs
type: Graduate School of Arts & Sciences (GSAS) Administration

name: Guild of Bookmakers
mission: The purpose of the Guild of Bookmakers is to make the experience of bookbinding available to everyone on campus, to rekindle interest in bookbinding and the book arts, and to bring together people who share a love of bookbinding.
goals: The Guild of Bookmakers would like to hold weekly or biweekly workshops in the Davenport bindery (limiting space to comply with CDC and university guidelines to prevent the spread of COVID-19).

name: Precision Medicine Interest Group
mission: PMIG is a student-led organization dedicated to promoting student education and interests in precision medicine – a rapidly evolving, multidisciplinary field that seeks to tailor therapeutic and preventative care. Throughout the academic year, we will organize talks and panels from leaders in the field to help students to explore clinical, research, and career opportunities in precision medicine.

name: Guild of Carillonneurs
mission: The purpose of the Guild shall be to maintain a regular ringing schedule of the Yale Memorial Carillon in Harkness Tower during the academic year; to further the musical education of its members by, among other things, meeting regularly as a group to perform for each other and visiting other carillons at least once a year; to teach and train underclassmen in the art of carillon-playing during the annual Heel and to elect new members into the Guild after auditions at the end of Heel; to organize a carillon concert series each summer; to perform at official functions of the University; to maintain and further good relations with carillonneurs at other carillons around the world, the Guild of Carillonneurs in North America (GCNA), and the national carillon schools in Europe; to maintain and enlarge the library of music sheets and books and literature on campanology; and, to encourage general interest in the bells and the art of carillon-playing at the University and in New Haven.

name: HackYale Student Group
mission: HackYale is an organization of students who are passionate about bringing Computer Science and modern technology to the Yale community. HackYale offers a wide array of lectures and workshops on many topics in the modern world of software and technology. HackYale aspires to cultivate a passion for code, creativity, and innovation in our students, to raise technological literacy among the Yale student body, and to empower Yalies with the knowledge they need to realize their vision and actualize their potential.
goals: HackYale is an organization for students to teach other students various topics and tools in software development with an emphasis on real-world applications.

name: Hangarak
category: Cultural, Performance: Singing, AACC Affiliate Org
mission: The purpose of Hangarak is to perform songs from the Korean repertoire while staying true to Yale’s traditions of a cappella. This purpose will be actualized through Hangarak's mission to promote, celebrate and share Korean culture through music.

name: Hanppuri
mission: Hanppuri is an organization meant to provide a sense of community for the Korean international students at Yale. With ever-increasing numbers of international Koreans coming each year, it is important that we provide a community where they can find a safe haven and somewhere to escape from some of the hard cultural transitions they may have had to make.

name: HAPPY (Hypertension Awareness and Prevention Program at Yale)
mission: HAPPY is a Yale University student organization committed to providing regular hypertension screening services, linking hypertensive patients with available care, and eliminating barriers to follow-up care for chronic hypertension, for the low-income and homeless populations around New Haven, CT. We engage student volunteers and leaders in active volunteerism, educational outreach, research, publications, fundraising, and other innovative projects to achieve highest quality of our services and maximize our service impact. We envision creating a successful model at Yale and New Haven and replication our model of success in other universities across the country by establishing a national non-profit organization.

name: Happy Hands
mission: Just like any other language, ASL (American Sign Language) cannot exclusively be learned in the classroom. To obtain mastery, one must spend time interacting with the deaf community and understanding its culture. Thanks to Marrakech Inc.'s cooperation and support, we can provide students with an opportunity to do just that. By pairing members with deaf residents in Marrakech's Winsted home, Happy Hands hopes to cultivate meaningful friendships and help combat the isolation and dehumanization often experienced by members of the deaf community. Our goal is to drive home the idea that small acts of kindness, such as befriending someone and treating them with respect, can go a long way in bringing people joy. We hope to demonstrate the importance of compassion, especially towards a community that, unfortunately, tends to get overlooked in society. In an effort to spread awareness of deaf culture, we would love to take part in Dwight Hall's Days of Service, where interested students could volunteer with us for a day and immerse themselves in the deaf/ASL community.

name: Harbor Scholars: A Dwight Hall Program at Yale
mission: Harbor Scholars: A Dwight Hall Program at Yale is a service, scholarship, and advocacy organization that seeks to address the unique challenges faced by those who do not benefit from the personal and financial support that many of their peers receive from family, both on campus and throughout Connecticut. This identity includes but is not limited to foster youth, emancipated minors, unaccompanied minors, estranged LGBTQ+ youth, and those who lack parental support for other reasons. In order to ensure the continued success of these individuals at the collegiate level, the program provides financial assistance, winter housing accommodations, community and social support to college students of this identity, starting with Yale in its pilot phase. The program also engages in mentorship and college counseling services for youth in out-of-home care across Connecticut and youth advocacy on the state and local levels.

name: Harmonies Between Us
mission: Harmonies Between Us provides an opportunity for undergraduate musicians at Yale to connect with the greater New Haven area through volunteer music performances at the Yale New Haven Hospital.
goals:
Conduct two separate Level 1 hospital volunteer performances. (A description of Level-1 performances is listed within our Constitution). We are hoping to have at least 6 volunteers at each performance and collectively prepare enough music for an hour-long video performance
Develop a more collaborative relationship with the hospital so that we can begin to establish a set protocol for each level of performance.

name: HAVEN Free Clinic
address:
Yale Physicians Building800 Howard Ave., Floor 1
New Haven, CT 06519 United States
mission:
The HAVEN Free Clinic is a student-run primary care clinic that partners with Yale University to provide the New Haven community access to comprehensive, high-quality health care free of charge. Our model is unique because we include members across various disciplines in health care, including medicine, nursing, physician’s associate programs, and public health.
We serve as a sustainable free clinic that provides uninsured adults in New Haven with primary care, wellness education, and assistance in securing health care while simultaneously educating health professional students at Yale about patient care and community health.

name: HAVEN Medical-Legal Partnership
mission: The Haven MLP is a partnership with HAVEN, a free clinic operated by Yale medical students every Saturday for uninsured patients, the great majority of whom are also undocumented immigrants. Law student volunteers work onsite at the clinic and meet directly with patients to conduct legal screening and identify issues that should be referred to NHLAA for possible legal representation. Common legal issues include immigration, wage theft, landlord/tenant concerns, and domestic violence. A training session is conducted at the beginning of each semester for interested students who can then sign up for individual shifts.

name: Haven of Hearts Chinese Christian Campus Fellowship at Yale
mission: The Haven of Hearts Chinese Christian Campus Fellowship at Yale is committed to be an open, Christian group that welcomes all Chinese-speaking graduate students and scholars, regardless of any denominational background (or none), race, ethnicity, age, nationality, sexual orientation, gender identity/expression, or physical or mental disability. We strive to serve as a safe haven to the members of this fellowship, by providing study, social, service, worship and ministry opportunities open to all Chinese-speaking graduate students and scholars. We are dedicated to the spiritual, ethical, intellectual, social, physical and mental well being of the community of Chinese graduate students and scholars. Though we are a Christian Fellowship, we are committed to collaborating with other religious groups to foster respect, open dialogue and mutual understanding among people of different faith and cultures.

name: Health and Education Advocates for Refugees
mission: Our organization’s main mission is to provide accessible and comprehensible pamphlets and/or brochures on physical and mental health necessities, targeting refugee populations in New Haven. Our organization also hopes to raise awareness on the mental and physical health of refugees on Yale’s campus. The topics that will be discussed on these pamphlets and/or brochures include, but are not limited to, dental hygiene, women’s hygiene, nutrition, and disease prevention.

name: Health and Environment at Yale (HEY)
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups

name: Health Professionals Recruitment and Exposure Program
HealthCORE
type: School of Public Health Student Organizations
address:
47 College St
New Haven, CT 06510 United States
mission: HealthCORE is a student run non-profit at the Yale School of Public Health that exists to create and maintain sustainable partnerships locally and globally.
goals:
CURRENT GOALS:
1. Empower underserved communities through public health practice
2. Commit to learning about effective and sustainable practices, keeping local communities at the forefront of all initiatives
3. Allow students opportunities to lead and gain hands-on experience in non-profit global health work
4. Leverage established relationships between key faculty and respective communities
5. Expand both current domestic and global projects

name: Hear Your Song
mission: Hear Your Song is dedicated to giving children the opportunity to express themselves freely and have their voice amplified by song in clinical settings where they otherwise may not have the option for musical self-expression.

name: Helicon - The Yale Undergraduate Journal of Classics
Hellenic Society
mission: A. To bring together the Greeks of Yale University with the purpose of facilitating homogenous relationships, upholding Greek traditions, and formulating a support group that will help native Greeks feel more at home in their new country of habitation. B. To up-date members of the Hellenic Society, members of Yale University, and members of New Haven on Greek cultural and political events. C. To work with other Hellenic Societies of American academic institutions and to bond with the Greek community of New Haven. D. To maintain direct connection with alumni members of the Society in order for the alumni to have a vivid remembrance of their college years and to establish links among older and current members.

name: Her Campus at Yale - An Undergraduate Organization
mission: The mission of Her Campus at Yale is to provide a dynamic, supportive, and boundary breaking online platform for every college woman to write about the social, political, and health-based issues that matter in our college community.
goals: The primary goal of Her Campus at Yale is to get the voice of the young college writers heard in a way that remains supportive and genuine to the individual.
