To achieve this, we aim to make personal expression as boundless as possible through one-on-one connection with editors dedicated to preserving the individual's uniqueness in content, storytelling, and writing style, an open and encouraging policy for first time or less experienced writers, and a commitment to maintaining an empowering and welcoming space for writers of all identities.

name: Hillhouse Undergraduate Fund at Y
mission: The Hillhouse Undergraduate Fund at Yale (HUFY) is a student-run, educational finance organization focused on providing students at Yale, a platform for financial education while supporting on-campus entrepreneurship. HUFY will host events where aspiring Yale entrepreneurs are able to present their ambitious ideas, and potentially qualify for funding in the form of non-equity grants. Qualifiers will have the chance to be featured in the report we provide to our donors.
benefits: Members will receive early exposure to experience in the field of venture capitalism by vetting deals with reputable investors, performing diligence backed by alumni, and helping Yale startups gain exposure to a broad network of investors across the country.

name: Himalayan Students Association at Yale
mission: The Himalayan Students Association at Yale is a cultural group dedicated to preserving and celebrating the rich culture of nations within the Himalayan range. We are comprised of mostly Nepali, Tibetan, and Bhutanese students, and host events that spread awareness of Himalayan culture to the greater non-Himalayan population at Yale.
goals: Because there are only so few Tibetan, Nepali, and Bhuntanese students at Yale, the HSAY has combined students from across these nations to create a larger consortium that is allied through its shared Himalayan culture. Our ultimate goal is to celebrate our distinct culture with one another, while simultaneously sharing it with the greater Yale community.

name: Hong Kong Students Association
mission: The Hong Kong Students Association (HKSA) is a home away from home for students with ties to Hong Kong. We are a community group for those born and bred in Hong Kong, third culture kids who lived in Hong Kong at a certain point in their lives, individuals whose families emigrated from Hong Kong, and everyone in between. We aim to bring people together through shared cultural experiences, build community, and embrace all the various interpretations of what it means to be a Hong Konger.

name: Hult Prize at Yale
category: Advocacy/Policy, Entrepreneurial/Business, Food/Culinary, Funding, Health/Wellness, International Affairs, Leadership, Media/Technology, Medical/Nursing/Public Health, Professional, Science/Technology, Service/Volunteering, Social, Special Interest, International
mission:
The Hult Prize is a social impact-oriented entrepreneurship program, and there’s an opportunity for students to participate in the Hult Prize at Yale on-campus competition! The competition, which will occur near mid-December, will allow students to compete in teams of 3-4 in pitching a startup idea for the challenge of the year. 
If they are the selected winners of the On-Campus competition, they will move on to a Regional competition and, potentially, the final Hult Prize competitions where the winning team & idea wins $1,000,000 to build (or continue building) their startup. 
Additionally, they will receive mentorship from business leaders and entrepreneurs within the United Nations Foundation, the Hult Prize Foundation, and the Clinton Global Initiative. The On-Campus competition at Yale will send at least one team to Regionals, which will occur around March 2021.
goals:
The Food for Good Challenge: Hult Prize 2021 at Yale! 🏆 
In 2021, the Hult Prize is asking students around the world to build viable food enterprises that will create jobs, stimulate economies, reimagine supply chains, and improve outcomes for 10,000,000 people by 2030.

name: Hunger and Homelessness Action Project
mission: The Yale Hunger and Homelessness Action Project (YHHAP) is a student organization using education and action to alleviate housing and food insecurity in New Haven. Not-for-profit, we use our direct service, community involvement, and advocacy efforts to address root causes and to support immediate and long-term solutions for local food and housing deprivation.

name: Ichthys
mission: This group exists in order to provide a community and confidential space for individuals who identify on the spectrums of Christianity and queerness.

name: Immigrant History Project
mission:
At the Immigrant History Initiative, we believe in the power of storytelling to empower and drive change. Our mission is to fundamentally change to how we learn, talk, and think about race, migration, and social justice as a global society. We do this by providing comprehensive education resources that center on the histories and lived experiences of immigrant communities and people of color. 
IHI’s model has four key components: 1) multimedia curriculum & course design, 2) anti-racist resource development, 3) community engagement and empowerment, and 4) equitable education support.
​
We work with students, educators, schools, communities, and organizations to share the untold stories of immigrant diasporas. Immigrant history IS American history.

name: Implementation Science Group
type: School of Public Health Student Organizations
address:
47 College St
New Haven, CT 06510 United States
mission:
The ISG aims to help students with interest in public health and healthcare services to gain a foundation in Implementation Science by exposing them to high quality implementation science research, training, programming/practice, and resources. 
At ISG, we aim to bridge the gap between knowledge and practice in public health and healthcare.
goals:
Our goals are to:
1.	Attract student interest to Implementation Science 
2.	Provide students opportunities to network in Implementation Science
3.	Help students identify careers in Implementation Science

name: India at Yale - An Undergraduate Organization
mission: India at Yale plans to primarily host social and political events that bring the Indian community closer and proliferate interest and awareness about Indian issues on campus. We work with the South Asian Studies Council, among other entities, to achieve these goals.

name: Indonesia Yale Association: An Undergraduate Student Organization
mission: The Indonesia Yale Association: An Undergraduate Student Organization is a community of students interested in Indonesian culture, history, politics, and language. It serves to both strengthen the Indonesian community at Yale and to promote Indonesian culture towards the broader Yale community.

name: Industrial Ecology and Environmental Management (IEME) SIG
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups

name: Industrial Ecology and Green Chemistry Learning Community
mission: Industrial ecology and green design are key to addressing many of the sustainability challenges posed by ever-increasing industrial production.In this LC, students study the energy and materials used in industry, and develop strategic approaches to the design, use, and re-use of materials.

name: Ink & Vellum: Undergraduate Architecture Society
mission: As a society, Ink & Vellum will aim to support student activities and events related to the study of architecture and urban studies, particularly for students in those two majors. We intend for the society to support the current interests within the major, provide a stronger community which includes mentorship as well as educational opportunities outside of the Yale curriculum.

name: Institute of Sacred Music
category: Academic, Administrative, Arts: Other, Performance: Other, Performance: Singing
mission:
Welcome to the Yale Institute of Sacred Music—a premier center for the interdisciplinary study of sacred music, worship, and the related arts. Partnering with the Yale School of Music and Yale Divinity School, as well as other academic and professional units at Yale, the ISM prepares its students for careers in church music and other sacred music, pastoral ministry, performance, and scholarship.
The ISM engages musicians, artists, clergy, and scholars from around the world in rigorous training and collaboration, and offers a full calendar of concerts, lectures, exhibitions, and other events.

name: Institute of Sacred Music Student Life
mission:
- Envision, plan, and implement a range of events open to all ISM students to promote friendship, inclusivity, and respect.
- To empower students to imagine the shape and priorities of interdisciplinary community and create experiences to realize that vision for the benefit of the ISM, Yale, and broader New Haven communities.

name: International Refugee Assistance Project
mission:
The International Refugee Assistance Project (IRAP) organizes law students and lawyers to develop and enforce a set of legal and human rights for refugees and displaced persons. Mobilizing direct legal aid, litigation, and systemic advocacy, IRAP serves the world’s most persecuted individuals and empowers the next generation of human rights leaders.
Since its founding in 2008, IRAP has helped resettle over 4200 refugees and their families to 18 different countries and has trained over 2000 law students and lawyers in the process. The Yale Law School chapter is one of IRAP’s 30 student chapters across the United States and Canada.

name: International SIG
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups

name: International Society of Tropical Foresters (ISTF) SIG
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups
mission:
ISTF is the home for anyone interested in the tropics and also plays host to one of the largest and longest-running student-led conferences at Yale every spring! 
Learn more at https://istfconference.events.yale.edu/

name: International Spouses & Partners at Yale
mission: Meet other spouses & partners and learn more about the opportunities and resources available to you at Yale and in New Haven.
benefits: We would like to welcome and meet you, share activities, information, and friendship with you, and to put you in contact with other spouses and partners. We would encourage you to get involved and make your stay at Yale a positive and enriching experience. As part of such a diverse and culturally rich community, we have much to offer one another and there is much offered to us.

name: ISPY Babies @ Yale
benefits: This playgroup is an ideal opportunity for little ones to begin socializing and learning about group play. This is also a great meeting place for parents and caregivers looking for opportunities to practice speaking English, and for everyone to share experiences, tips and ideas. As the International Center does not offer a child-proof setting, Babies @ Yale is recommended for babies and toddlers that will be content playing together behind the glass partition (up to approximately one year). The OISS has a limited number of toys and books available to the group. Families are invited to bring their own activities to share with the group.

name: ISPY Book Club
benefits:
We have started the book club because we love to read and being a part of the international community at Yale, we also wanted an alternative way to improve our English skills together. We will read just one book a month and then come together for a weekly discussion. 
What Is a Book Club?
A book club is a reading group, usually consisting of a number of people who read and talk about books based on a topic or an agreed-upon reading list. It's common for book clubs to choose a specific book to read and discuss at the same time.

name: ISPY Chinese Conversation Group
benefits: The Chinese Conversation Group provides a relaxing environment that offers opportunities for conversing in Mandarin Chinese. People of all skill levels are welcome, including beginners, experts, native speakers, and everyone in-between. Please join us! You can improve your Chinese and learn more about China and Chinese culture by discussing a variety of topics.  Please contact oiss.chinese@gmail.com.

name: ISPY Crafty Mondays
benefits: We will be making many crafts and learning many different techniques. Our goal is to make a unique craft for each season and learn with each project more about U.S. holidays. Everyone is welcome to join.

name: ISPY International Cooking Club
benefits: Meet fellow food lovers from around the world to share new ideas and learn about others' cuisines. We will meet once a month to learn new cooking techniques and challenge one another!

name: ISPY Japanese Conversation Group
benefits: You can improve your Japanese and also learn about Japanese culture! Let's enjoy Japanese traditional games, seasonal events, and so on!

name: ISPY Job Hunters
benefits: Are you looking for a job? (Or will you be looking for one in the future?) Join our group and learn from others about creating effective resumes in the American way and writing superb cover letters, networking like a pro, nailing job interviews, and in general just to get support through the (sometimes stressful) process of job hunting. You don't have to go through it alone! For more information and summer meetings, please contact the group at oiss.jobhunters@gmail.com.

name: ISPY Knitting/Crocheting Group
benefits: Come together with fellow knitters (or those who crochet and do other needlework!) over a cup of coffee or tea at the IC. All are welcome, even if you don't know how to knit or crochet. For more information, contact the group coordinator at knittingoiss@gmail.com.

name: ISPY Productivity Group
benefits: The Yale Productivity Group, also known as the “Anti-Procrastination Group” or the “Trick-yourself-into-getting-things-done group” is for independent workers and learners. The group gets together to provide a structure, spend time with other people, break down goals into manageable pieces, set deadlines, and keep each other accountable.

name: ISPY Spanish Conversation Groups
benefits: Whether you're a beginner looking to learn Spanish or a native speaker, we have a group for you! Spanish for Beginners is targeted to those who are looking to learn the basics of Spanish, or brush up on language skills you might not have used in a while. Spanish Conversation Group is for advanced or native Spanish speakers. This group will engage in lively discussion and allows you to meet fellow speakers from around the world! The SPC is not a language class, but rather a weekly opportunity to practice your language skills in a pleasant, low-key setting. For both groups, please contact scgoiss@gmail.com.

name: ISPY Toddlers @ Yale
benefits: Meet fellow parents, bring your toddlers, and bond over shared experiences as international families in New Haven! This is best for toddlers ages 1-4.

name: ISPY Traditional Chinese Painting and Calligraphy
benefits: Chinese painting is one of the oldest continuous artistic traditions in the world, dating back to the Neolithic Period. This group is open to anyone interested in Chinese painting and calligraphy. Please contact YaleCPCgroup@gmail.com, for more information.

name: International Students' Organization
mission:
With over 750 members, ISO is Yale’s largest cultural organization and is omnipresent
on campus. Our cultural, political, social and inclusion councils organize culinary, artistic and other cultural events; the best parties on campus; debates and panels with global leaders; and
sessions to help students with the logistics of living abroad.
We strive to provide support to the international students at Yale College as well as organize a wide range of great events of interest to the entire Yale community.

name: Intimate Partner Violence Awareness Association
mission: We are interested in expanding awareness of the issue of intimate partner violence. We focus on increasing awareness of histories of intimate partner violence in idolized public figures and improving screening for intimate partner violence in college campus health services.

name: Italian Undergraduate Society
mission: Our mission is to promote Italian culture at Yale as well as serve as a support group for students coming from Italy by hosting events to network, socialize, and share information about Italy and any Italian-based events at Yale. Every year we welcome several new arrivals to our group, offering moral support and sharing our past experiences as Italian students living and studying abroad and at Yale.

name: J Street U
mission: The purpose of J Street U is to educate the Yale community about the current situation of Israelis and Palestinians, to advocate for American political support and involvement in the realization of the two-state solution, and to provide a community for liberal, like-minded students who are committed to a peaceful resolution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

name: J. Reuben Clark Law Society
mission: The J. Reuben Clark Law Society serves members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (Mormons) and all others interested in or affiliated with the LDS faith.

name: J.M Bolin Program
mission:
The Jane Matilda Bolin Program at Yale aims to provide New Haven area high school students of
color with an opportunity to develop academic skills and community through mentoring and
independent study of issues in the African diaspora. The

name: Jackson DEI Council
type: The Jackson Institute for Global Affairs

name: Jackson New Student Orientation 2022
type: The Jackson Institute for Global Affairs

name: Jackson Salon
type: The Jackson Institute for Global Affairs

name: Jackson Student Advocacy Council
type: The Jackson Institute for Global Affairs

name: Jackson Women
type: The Jackson Institute for Global Affairs

name: Japanese American Students Union
mission: The purpose of the Japanese American Students Union is to provide a forum on campus for political, social, and cultural conversation for Yale students of Japanese descent and students interested in Japanese culture. To this end, JASU will conduct outreach to the aforementioned students, organize events, and voice the concerns of the Japanese American community to the larger Asian American and University student-body.

name: Jerome N. Frank Legal Services Organization
Jewish Christian Bible Study
mission: Jewish Christian Bible Study is dedicated to fostering interreligious dialogue through Biblical study. We seek to learn from one another and our diverse approaches to a shared text, and hope to build a strong, collaborative relationship between Jewish and Christian communities on campus.

name: Jewish Medical Student Association (Maimonides Society)
mission: Welcome to the Maimonides Society, which is a Jewish Medical Student Association for the Yale School of Medicine. The Maimonides Society aims to welcome and support students by creating a Jewish community and family. Over the course of the year, we hold classes, events, dinners, holiday parties, and philanthropic events. The Maimonides Society supports our members by helping in any way we can including connecting students to clergy, learning opportunities, services, etc on the Yale campus. The Maimonides Society continues to evolve and pursue the current students' passions from medical ethics to Jewish education.
benefits: As a member of Maimonides Society at the Yale School of Medicine, you will be connected and plugged into the Jewish community and events at Yale. Additionally, upon request you can be connected with one of the many clergies as well as be invited to classes, events, holiday parties and more!
goals: The Maimonides Society aims to welcome and support students by creating a Jewish community and family.

name: Jook Songs
category: Arts: Other, Cultural, Performance: Other, AACC Affiliate Org
mission:
Jook Songs, Yale's Asian American poetry and performance group, seeks to elevate the creative voices of Asian Americans at Yale through writing, workshopping, and performing. 
Since our founding in 1999, we have collaborated with artists such as Sally Wen Mao and Princess Nokia, performed at the Asian American Writers' Workshop, hosted open mics for incoming Yale first-years, created youth poetry workshops with Splash at Yale, and more.

name: Journal of Literary Translation
mission: The Journal of Literary Translation (JoLT) publishes English translations of poetry and prose, as well as essays on the theory and practice of translation. A bi-annual magazine, JoLT seeks to showcase the excellent work of translators at Yale, to think critically about translation in a variety of contexts, and to explore metaphors for translation through the physical design of each issue. We also host readings and workshops to promote literary translation in the greater community at Yale.

name: Just Add Water
mission: JAW aims to provide magical comedy to the Yale Community and beyond, during both our on-campus shows, off-campus gigs, and biannual tours in various locations around the United States.  Whats more, JAW provides an environment for Yale students to explore themselves and the world around them via improv.  These tools have proven invaluable for our members, current and of legend, and explain in part why JAW is considered a second family by its members.

name: Kale Skies Club
mission: Kale Skies Club aims to encourage students to take time to admire and capture, through visual art, the sky around campus. We will provide access to art supplies (e.g. cameras, painting and crafts materials, etc.) for students to explore art mediums and styles in their journey documenting the New Haven. We will have organized events at various times and locations around New Haven to allow for different vantage points.

name: Kansas City Fan Club - an Undergraduate Organization
mission: The Kansas City Chiefs Fan Club strives to provide a place and a group for fans to watch the games of our favorite team while on campus. We look forward to cheering for the Kansas City, Patrick Mahomes II, and Andy Reid.

name: Kappa Alpha Theta
mission:
The object of Episilon Tau Chapter of Kappa Alpha Theta is to provide an environment that fosters philanthropic and service involvement as well as serves as a safe, welcoming community for its members and contribute positively to the campus community in general. 
The organization exists with the purpose of fostering deep and meaningful relationships among campus women encompassing diverse backgrounds.

name: Kappa Kappa Gamma
mission: Kappa Kappa Gamma is an organization of women, which seeks for every member throughout her life bonds of friendship, mutual support, opportunities for self-growth, respect for intellectual development, and an understanding of and an allegiance to positive ethical principles.

name: Kasama: The Filipino Club at Yale - An Undergraduate Organization
mission:
Our purpose is to engage the Yale community in issues regarding Filipino culture. We achieve this goal by hosting events that raise awareness of Filipino identity, such as cooking events, weekly dinners, mixers, cultural shows, and political discussions.
Kasama is a small club and our name - translated from Tagalog as "together" - embodies our mission to bring together members of the community both Filipino and non-Filipino. Thus Kasama is involved in the Asian American Cultural Center at Yale, The Asian American Students Alliance, and other umbrella organizations in order to embrace both Filipino and pan-Asian identity. We work closely with other groups at Yale to foster a sense of collaboration and inclusivity.

name: Korean American Students at Yale
mission: The Korean American Students at Yale (KASY) was established in 1984 by a group of students who wanted to promote the cultural, political, and social interests of the community of Korean Americans at Yale. In the thirty-plus years since its inception, KASY has grown both in size and influence, but still remains dedicated to its founding principles. Known as a vibrant and thriving undergraduate organization, KASY functions as a promoter of cultural awareness, a vehicle for political action, and most importantly, a tightly-knit family.

name: Korean Evangelical Student Group
mission: The Korean Evangelical Student Group consists of both Koreans and Evangelical students at YDS including Korean-American, Korean-Korean, and those who identify themselves as Evangelical. This group has two purposes in its foundation: To encourage and help the Korean students, so-called ‘minority group’ in YDS community, to grow and sustain their identities by the means of prayers, worship and fellowship. Also, to contribute to the YDS community,  the group will present its own ethnicity and religious identity with an open mind.

name: L'accademia degli Incogniti, altrimenti detto: The Yale College Puzzle Club
mission: L’accademia degli incogniti, altrimenti detto: The Yale College Puzzle Club is an organization that seeks to provide an opportunity for good company, stimulating conversation, and the under-appreciated art of jigsaw puzzles. We welcome all members of the Yale community to regular, informal meetings structured around puzzles of different sizes.

name: La Casa Cultural Julia de Burgos: The Latino Cultural Center at Yale
address:
301 Crown Street
New Haven, CT 06510 United States
mission: Building on a strong campus community, the Latino Cultural Center promotes a sense of unity among Latinx people at Yale. We are committed to providing a comfortable space where our diverse cultural heritage, history and traditions can be celebrated and explored by all Yale University and New Haven community members. In partnership with our resident organizations, La Casa provides opportunities that foster a sense of belonging and pride while supporting the intellectual, personal, leadership and social development of our students.

name: La Comunidad
category: Cultural, Religious/Spiritual, Social, La Casa  Affiliate Org, Cultural: Mixed Race, International
address:
409 Prospect Street
New Haven, Conn 06511 United States
mission: La Comunidad, the YDS Latinx/e Student Group, is dedicated to creating spaces for Latinx voices and bodies at YDS to gather and build community of solidarity and support. La Comunidad also seeks to provide resources to promote theological and cultural education for an entire YDS student body preparing for service to the church and the world. La Comunidad hopes to foster comunidad Latina: an open, welcoming place to learn, struggle, and celebrate.

name: La Unidad Latina, Lambda Upsilon Lambda Fraternity, Inc.
mission:
La Unidad Latina, Lambda Upsilon Lambda Fraternity, Incorporated primarily seeks to take a leadership role in meeting the needs of the Latino community through academic achievement, cultural awareness, community service and promotion of the Latino culture and people.
We strive to become the premier Latino Fraternity in the country. More specifically, we strive to become a nationally recognized Latino fraternal organization comprised of the best and brightest leaders committed to excellence in service and education.
Since its inception in 1982, La Unidad Latina has remained on the vanguard of political and community empowerment by developing influential leaders that strive to exert knowledge and power into its peers in order to attain mutual success. We commit ourselves to academic excellence, leadership development and cultural enlightenment, enhanced by a diverse cognizant membership. La Hermandad strives to preserve and promote an inclusive intellectual environment for its members, in addition to the general community.

name: Latina Women at Yale
category: Cultural, Food/Culinary, Health/Wellness, Leadership, Service/Volunteering, Social, La Casa  Affiliate Org, Cultural: Mixed Race
mission: Latina Women at Yale strives to create a community and safe space on campus for all Latinas across all intersectional identities. We listen to and learn from one another, as we support each other as Latina women.
goals:
- Mentorship for undergraduate students
- Social events
- Wellness and self-care
- Professional development

name: Latino Medical Student Association: Pre-health Latinx Undergraduate Society at Yale
mission: We aim to foster a community that offers reassurance and guidance for undergraduate Latinx students interested in pursuing health professions. Through service and education, we are also committed to sensitizing ourselves and others to areas of concern of the Latinx community regarding health and well-being.

name: Latinx Law Students' Association
mission: The Latinx Law Students Association (LLSA) supports Latinx students at YLS primarily by community building, providing professional and academic mentorship, offering opportunities for political engagement on issues confronting the Latinx community, and connecting members with Latinx alumni and practitioners.

name: Leadership Education and Development
mission: LEAD is a specialized program designed to provide integral leadership skills and introduce new and unique opportunities on campus to first-years. The program consists of weekly meetings where members can engage with prominent student leaders as well as other guests including SOM professors and Fortune 500 executives. In the second semester, students will apply the skills they have developed to a hands-on leadership project, working with student and or outside organizations. Students are selected by application during their first year.

name: Light and Truth
category: Academic, Arts: Other, Arts: Visual Arts, Political, Publication, Religious/Spiritual, Speech/Debate
mission: PROMOTING VIEWPOINTS ON YALE’S CAMPUS, LIGHT & TRUTH IS AN ONLINE STUDENT PUBLICATION THAT PROVIDES THOUGHTFUL AND RIGOROUS ESSAYS, ARTICLES, AND OTHER WORKS IN PHILOSOPHY, POLITICS, AND CULTURE.

name: Living History Project
mission: The Living History Project works with the Yale New-Haven Hospital to interview patients and share their stories with their families and care teams. Our aim is to bring patients' personal stories to life, so that their medical teams can provide more holistic care. Moreover, we provide undergraduates with the opportunity to experience patient-centered interactions.

name: Living Water at Yale – an Undergraduate Organization
Lo Stivale
mission: Lo Stivale is the Italian culture club at Yale. Our mission is to celebrate Italian culture (in the form of food, cinema, games, etc.) through internal events, yet also to promote it through events that are accessible to the Yale public at large.

name: LoggerRhythms
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups

name: Low Strung
mission: Low Strung provides cellists with the opportunity to explore new kinds of cello playing and perform for audiences on campus and worldwide.

name: Lowenstein Human Rights Project
mission: The Lowenstein Human Rights Project matches small teams of students with human rights organizations, other public interest NGOs, and governments to work on specific research, writing, and advocacy projects concerning human rights issues.

name: LuMin at Yale
mission:
LuMin at Yale is…
a community that honors questions
a gathering of spirit, conversation and justice-seeking
a refuge from academic pressure and deadlines
goals: LuMin at Yale (formerly Luther House) is the home for students on campus who come from a Lutheran tradition. While we are Lutheran by tradition, we welcome any and all people looking for a space to explore spirituality, religion, and themselves in a community that welcomes them for who they are.

name: Lutheran Student Organization
mission: Through worship, retreats, barbecues, and informal gatherings, the Lutheran Student Organization (LSO) provides fellowship for all students involved in the Lutheran traditions. Functioning within YDS’s Lutheran Studies Program, students plan Tuesday evening Vespers in the Henri Nouwen Chapel, joint Eucharist services with Berkeley Divinity School, and morning school-wide services in Marquand. The LSO also sponsors guest speakers and discussion forums for issues pertinent to the YDS community.

name: Lux Improvitas, An Undergraduate Ensemble
mission: Lux Improvitas seeks to explore the possibilities and boundaries of improvisation. While the central medium for much of this exploration is the “improvised play” (and its derivatives), every iteration of the Lux Improvitas ensemble should feel encouraged to explore styles of improv beyond this format and to create new forms of its own. We believe in creativity, in change, and in community.

name: Magevet
mission: Magevet's mission is to bring Jewish, Hebrew, and Israeli music around the world to communities that may otherwise not be able to access it.

name: Maison de Beauté at Yale: An Undergraduate Organization
mission: Maison de Beauté at Yale: An Undergraduate Organization hopes to be the dedicated group for the study and exploration of cosmetics. We hope to be the primary interface between Yale students and the world of cosmetics. We hope to examine the role of cosmetics in the anthropological, socioeconomic, cultural, and scientific spheres. We will look not only at contemporary uses of cosmetics but also investigate the history of cosmetics, going all the way back to Cleopatra and her use of perfumed oils or Catherine de Medici and her perfumes at the Santa Maria Novella apothecaries. We will attempt to answer the questions: What is beauty? And how does it interact with art and culture? This issue is especially pertinent in our world today with social justice. We will examine the use of cosmetics and “beauty” as something that defines and limits femininity and simultaneously something that empowers gender fluidity.

name: Malaysian and Singaporean Association
mission: The Malaysian and Singaporean Association (MASA) supports the interests of Malaysian and Singaporean students, and promotes the culture of both countries at Yale.

name: MAR Cohort Group
mission: Space for MAR current students. Receive news and updates from your year group reps, schedule events together as a program community and connect with other MAR'ers!

name: Marquand Chapel
category: Administrative, Arts: Other, Arts: Visual Arts, Performance: Other, Performance: Singing, Religious/Spiritual
address:
409 Prospect Street
New Haven, CT 06511 United States
mission:
Marquand Chapel is at the heart of Yale Divinity School.
Worship is planned and led by students, faculty, and staff of both Yale Divinity School and the Institute of Sacred Music, under the leadership of the Dean of Chapel and a team of staff and students. 
Worship in Marquand often draws on a wide variety of inherited Christian traditions, with the worship of many denominations being represented. Beyond that, though, we also pay attention to the rising number of people in Western society who have a lively interest in spirituality but feel no connection to traditional forms of church and worship. So Marquand is also actively engaged in original, creative, and experimental forms of worship, both for committed Christians and for those exploring the faith.
Attend Marquand five days in a row, and you may encounter an orthodox liturgy of St. John Chrysostom, a Mardi Gras worship party, a service of silent Lenten contemplation, a chapel converted into one of Dante’s spheres of heaven, or a worship café. As a student at Yale Divinity School, you may well have taken part in designing one of these services.
From traditional worship to brave experiment, from ancient liturgy to post-modern praise, from the heart of America to global worship, Marquand’s mission is to be worshipful, educational, and ecumenical, and we look forward to welcoming you here. 
Services take place in Marquand every weekday classes are in session. All services are open to the community.
For more information, contact marquand@yale.edu.

name: Marshall-Brennan Constitutional Literacy Project
mission: The Marshall-Brennan Constitutional Literacy Project is a national civics education program that sends law students into public high schools to teach courses in constitutional law and oral advocacy. These courses focus primarily on educating high schoolers about their constitutional rights.

name: Marxist Study Group
mission: The Marxist Study Group aims to create a body of students who engage in critically examining Marxism and capitalism. Recognizing that Marxism is usually not explored by high school students, we want to balance the political discourse and include alternative left ideology. Our goal is to make Marxist theory and ideas more accessible to the Yale student and New Haven population, and to highlight the diversity of Marxist thought and Marxist thinkers.

name: Math Help Desk
mission: Volunteers at MHD will assist with any math question, no matter how big or small. Our services range from tutoring entry-level courses, to try to help understand mathematics-related research papers.

name: MATHCOUNTS Outreach; a Yale Undergraduate Organization
mission:
(1) Build a lasting interest in mathematics amongst middle school students through weekly tutoring sessions.
(2) Support middle school students in their mathematical educations through review and enrichment of material
(3) Create a platform for the students to apply their skills through annual competitions.
(4) Serve the New Haven community by improving the general level of mathematics education.

name: Matriculate Chapter at Yale - An Undergraduate Organization
mission: Matriculate’s mission is to empower high-achieving, low-moderate income high school students to make the leap to colleges and universities of best fit with support and advising from undergraduates at Yale.
goals:
Our vision is that one day all students will have access to college regardless of their socio-economic status or background, which will give them a unique opportunity to change the trajectory of their own lives and the lives of their families.
We train talented college students at top institutions to virtually advise high achieving, low-income high school students from around the country.

name: Qui Transtulit Sustinet
mission:
QTS is a student organization that seeks to foster a safe space and
to create a sense of community for transfer students at YLS. QTS
leadership will gather the institutional knowledge that current
transfer students possess to facilitate the adaptation process of
future transfers. It will also make demands to the administration
and other student-run organizations regarding the needs of transfer
students.

name: McDougal Graduate Student Life
type: Graduate School of Arts & Sciences (GSAS) Administration
address:
(Center closed due to COVID-19 precautions in 2020-21)135 Prospect Street, upper level (accessible)McDougal Graduate Student CenterYale University
New Haven, CT 06511 United States
mission:
The McDougal Graduate Student Life (GSL) staff and fellows organize many fun programs and events to help you connect with other GSAS students, explore New Haven, and build a strong sense of community. Please feel free to reach out to us if we can help you!
 
To learn more about our events:
-check your email for our “GSL Notes”, which are sent to all GSAS students each week - also in your "My Inbox" in Yale Connect under "More" or on Group Page as "Newsletters" or in Yale Connect App as a Push notification
-view GSL events on Yale Connect App & Web
- check out GSL Facebook Page and some FB groups, like Grad Spouses & Partners and Grad students with Children.
benefits: Having a Life in Grad School - Taking a break from studies, wellness, meeting people and making friends, pursuing your interests and personal and professional development.

name: Toolkit & Resources for Graduate Student Organization Leaders  (GSAS-McDougal GSL Groups)
MDiv Cohort Group
mission: Space for MDiv current students. Receive news and updates from your year group reps, schedule events together as a program community and connect with other MDiv'ers!

name: Med Out the Vote
mission: Med Out the Vote (MOtV) is a voter registration/mobilization campaign initiative by AMSA. We are a non-partisan campaign that is dedicated to increasing the civic engagement of healthcare professionals.

name: Medical Mandarin Interest Group
mission: The Medical Mandarin Interest Group (MMIG) is dedicated to helping students develop their Mandarin skills in an effort to provide the best possible care to an increasingly diverse patient population.

name: Medical Student For Compassion and Choices
Medical Swahili
mission: To encourage the learning and practice of medical Kiswahili, both for the language’s intrinsic value and for the insight it can provide into the nuances of the clinician-patient interaction in Kiswahili-speaking countries

name: Medicine and Religion Interest Group
mission: The Medicine and Religion Interest Group fosters dialogue about the interplay between religion and medicine among students and faculty at Yale University and beyond. We collaborate across departments and schools in the research of religion and medicine and translate and disseminate the fruits of research in order to foster mutual understanding and improve patient care.

name: Meditation and Mindfulness at Yale - An Undergraduate Organization
mission: We aim to facilitate regular meditation and mindfulness practice among Yalies. This is done by organising weekly group sits and helping to ensure there are facilities available for come and go private sessions. We also strengthen each other's practices through regular discussions of relevant literature. We are open to people from all meditative backgrounds.

name: MedSci
mission: MedSci is an education-focused organization and strives to strengthen Yale students' relationship with the local community and benefit all involved with its programs. Through its education outreach program, elementary school students will be encouraged to explore higher-level science concepts and older mentors will have the opportunity to build their leadership and public speaking skills.

name: MENA SIG
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups

name: Middle Eastern and North African Law Students' Association
Migration Alliance at Yale - An Undergraduate Organization
mission: MAY is a coalition of undergraduate students passionately devoted to aiding refugees, immigrants, and all other migrants in Greater New Haven – through advocacy and direct service.

name: Military History Society
mission: To promote the discussion and study of military history and military strategy among members of Yale College and the wider Yale community by hosting events including wargames, strategy games, and presentations.
goals: To foster the enjoyment and discussion of military strategy and how it relates to historical military campaigns.

name: Minnesota Club
mission: The Minnesota Club seeks to promote the state of Minnesota and the Midwest through social activities. Our objectives are to educate others about Minnesota, promote the Minnesota community on Yale's campus, uphold the positive spirit of "Minnesota Nice," and preserve the Minnesota lexicon.

name: RALY (Reproductive Action League @ Yale) - an Undergraduate Organization
Miracle League Dance at Yale - an Undergraduate Organization
mission: This organization’s mission is two-fold. This organization is intended to provide members of the surrounding New Haven community with an otherwise non existent opportunity, due to a physical, intellectual, or developmental disability, to express themselves through dance. The environment provided is intended to be relaxing and fun. The dancers attending the rehearsals will have the option of dancing without the constraints of a specific style of dance. Additionally, this organization intends to provide members of the Yale community with an opportunity to be exposed to people who overcome their respective disabilities.

name: Mixed Company
mission: Mixed Company is an undergraduate organization formed primarily to promote public appreciation of group harmony singing and to educate students at Yale and other educational institutions and the general public about such music.

name: Moneythink: A Yale Undergraduate Organization
mission: Moneythink's mission is to restore the economic health of the United States through teaching high school students how to navigate their own personal finances and the financial system of the U.S.

name: MonstRAASity
category: Cultural, Performance: Dance, AACC Affiliate Org
mission: The goals of MonstRAASity are: To provide an opportunity for students to learn and observe the Gujarati folkdance Raas; to perform at cultural events and other venues across the University; to contribute to the cultural diversity of the University community by means of sharing Gujarati culture.

name: Morris Tyler Moot Court of Appeals
Movimiento Estudiantil Chicano de Aztlan (MEChA) de Yale
mission: MEChA de Yale is an organization of students in pursuit of social justice, community empowerment and cultural awareness.

name: Music Makers
mission: Music Makers aims to connect Yale student musicians with the New Haven community, by teaching music at children’s organizations and organizing performances by groups of Yale student musician volunteers at retirement communities, nursing homes, hospice, open-air locations, and other spaces in the community where music can be uplifting and helpful.

name: Muslim Law Students' Association
mission: The Muslim Law Students’ Association serves as a vehicle for gathering Muslims and others interested in learning about Islamic legal issues and issues of concern to Muslims and other minorities.

name: National Lawyers Guild
mission: The National Lawyers Guild (NLG) is dedicated to the need for basic change in the structure of our political and economic system.

name: National Organization for the Professional Advancement of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers (NOBCChE)-Yale
mission: The mission of NOBCChE includes building an eminent community of scientists and engineers by increasing the number of underrepresented minorities in the fields of chemistry, chemical engineering, and related disciplines. NOBCChE-Yale and its partners will use a combination of in-person and virtual meetings, workshops, demonstrations, awards, and other events to deliver programming that advances the shared objectives of NOBCChE-Yale and the national organization.

name: National Society of Black Engineers
mission: The National Society of Black Engineers, as a national student and professional based organization, does hereby dedicate itself to the development of intensive programs for increasing African-American and other ethnic minority participation in the field of engineering and engineering technology.  These programs will be initiated both within and outside the campus community and will serve to strengthen relations between professional industry and the African-American community.  Members of the organization are encouraged to join and participate in their individual professional societies.  This organization will endeavor to provide general counseling to all members.  The Yale University Chapter of the National Society of Black Engineers declares its intention to fulfill the mission of the national organization on Yale’s campus and in the New Haven community.

name: Native American Cultural Center
address:
26 High Street
New Haven, CT 06510 United States
mission: The NACC strives to maintain a permanent and prominent Indigenous presence at Yale that incorporates and supports the success of future Native leaders through recruitment, encouragement, mentoring, service, and the fostering of a community that makes Yale the most sought after Ivy Institution for Indigenous achievement, research and solidarity.

name: Native American Law Students' Association
mission: The mission of the Yale Native American Law Students Association (NALSA) is twofold. First, we are dedicated to providing personal, professional, and cultural support to Yale’s Native American law students and fostering a community among all law students who are interested in Indian legal issues. Second, we are committed to educating Yale’s student body about Indian law, tribal sovereignty, and indigenous rights. NALSA is inclusive and welcomes all members of the YLS community.

name: Natyamandala
mission: NATYA MANDALA is an Indian classical dance awareness group that promotes traditional Indian dance forms through performance, shows, workshop and other events.

name: Negative Space
category: Arts: Other, Arts: Visual Arts, Cultural, Publication, AACC Affiliate Org, Cultural: Mixed Race
mission: Our project aims to create a more nuanced portrait of Asian American identity by collecting and archiving the voices of students, faculty, and staff at Yale who identify as Asian or Asian American through oral history interviews, submissions of artwork and writing, and yearly exhibits of our collective voices. Our goal is to celebrate the heterogeneity of all those who consider themselves to be Asian or Asian American and, in so doing, to encourage a broader and more inclusive view of the kinds of narratives encompassed by that label.

name: New Haven Resource for Essay and Application College Help
mission: New Haven REACH is a student-run organization that seeks to provide the information and support necessary for New Haven youth to access the higher education best suited to their dreams, potential, and ambitions. REACH was founded by graduates of the Wilbur Cross Class of 2011, and we now have volunteers from all over America and all over the world. We all share the core belief that no one should be shut out from attending college just because they don't have the information and support they need to apply.

name: New Haven Urban Debate League
mission: Our mission is to empower New Haven's students with the public speaking and critical thinking skills necessary to lead the future.

name: OCS Student and Postdoc Group Advisory Committee
Office for Graduate Student Development and Diversity (OGSDD), GSAS
type: Graduate School of Arts & Sciences (GSAS) Administration
mission: The Office for Graduate Student Development and Diversity (OGSDD) is committed to building and maintaining a nurturing and caring community of scholars where students from diverse backgrounds and experiences are supported in their professional and intellectual goals and pursuits.
benefits: The Office for Graduate Student Development and Diversity (OGSDD) supports a nurturing and caring community of scholars that will welcome you, no matter who you are.

name: Office of Gender and Campus Culture
mission:
Preventing, recognizing, and responding to sexual misconduct is a community-wide project: every one of us has a part to play in making our campus culture as safe, respectful, and supportive as it can be. To build our individual and collective skills, all members of the Yale community have an annual sexual misconduct training requirement.
Juniors and seniors may choose to attend an in-person, CCE-facilitated workshop or complete an online training. Details on the in-person workshops are listed below, and you can register for most of them under the Events tab above. To complete the online training, go to https://smr-training.yale.edu/.
If you would prefer to have an individualized conversation, please email Dean Janay Garrett at janay.garrett@yale.edu to arrange one. You do not need to share any personal information.
Some students, such as FroCos, Peer Liaisons, pre-orientation leaders, and varsity athletes, may have already participated in training sessions that meet the annual sexual misconduct training requirement. To see a full list of trainings that fulfill this requirement, please consult the FAQs under the Documents tab above.
If you would like to arrange a customized workshop for a student group in which you participate, please email the Office of Gender and Campus Culture at gcc@yale.edu.
--
Seniors must fulfill this requirement in the fall semester by December 3rd. Seniors who would like to fulfill the requirement with an in-person workshop should register by November 5th.
Juniors may fulfill this requirement in either the fall or spring semester before April 22nd. Juniors who would like to fulfill the requirement with an in-person workshop should register by February 18th. More workshops will be held in Spring 2022 and will be made available in January.
--
FALL 2021 TITLE IX WORKSHOPS
Advanced Bystander Intervention
Saturday, October 30, 12-2pm
Friday, November 12, 12:30-2:30pm
The Advanced Bystander Intervention workshop builds on the introductory bystander intervention training to strengthen participants’ core intervention skills while offering new strategies for a wide range of situations.
Intimate Communication
Friday, November 5, 3:30-5:30pm
Monday, November 8, 4-6pm
In Intimate Communication, participants will learn pragmatic skills for productive conversations, with a focus on expressing romantic and sexual desires; navigating differences in values, identities, goals, and experiences; active listening; re-connecting in moments of anger or tension; and expressing appreciation, respect, and affection.
Making the Party Your Own: Hosting Skills 101
Saturday, November 13, 3-5pm
This workshop helps participants think through the process of hosting a party, from choosing a vibe and selecting a venue, to responsibly serving food and alcohol, to maintaining a welcoming tone and safe, inclusive space at the party itself.
 
Preventing and Responding to Sexual Misconduct
Online
This foundational training outlines Yale’s sexual misconduct definitions and policies, campus resources, and reporting mechanisms, with an emphasis on the ways that SHARE, Title IX, the UWC, and other campus resources can provide help, support, and options for action. Through interactive scenarios, participants learn core strategies for helping a friend, intervening as a bystander, and reducing overall campus risk.
You can access the online training here: https://smr-training.yale.edu/
Self-Care Toolkit: Building Resilience
Sunday, November 14, 7-9pm
This workshop explores the concepts of resilience and wellness and provides an opportunity to try out coping skills, including trauma-informed yoga practices, therapeutic art activities, relaxation exercises, and grounding techniques.
Supporting Survivors: Exploring Impacts and Promoting Holistic Wellness
Saturday, October 30, 3-5pm
Monday, November 1, 4-6pm
This workshop will expand upon the core elements of a helpful response (listening, not judging, offering support, facilitating referrals to resources) to consider how to promote holistic wellness in both survivors and ourselves.
TIPS Bartender Training
Thursday, November 11, 12-2pm
Wednesday, November 17, 3-5pm
Monday, November 29, 2-4pm
TIPS is a nationally recognized alcohol safety and bartender certification course. Participants will learn how to use the roles of bartenders to create safer, more inclusive spaces and reduce the risk of sexual misconduct. This workshop teaches practical skills, including identifying dangerous intoxication, slowing down and cutting off service, responding to sexual harassment, de-escalating conflict, and getting help in an emergency. Upon successful completion, students receive TIPS bartender certification, and are eligible to participate in an AODHRI-sponsored mixology class.
TIPS Trainings are run by Student Affairs Fellows, and can be found in the AODHRI YaleConnect portal, here: https://yaleconnect.yale.edu/feeds?type=club&type_id=34479&tab=events.

name: Office of International Students & Scholars
address:
421 Temple Street
New Haven, CT 06511 United States
mission:
"Over 6000 international students and scholars from more than 120 countries call Yale University their home away from home. You come from Albania and Zimbabwe and many places in between and you are making untold contributions to this university. The OISS is here to help and support you throughout your Yale experience and beyond, be it a question about your immigration status or your transition to this new culture and community. We look forward to getting to know you!" 
- Ann Kuhlman, Executive Director, Office of International Students and Scholars

name: Office of LGBTQ Resources at Yale University
address:
135 Prospect StFirst floor
New Haven, CT 06511 United States
mission: The Office of LGBTQ Resources provides services and support for students, faculty and staff across the University, in part by providing training and support for the programing, organizations and initiatives of students, faculty, staff, alumni and the local community.

name: Recess SIG
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups

name: SAYPH- MPH Executive Online Group
mission: SAYPH Subgroup for the Executive MPH Program

name: Sunday Sports Club
mission:
Sunday Sports Club is a student group at the Yale School of Music that provides opportunities for YSM'ers to play a variety of outdoor sports together. The group’s mission is to foster community and promote student wellness.
---
Sunday Sports Club is committed to ensuring accessibility for people with disabilities. We will do whatever is needed to ensure that everyone is able to take part in SSC activities.
benefits:
Members will have access to:
- Sports equipment
- Weekly organized sporting activities
- Opportunities to take part in day trips such as rock climbing, hiking, etc.

name: Office of the Secretary and Vice President for University Life
Office of the Secretary and Vice President for University Life
Opera Theatre of Yale College
mission: The Opera Theatre of Yale College (OTYC) is the undergraduate opera company at Yale University. Our organization is entirely student-run; every show offers our members the opportunity to learn firsthand the mechanics of performing and producing an opera. Our members are singers, instrumentalists, conductors, theatre technicians, costume and set designers, choreographers, and dancers. OTYC is an immersive extracurricular experience that prepares young artists and administrators for professional life after Yale. We are committed to bringing creative, thoughtful, and innovative opera productions to the Yale and New Haven communities.

name: Orthodox Christian Fellowship of Yale: An Undergraduate Organization
mission: By creating a branch of the Orthodox Christian Fellowship at Yale we hope to connect Orthodox college students and those interested in the Orthodox faith together by providing information, talks, and activities to strengthen the Orthodox community at Yale.

name: Orville H. Schell, Jr. Center for International Human Rights
Out in Public
type: School of Public Health Student Organizations
address:
47 College St
New Haven, CT 06510 United States
mission: Out in Public seeks to promote diversity and awareness at Yale School of Public Health by providing a platform for students to advocate for the needs and concerns of the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer (LGBTQ) community at YSPH and beyond, by creating a personal and professional network for the LGBTQIA+ community, and by organizing social and academic events aimed at fostering a sense of community at YSPH.

name: Out in the Woods SIG
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups

name: Outdoor Recreation Industry SIG
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups
mission:
The Outdoor Rec Industry SIG (ORec SIG) aims to provide a space for YSE students to discuss the future of the outdoor industry, diving into its impacts and opportunities for environmental, economic and social benefit. This may include historic narratives on who recreates outside and why, the role of private companies (Patagonia, REI, The North Face, etc.), public land management policy (National Park Service, U.S. Forest Service, Bureau of Land Management, etc.) as well as nonprofits that connect communities of all types to the outdoors. Topics for the SIG will cover sustainability in supply chains, innovations in materials, opportunities for justice, equity, diversity and inclusion in outdoor spaces, economic development in the rural United States, and others. Additionally, confronting racism both within Yale and in the outdoor recreation industry at large is central to the mission of ORec SIG. Additionally, ORec SIG notes that the ability of people across the country to enjoy time outside is enabled by land that was stolen from Indigenous peoples. 
ORec SIG seeks student contributors to the "New Directions in Outdoor Recreation" publication, which showcases student writing on various aspects of the Outdoor Recreation Industry. https://medium.com/new-directions-in-outdoor-recreation-at-yale-fes

name: OutLaws
mission: OutLaws is an organization of lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer (LGBTQ) members of the Law School community. Our goals are to provide a community for LGBTQ-identified people within YLS, to provide opportunities and connections for members of the YLS community who are interested in LGBTQ rights, and to advocate for legal issues of interest to the LGBTQ community.

name: OutPatient
mission: As YSM's LGBTQIA+ student group, OutPatient aims to build a community for the LGBTQIA+ identifying individuals and allies among medical students, and to spark conversation about health care issues facing the LGBTQIA+ patient populations. We aim to increase awareness, visibility, and education focusing on LGBTQIA+ populations, related resources for the New Haven communities, and other associated concerns.

name: PALS: Tutoring and Mentoring Group
mission: PALS' mission is to reach as many students from first to sixth grade as possible with quality weekly tutoring. We focus on core academic skills and building individual relationships with our students. We particularly seek students that lack the opportunity to receive tutoring elsewhere.

name: Partners in Health Engage: Undergraduate Yale Chapter
mission: We recruit, train, and equip dedicated teams of volunteer community organizers who mobilize their communities in the fight for health equity. With each campaign, petition, and event, we generate new resources, foster public discourse, and advocate for policies that advance the right to health worldwide.

name: Party of the Left
mission: We, the Party of the Left, are a community devoted to political discourse. As such, we seek both to develop our Members as people and leaders, and to develop a new vision of the American Left. Our means are spirited discussion and formal debate of the politics, policies, and philosophies that divide our community. We value intellectual integrity: the willingness to examine one’s innermost beliefs in a manner that is both honest and rigorous. Internally, we compete to present compelling visions of the Left. Externally, we test our ideas and abilities against our ideological opponents. We seek to bring discourse to the outside world, and the outside world to discourse. Together, we strive to advance the Party, the Yale Political Union, and the Left.
goals: We seek to provide quality, intellectual debate to our members and guests, and engage with the activists, thinkers, policymakers, etc. empowering the left's future. We strive to synthesize first principles and policy, debating each new topic with enthusiasm and developing our members as participants in a leftist project.

name: Pathways to Arts- for Graduate  & Professional Student Volunteeers
Pathways to Science - for Graduate & Professional Student Volunteers
mission: Pathways to Science is Yale’s coordinated STEM outreach infrastructure that provides an overarching infrastructure for the many and varied STEM programs and events for local pre-college students at Yale. Guided by a steering committee of Yale senior scientists and administrators, the Office of New Haven Affairs serves as a central hub for this initiative, both assisting Yale faculty, graduate students, and undergraduates in designing and implementing STEM programming as well as managing contacts and relationships with participating school districts, teachers, parents, and pre-college students. The more than 1,800 Pathways to Science Scholars are considered the youngest members of Yale’s scientific community and are invited throughout the year to special events, academic lectures, demonstrations, hands-on activities, summer programs, and research opportunities.
benefits:
Volunteer opportunities. 
Assistance with designing and implementing STEM (and nonSTEM!) outreach events for local students. 
Assistance with broader impacts components of NSF Grants. 
And more!
goals: With an overarching goal to encourage and support promising young scholars to pursue careers in science, technology, engineering, and math, Yale Pathways to Science opens the door for middle and high school students to explore STEM at Yale University.

name: Paul Tsai China Center
mission:
Founded by Professor Paul Gewirtz in 1999 as the China Law Center, the Paul Tsai China Center is the primary home for activities related to China at Yale Law School. The Center is a unique institution dedicated to helping advance China’s legal reforms, improving U.S.–China relations, and increasing understanding of China in the United States.
In interaction with research and teaching at Yale, the Paul Tsai China Center works collaboratively with a broad range of top experts in the Chinese government, universities, and civil society on concrete projects designed to have a positive practical impact. Our Center has an established track record in helping to further a broad range of legal reforms in China. Cooperative projects have focused particularly on issues of judicial reform, criminal justice reform, administrative and regulatory reform, and public interest law. Projects involve a range of activities, including workshops and seminars in the United States and China, research visits to Yale and to China, and books or articles by Chinese or U.S. scholars.
The Paul Tsai China Center also conducts research and convenes high-level Track II and Track 1.5 meetings on a broad range of U.S.–China foreign policy issues. The centerpiece of this work is the Dialogue on U.S.–China Relations, a thriving channel since 2012 for top U.S. and Chinese figures to develop and provide timely policy recommendations for both governments. The dialogue convenes carefully selected former officials and practitioners to work toward strategic and diplomatic innovation over the full range of issues in the U.S.–China relationship, with dual emphases on security and economic issues. The Center also hosts top Chinese and U.S. scholars and policy practitioners at Yale as guests and visiting scholars who produce original research and interact with the broader Yale community.
In 2016, Yale Law School received an extraordinary gift of $30 million in honor of its distinguished alumnus, the late Dr. Paul C. Tsai, ’54 LL.M , ’57 J.S.D., to support the continuing work of the China Center. This generous gift was given by Paul Tsai’s son, Joseph C. Tsai, Yale College, B.A. ’86; Yale Law School, J.D. ’90. In recognition of this gift, the Center was renamed the Paul Tsai China Center.
The Director of the Paul Tsai China Center is Professor Paul Gewirtz. Prior to establishing the Center in 1999, Professor Gewirtz was on leave from Yale University from 1997–1998 and was a part of President Bill Clinton’s administration, where he served as Special Representative for the Presidential Rule of Law Initiative at the U.S. Department of State. In that post, he developed and led the U.S.–China initiative to cooperate in the legal field that President Clinton and China’s President Jiang Zemin launched at their October 1997 Summit.

name: Red Hot Poker
mission: Red Hot Poker produces live sketch comedy onstage and video sketches to be published on our website and YouTube channel. We have roughly four live performances a semester.

name: Red Territory Drum Group
mission: Bringing cultural song and dance to our temporary home.

name: Plant-Based for Public Health
type: School of Public Health Student Organizations
category: Academic, Advocacy/Policy, Food/Culinary, Health/Wellness, Medical/Nursing/Public Health, Social, Special Interest
mission: Plant-Based for Public Health (PB4PH) at YSPH is dedicated to recognizing, amplifying, and celebrating the connection between nutrition, individual wellbeing, population health, animal welfare, and environmental health. PB4PH embraces the One Health perspective. We exist to empower individuals through education, community advocacy, and wholehearted inclusion to wield the power of accessible dietary and lifestyle choices for the promotion and progression of public health. We advocate for a healthier, more equitable, sustainable, and compassionate food system, and recognize that public health depends on the wellbeing of humans, animals, and the planet.
goals: The goal of PB4PH is to create a dialogue at YSPH about plant-based nutrition, and how this relates to public health and the One Health perspective. We aim to invite speakers who are experts in nutrition, climate change, infectious diseases, food security, farm workers rights, and farm animal veterinary science to speak about their expertise in public health. We will co-host events across schools with the Animal Law Society, the Yale Farm, the School of Environment, the Yale Center for Climate Change and Health, and others. PB4PH serves as a space for community-building: We will host film discussions and social events to learn from the diverse cultural, academic, personal, and professional backgrounds of our peers – to develop and grow our understanding of plant-based living. Our organization is open to all members of the Yale community.

name: Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery Interest Group
mission: To generate and support student interest in PRS

mission: The Yale Poorvu Center for Teaching and Learning promotes equitable and engaged teaching throughout the University, and supports students across the curriculum as they take ownership of their learning. As part of a world-class research institution, we provide training, consultations, and resources designed to make teaching and learning more public and collaborative, so that every Yale instructor experiences the satisfaction that results from teaching well, and every student develops the critical reflection that marks deep and independent learning.

name: Poorvu Center: Academic Strategies Program
type: Poorvu Center for Teaching and Learning
address:
301 York Street
New Haven, Conn 06511 United States
mission: Our mission is to help all Yale undergraduates become active, empowered learners in their academic lives at Yale. Through peer academic mentoring and interactive workshops, we hope to provide you with the tools to help propel you towards your goals.
benefits: The Academic Strategies Program offers one-on-one peer mentoring and a series of workshops. During a mentoring session, talk through your academic work and create a strategic plan to help you achieve your goals. Our interactive workshops offer practical advice and strategies for common academic challenges, such as, time management, tackling problem sets, and studying for exams.

name: Poorvu Center: Faculty Programs and Initiatives
type: Poorvu Center for Teaching and Learning
address:
301 York Street
New Haven, Conn 06511 United States
mission: The Yale Poorvu Center for Teaching and Learning promotes equitable and engaged teaching throughout the University. As part of a world-class research institution, we provide training, consultations, and resources designed to make teaching and learning more public and collaborative. We hope every Yale instructor experiences the satisfaction that results from teaching well.

name: Poorvu Center: Graduate and Postdoctoral Teaching Development
type: Poorvu Center for Teaching and Learning
address:
301 York Street
New Haven, Conn 06511 United States
mission: Graduate and Postdoc Teaching Development initiatives serve many populations -- graduate students, professional school students, and postdoctoral fellows.  We offer an extensive set of workshops for new teachers that encourage creativity and promote good teaching practices.  These workshops include the Fundamentals of Teaching (tailored to particular disciplines) and Advanced Teaching Workshops, on themes ranging from active learning to universal design, to inclusive assessment. We also offer support for graduate and postdoc teaching through classroom observations and one-on-one consultations, which allow new teachers to share challenges in a neutral space.  Graduate students and postdocs who want to do more intensive teaching development can pursue the Certificate in College Teaching Preparation (CCTP), the requirements for which include teaching, participating in workshops, observing others’ teaching, and preparing a capstone teaching portfolio.  At the heart of our program is a group of 22 McDougal Teaching Fellows who run many of our workshops and manager classroom observations.  Other opportunities for graduate student development include the Associates in Teaching program, which allows a graduate student to teach as instructor of record in partnership with a faculty member, and the Teaching Innovation Projects grant, which invites fresh ideas for using digital tools in the classroom.  The Graduate Teaching Program also serves the teaching needs of individual departments, promotes faculty-student mentoring, and responds to emerging developments in research about teaching.

name: Poorvu Center: Canvas Admins
