301 York Street
New Haven, Conn 06511 United States

name: Poorvu Center: Graduate Writing Lab
type: Poorvu Center for Teaching and Learning
address:
301 York Street
New Haven, Conn 06511 United States
mission: The Graduate Writing Lab creates and administers programs to help graduate and professional students become confident and proficient academic writers and presenters of their research. Through individual and classroom programming, we promote best practices in developing written and oral communication skills.

name: Preventative Medicine Interest Group
mission: The goal of the Preventative Medicine Interest Group is to make members more . familiar with foundational aspects of exercise physiology, biopsychosocial aspects of exercise in communities, and the implementation of exercise as a treatment in medical care. Through lectures and workshops, we hope to explore when, how, and why to recommend and help people begin and maintain lifestyle changes related to physical activity. So when someone comes to you wanting to reduce their blood pressure or improve their insulin sensitivity--and they want to do more than just take medications--you can confidently help them explore a variety of evidence-based options. We plan to discuss research on physical activity, aerobic exercise, and anaerobic exercise and how they affect many of the most common health maladies we’re likely to encounter as healthcare providers. We also plan to lead hands-on workshops in the Harkness gym so that you can learn how to implement the research. We don’t intend to train you to become personal trainers--doing so is beyond the purview of this endeavor--though we hope you’ll be familiar enough with these ideas and methods so that you can make confident suggestions to patients. Of course, we also value your feedback, so if there’s anything you’d like us to address, then please let us know and we can try to do so.

name: Pride Corp
mission: This organization was created and is motivated to allow equal access and resources to LGBTQ students pursuing a career in business. Given the historical basis of the financial sector being widely heterosexual and heteronormative, this organization aspires to disrupt the status quo by educating and preparing LGBTQ students for a career in business.

name: Prism LGBT+ in New Haven
mission: Prisme LGBT+ in New Haven is the New Haven chapter of Prisme LGBT+, a non-profit founded in France whose mission is to educate teens and younger children about queer identities at the local level. This means cooperating with organizations like Dwight Hall and Splash and Sprout at Yale to directly engage with students in and around New Haven, collaborating with local and statewide organizations at events like the New Haven Pride Block Party and the True Colors Conference, and working to build long-term coalitions with transformative organizations like the New Haven People's Center and local progressive networks.
goals: Through our educational efforts, we seek to not only introduce students to queer identities and debunk stereotypes that oppress the queer community, but also to provide students with the theoretical tools necessary to understand the oppressive social norms that are institutionalized in our society, including heteronormativity, cisnormativity, and sexism.

name: Program on Refugees, Forced Displacement, and Humanitarian Responses
type: MacMillan Center for International and Area Studies

name: Project Access at Yale - A Student Organization
mission: Project Access' aim is to create a world where passion and potential define a young person’s future by tackling inequalities in admissions to top universities.

name: Proof of the Pudding
mission: Proof of the Pudding was founded to extend the male-dominated tradition of a cappella at Yale to women and continues today for that same goal. Proof strives to make music at the highest level and provide group members with the opportunity to perform for audiences on campus and around the world. Above all, Proof aims to fulfill our mission of cultivating sisterhood and song that lives on for future generations.

name: Public Health Teaching Fellow Training
mission: To help YSPH teaching fellows to complete all of the required training in order to be effective teaching fellows.

name: Public School Graduates
mission:
The mission of this organization is to create a space for graduates
of public institutions of higher education to network, share
experiences, and combat the imposter syndrome that often attends
being a product of public education in an incredibly elite and, at
times elitist, institution.

name: Queer People of Color Coalition at Yale
mission:
The QPOCCoalition@Yale is an organization for graduate students, staff, and faculty that seeks to create safe spaces and opportunities for Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, and Queer (LGBTQ) people of color to build a vibrant community. We invite thoughtful dialogues and discussions on many social issues, especially those that pertain to the intersections of race, ethnicity, gender, and sexuality. We also provide mutual support for our members by exploring the ways that LGBTQ communities of color can successfully navigate predominantly white institutional spaces while building support networks and celebrating our various QPOC identities.
In light of recent hot-button political issues such as Black Lives Matter, the Orlando Nightclub Shooting, and the 2016 Presidential Election, members have expressed deep gratitude for a safe space that recognizes all of their marginalized identities as people of color, LGBTQ individuals, women, transgender people, gender non-conforming, and non-binary individuals (individuals who identify as neither male nor female). Given students’ increasing anxiety about issues of racism, sexism, homophobia, and xenophobia in America, a safe space that recognizes all of these intersecting identities is needed now more than ever.

name: QuestBridge- a student organization
mission: The Quest Scholars Network is a network of QuestBridge Scholars attending partner schools. The purpose of this network is to provide community and a support network for the Scholars. We work to provide a welcoming, supportive community for the Scholars on campus, as well as any other Yale students who identify as Low-income or First-generation.

name: Redhot & Blue
mission: Through the dedication of our members, past and present, we’ve come together to chase the bounds of musical possibility, while always looking back to the greats who inspired the conception of Redhot & Blue. We are dedicated to maintaining our history of strong musicality, both vocally and with our arrangements, all of which are created by current or former members, as well as sharing that musicality with audiences of all ages and backgrounds.

name: ReDirected Studies
mission: Yale ReDirected Studies commits itself to reflecting on the limitations of the ‘Western’ intellectual tradition and articulating alternatives to said tradition. With this in consideration, we strive to focus on ‘non-Western’ intellectual and cultural works typically excluded from these ‘canons,’ while consistently re-evaluating how framing as such edifies concepts like the ‘West.’ ReDirected hopes to accomplish our goals by inviting Yale’s wider community to explore traditions that developed independently from the stereotypical ‘West,’ whether wholly or in part.
goals:
Our participation in elite academia, via Yale University, upholds colonial perspectives and outcomes. We hope to make space for dynamic, and even fragmentary, knowledge systems by engaging in a robust and sustained critique of ‘Western’ ones. 
We recognize the need for consistent reflection on the limitation of our methodologies and perspectives, as well as self-criticism of our own complicity within ‘Western’ Eurocentricity. 
We plan to integrate the anti- and decolonial discourse into our criticism of the canon in order to decenter the European ‘West.’
We seek to expand the scope of our education, while searching for a balance in the tension between inevitable cultural differences and potential inter-regional similarities. 
Knowledge belongs to no one and should appeal to everyone; our project strives to make knowledge and discussions about knowledge readily accessible to all, regardless of financial, social, or cultural barriers.
We aim to maintain a relational dynamic in our work and reject transactional approaches. All of our members have an equal say in constructing our learning space.

name: ReformAmerica
mission: ReformAmerica is a student-led organization that seeks to make policy changes on a national stage, as well as within New Haven. Our initiatives will encompass a wide variety of pressing issues, primarily criminal justice and education reform, by pursuing research in the community to push for public policy reforms.

name: Reformed Students Group
mission: The Reformed Student Group hosts weekly student-led worship services intended to make room for non-academic spiritual reflection and building meaningful community. Created by students in the Reformed Studies Program, the services are often led by students belonging to Reformed and Reformed-adjacent traditions and borrow from Presbyterian (PCUSA) liturgies. However, the services are broadly ecumenical and open to all. The Reformed Student Group provides a space to explore what it means to be Reformed in the 21st century. In addition to our weekly worship, the group meets for more traditional PCUSA communion services on the first Sunday evening of each month. These services include a student-led homily and are presided over by an ordained minister in the Reformed tradition.

name: Refugee and Immigrant Student Education
mission: RISE is a tutoring and mentoring organization that works with immigrants and refugees in New Haven to overcome language and cultural barriers they may face. Our team of tutors works through weekly in-school and in-home sessions in a variety of public schools and family homes. Our tutors work with a curriculum designed by our team, and we provide resources necessary for our ESL based programming. In addition to these weekly sessions, we organize monthly community events to allow for cultural exchanges to benefit the greater New Haven community, the immigrant and refugee populations, and the Yale community.

name: Reproductive Justice Action League at Yale - An Undergraduate Organization
mission: The Reproductive Justice Action League at Yale College is committed to the advancement of reproductive freedom as a fundamental human right, as well as the promotion of students’ control over their sexual and reproductive lives. In its protection of reproductive rights, RALY works actively within the university community and the city of New Haven to encourage discussion, educate individuals of their reproductive options, and raise awareness of national policy and legislation.

name: REPROJustice
type: School of Public Health Student Organizations
address:
47 College St
New Haven, CT 06510 United States
mission: REPROJustice at the Yale School of Public Health is dedicated to advocating for sexual and reproductive liberties, gender equity, and social justice within public health. Through community engagement, education, and advocacy we are working to sustain the reproductive and sexual freedoms entitled to people of varying genders and sexualities and actively pushing to create a healthier, safer, and more just world for all.

name: Restaurant Rescue Project
mission:
The Restaurant Rescue Project seeks to reallocate food waste and combat local hunger through student-driven initiatives, with a focus on community integration and sustainable engagement.
Through a network of donors and receivers, the student-run system works to combat food waste on a community level. The project partners with local restaurants, grocery stores, and supermarkets, which donate usable food that would otherwise be wasted. Student volunteers operate regular shifts and transport food from these donors to receiving facilities, including soup kitchens, halfway houses, and shelters.

name: SAYPH - MS BIS/HI Group
mission: SAYPH Subgroup for MS students in BIS/HI

name: SAYPH - MS EID and CDE Group
mission: SAYPH Subgroup for MS EID and CDE Students

name: Returned Peace Corps Volunteers at Yale - a Graduate Student Association
mission: RPCVs at Yale is a social, service, and networking organization for RPCVs at Yale University. Its goals are: To “bring the world back home” (the Peace Corps Third Goal: “To promote a better understanding of other people on the part of the American people.”); To serve as a social network for RPCVs and friends; To assist the Peace Corps in its mission, including assisting prospective and new Peace Corps Volunteers.

name: Roman Catholic Fellowship at Yale Divinity School
mission: RCF exists to bring the Catholic students of YDS together as a community to learn together, grow in our Catholic faith and get involved in local community events and service opportunities.
benefits:
- Find intentional community and embrace the diversity of being Catholic at YDS
- A connection point for fellow Catholic students and faculty
- Attend and host social, faith-oriented and social events both in-person and online
- Share information about local opportunities for worship and community service and social justice
- Discuss with and support others undertaking the brand new Roman Catholic Lay Ministry Colloquium
goals: In a normal year, we might come together to share meals or attend lectures on a variety of interesting faith-related topics. Our goal this year is simply to move forward as one community and continue to share divinity school life together.

name: Roots SIG

name: RRAD Disaster SIG
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups

name: RTA Publications, Inc.
mission: Rumpus seeks to report on all things Yale in a way that people actually want to read. We fail. Frequently. But when we don't it's kind of great.

name: Rural Students Alliance at Yale
mission: Recognizing that students from small towns and rural communities have particular experiences that are unique from their urban peers and impact the way they experience Yale, the Rural Students Alliance of Yale is a group for rural students at Yale to get to know and support one another with the goal of improving the experience of rural students at Yale. We also aim to increase the visibility of rurality on Yale's campus, not only highlighting rural members of its student body but also increasing the presence of rurality in academic inquiry through guest speakers, panels, film screenings, and more.
goals:
Since RSAY is still a relatively new organization that is still forming and establishing its foundation, our goals for the coming 2020-2021 Academic Year is to create a community of rural students and promote events and advocacy initiatives to maintain cohesiveness between us. Some of our goals for the year are below, but we aim to derive our goals and initiatives from RSAY members and what they believe to be most beneficial to them being rural at Yale.
1. Hold online events to build community and express our shared experiences while also abiding by the CDC guidelines of social distancing given the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Examples include:
- Zoom Dinners to discuss being rural and chat about life
- Play online games such as skribbl.io and GeoGuessr
- Utilize the Groupme and Email functions to maintain communication.
2.  Create guidelines to help rural students navigate life at Yale and all its resources. Examples include:
- Working Through Imposter Syndrome
- Rural First-Years Handbook
- Navigating New Haven and Life in a City
3. Pool together rural experiences and struggles to advocate for administrative changes to better accommodate and include rural voices. Some issues brought up by the general body include:
- Farm’s net worth and its impact on financial aid
- Lack of classes discussing rural experiences nationally and globally
To reiterate, the goals of RSAY are subject to change as we want to derive our goals and initiatives from all of our members to best accommodate rural students from a wide range of backgrounds.

name: Russian Cultural Club
mission: The Russian Cultural Club is Yale’s official undergraduate cultural organization for Russian-speaking international students, immigrant and heritage Russian-speakers, and students of Russian and Eastern European cultures alike. In addition to organizing weekly dinners in the residential colleges, the club coordinates with the Slavic Department, the Russian Studies Project, and other undergraduate and graduate student organizations to organize cultural celebrations, screen films, invite guest speakers, and create a space on campus for the discussion and celebration of cultural traditions shared by Russian-speakers.

name: Sabrosura: Yale's Undergraduate Premier Latin Dance Team
mission: Sabrosura's mission is to promote and practice cultural expression and celebration through the medium of Latin dance. We hope to provide a space for students interested in Latin Dance, regardless of their cultural backgrounds, to teach and share their love of Latin Dance with Yale and New Haven communities.
goals:
1. We hope to provide an inclusive community for students interested in practicing and learning Latin Dance styles and techniques, regardless of their cultural backgrounds.
2. Perform at least once a semester, typically in the form of a showcase, in order to teach and share their love of Latin Dance with Yale and New Haven communities.
3. Create an inclusive social space for our members and the Yale community to form meaningful relationships by connecting through Latin Dance.

name: Sad, Overworked, and Beleaguered Study Group and Yodellers
mission: To provide a space for the discussion of politics, philosophy, and contemporary media.

name: SAGE Magazine
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups

name: Saint Thomas More Graduate Council
mission: Serve the Catholic Graduate Student and Post-Doc Community through Prayer, Study and Action.

name: Saint Thomas More Undergraduate Council
mission: The mission of the Saint Thomas More Undergraduate Council is to represent the undergraduates at Saint Thomas More Catholic Chapel & Center at Yale. The Saint Thomas More Undergraduate Council collaborates with the Assistant Chaplains to plan social events and programming for specifically for undergraduates throughout the academic year. Programming includes study breaks, social justice opportunities, intellectual and spiritual development.

mission: SAYPH Subgroup for the Advanced Professional MPH Students

name: Student Association of Yale School of Public Health
type: School of Public Health Student Organizations
address:
47 College Street
New Haven, CT 06510 United States
mission:
SAYPH is organized by YSPH students for YSPH students. SAYPH works to enhance the experience of each student at YSPH by sponsoring educational and social activities, providing a forum for students’ ideas and concerns, and acting as a liaison between students and the administration. Through SAYPH, students get involved in many areas including the following:
    Student clubs and organizations
    Professional development and alumni relations
    Community service and social events at YSPH and in the greater community
    Health and wellness promotion
    Recruitment of new students to YSPH
    New student orientation and commencement activities
SAYPH is led by an Executive Board consisting of a president, professional development chair, treasurer, alumni engagement chair, social chair, community service chair, and communications chair. There are also MPH departmental student representatives, PhD representatives, and MS representatives. Each department elects students to act as a liaison between students, faculty, and administration. All SAYPH positions are filled through a school-wide nomination process that takes place annually.

name: Students for Sustainable Waste-Reduction at YSPH
type: School of Public Health Student Organizations
address:
47 College St
NEW HAVEN, CT 06510 United States
mission: SWAY works to shift the current consumption practices at YSPH through a BYO (bring your own) campaign to: 1) minimize the use of disposable items at catered events; 2) stop current unsustainable food/catering disposable item practices; and 3) support a model for Yale's transition to sustainable consumption and minimalist disposal patterns.

name: Womxn of Color for Maternal & Child Health
type: School of Public Health Student Organizations
address:
47 College St
New Haven, CT 06510 United States
mission:
Womxn of Color for Maternal & Child Health is a group led by womxn of color passionate about health justice for pregnant people, infants, children, and young people of color. Our mission is to:
•	Facilitate interdisciplinary dialogue about health equity from a racial justice perspective, 
•	Elevate health narratives and health knowledge of people of color,
•	Advocate for health policies and solutions alongside communities of color driven by their needs,    
•	Promote the integration of evidence-informed practices* and holistic healing practices,  
•	Provide training on combating racism as a root cause of health inequities, and 
•	Promote equitable engagement between the Yale community, New Haven community and beyond.
*Evidence gathered from both academic and non-academic sources, including peer reviewed articles and laypersons’ experiences

name: Yale Biostatistics Student Association
type: School of Public Health Student Organizations
address:
47 College St
New Haven, CT 06510 United States
mission: YBSA aims to connect everyone who is passionate about biostatistics and help each member further explore their academic and career opportunities in biostatistics.

name: Yale School of Public Health Student Consulting Group
type: School of Public Health Student Organizations
category: Academic, Leadership, Medical/Nursing/Public Health, Professional, Service/Volunteering
address:
47 College St
New Haven, CT 06510 United States
mission: To provide pro-bono consulting and public health practice to organizations in the Greater New Haven area and beyond, while also creating opportunities for graduate students to advance their education, knowledge, and experience.

name: Schwarzman Center
address:
168 Grove Street
New Haven, CT 06510 United States

name: Scrubs Addressing the Firearm Epidemic
mission: Scrubs Addressing the Firearm Epidemic (SAFE) is a national organization of students, physicians, nurses, and healthcare professionals dedicated to eliminating the American firearm violence epidemic through research, education, and evidence-based policy.

name: Shades A Cappella, Inc.
mission: Shades is an all gender a cappella group founded to celebrate music of the African Diaspora.  It is our objective to offer a unique, musically excellent, and spiritually enriching performance experience to audiences at Yale University and beyond. Drawing from the diverse backgrounds of our members and the oral traditions of Black people across the globe, we strive to portray authentically the complexity of the Black experience.  In addition to mastering the style of our music, we develop an appreciation of its history and roots in order to educate audiences about our music’s lineage.  We acknowledge and accept that we are endowed with both the responsibility and the privilege of giving a voice to the voiceless, and we aim to do so through the richness of our repertoire with its power to inspire and unite us and our audiences.
goals: To foster excellence, learning, and global understanding in all people through the power of music, in particular the music of the African Diaspora. Setting an example to young minority students as a group of successful, primarily Black students.

name: Shaka: Yale's Undergraduate Polynesian Dance Group
mission:
Shaka is a Polynesian dance group that celebrates and shares traditional and modern styles of Hula and Tahitian dance with the Yale community. The popular Hawaiian gesture "shaka," meaning "hang loose," is used to convey the friendship, love, and compassion of the "Aloha Spirit" among friends and strangers alike.
Shaka aims to celebrate the Polynesian culture and Aloha Spirit with the Yale community by performing authentic dance from the islands of Hawaii and Tahiti.

name: ShARE Consulting Student Chapter at Yale
mission: ShARE is an international student-run consulting organization and think-tank, providing a two-year program of skills training and opportunities to gain professional experience. Operating under the motto of "Do Well, Do Good", ShARE aims to create a new generation of leaders and problem solvers who are well-equipped to succeed in their careers, and whose professional aspirations are aligned with the ideals of a more equitable world.

name: SheCode
mission: As our society becomes more and more technologically advanced, computer science becomes increasingly important and relevant.  However, programming is inaccessible to many minority groups, especially women.  We believe that teaching programming skills to girls will inspire and foster an interest in computer science.  Moreover, our classes expose students to a technical field and allow them to create concrete products and instill value of perseverance, creativity, ownership, and achievement.  SheCode wants to lower the initial intimidation barrier of computer science and create a supportive environment where students of all background can learn, collaborate, and create something incredible.

name: Sikhs at Yale - a Student Association
mission: Sikhs at Yale (SAY) aims to raise the cultural and spiritual awareness of the Sikh faith among Sikh and non-Sikhs alike on Yale’s Campus. In addition, we seek to create and foster a cohesive community through community service and social events as well as to build bridges with other groups.

name: Simplex Sciences
mission: The mission of Simplex Sciences Inc. is to educate students on running and innovating a biotech startup. We focus on areas of research and development, marketing, business operations, finances, sales, customer outreach, etc.

name: Singing Group Council
mission: The Singing Group Council serves as the administrator for the majority of Yale's a cappella community. Our primarily duties are to facilitate the audition process at the start of the year, organize groups' concert dates throughout the second semester, and serve as a liaison between Yale's a cappella community and performance venues in New Haven.
goals: For the 2020-2021 Academic Year, the SGC will focus on connecting a cappella groups and first-years through a variety of virtual events.  SGC member groups will NOT be allowed to conduct auditions this year, following group deliberations.

name: The Spizzwinks of Yale University, Inc.
mission:
Founded in 1914, the Spizzwinks(?) of Yale University are America's oldest underclassmen a cappella group.
Taking each 'wink to perform on all six inhabited continents and their hometown, Spizzwinks are committed to singing, brothership, service, and music education.

name: Sir Thomas More Lecture Series
mission: The Sir Thomas More Lecture Series is a set of weekly talks delivered over lunch on topics pertaining to politics, philosophy, history, religion, art, the humanities. Guests have ranged from Yale professors to an Austrian Archduke, and attendance is open to any and all Yale students.

name: Smart Woman Securities
mission: Smart Woman Securities (SWS) Yale and aims to empower undergraduate women of all academic backgrounds and all career interests with investment knowledge. Founded in 2010, it is the first finance organization for women at Yale. Through instructive seminars, mentoring initiatives, and meetings with successful investors such as Warren Buffett, SWS provides resources upon which women can build greater knowledge of financial markets. By giving young women direct investment experience while still in college, SWS aims to empower a new generation of women investors for the future.

name: Society for Advancement of Chicanos/Hispanics and Native Americans in Science (SACNAS) - Yale Chapter
mission: SACNAS chapter at Yale will focus on the connection of minority scientists on campus from the undergraduate to faculty level. As a group, we will focus on mentorhsip, science outreach, and resources for scientific development.

name: Society for Ecological Restoration (SER) SIG
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups

name: Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers - SHPE Yale Student Chapter
mission:
The purpose of this student chapter is to:
1) Encourage and promote engineering and related STEM fields to the Hispanic population at Yale University.
2) Increase Hispanic retention in engineering and related STEM fields at Yale University
3) Provide post-graduation advice, resources and opportunities that benefit Hispanic engineering students at Yale University.
4) Create community outreach programs to inspire and encourage children in the New Haven community, especially communities with large Hispanic and minority populations, to pursue careers in engineering and STEM.
5) Provide mentorship and a structured community for Hispanic engineering students at Yale University.

name: Solomon Center for Health Law & Policy
mission:
The Solomon Center for Health Law and Policy at Yale Law School is the first of its kind to focus on the intersection of law and the governance, practice, and business of health care. The Center brings together leading experts and practitioners from the public and private sectors to address cutting-edge questions of health law and policy, and to train the next generation of top health lawyers, industry leaders, policymakers, and academics.
The Center was established to meet a critical need for a new academic and legal-professional discipline that responds to the rapidly evolving environment of health care and its centrality in the nation’s economy and government. “Health law” as a field of study in law schools is a relatively new concept; it has yet to be embraced within the field of “public law,” alongside similar disciplines like labor law and environmental law. Among the few health law centers at U.S. law schools, the Solomon Center is unique in its focus on the government’s role in health care as well as health care business and physicians and scientists themselves. The Solomon Center distinguishes itself by doing what Yale does best: focusing on law as a tool to affect governance, industry, and the academy at the highest levels.
The Center’s programming includes many course offerings, both academic and experiential; career planning; academic research, policy work and litigation briefs; and numerous high profile panels and conferences that bring academic, government, and business leaders in health care to the Law School. We host a steady stream of academic visitors from all disciplines to enrich our programming and course offers, and we actively support student research, field work, and publications. Our work is highly interdisciplinary. Building on established relationships with the Yale School of Medicine, Yale Cancer Center, Yale-New Haven Hospital, Yale School of Management, and Yale Interdisciplinary Center for Bioethics, the Center brings together all that Yale has to offer to make a difference both at Yale and beyond.

name: Somali Affairs at Yale
mission: To promote Somali affairs at Yale University through education, research, and programs.
goals:
Represent Somalia on campus and beyond.
Share information and resources on Somalia with the public.
Engage in education and research on Somali affairs.

name: Something Extra
mission: Something Extra's goal is to create a space for women's empowerment and a way to promote the women's voices on stage.

name: South Asian Graduate and Professional Association
mission:
SAGA shall be dedicated to creating and providing social, professional, and 
intellectual forum for graduate and professional students interested in a range of 
issues related to South Asia and South Asians.
SAGA shall also work to increase awareness of and to promote issues affecting 
South Asia and South Asians at Yale University.

name: South Asian Law Students' Association
mission: The South Asian Law Students Association (SALSA) provides those interested in South Asian culture at Yale Law School a space to gather, create support networks, and form communities. We hope to instill awareness of the role of law students as future leaders who understand, care about, and support the history and concerns of the South Asian community.

name: South Asian Studies
type: MacMillan Center for International and Area Studies

name: South Asian Youth Initiative
mission: The South Asian Youth Initiative produces a national conference for South Asian young adults each year. The conference will interrogate social issues, while providing a forum for intergenerational learning and intercollegiate idea exchange.

name: South Slavic Society
mission: The South Slavic Society at Yale is committed to the promotion of culture and history of Balkans within the university community. The organization’s main objective will be the contribution to better understanding of the geo-political situation and the cultural conglomerate of the South-Eastern Europe through history to present. Another important purpose of our organization is to provide a sense of community to the Yale students with South Slavic origins or interest in South Slavic culture. Through a series of social gatherings, speaker discussions and networking events, we will seek to cultivate the culture, historical legacy, language and traditions of our countries.

name: Special Needs Undergraduate Swim Lessons
mission: The goal of this organization is to facilitate rewarding relationships between undergraduates and local special needs children, while ultimately creating a long lasting motivation within Yalies to give back to their community.
goals:
- Provide free swim lessons to children with special needs in the New Haven community
- Foster rewarding relationships between undergraduates and local spacial needs children
- Create a long lasting motivation within Yalies  to give back to their community

name: Sphincter Sketch Comedy
mission: To provide feminist and activist comedy to the Yale community.

name: Splash At Yale - an Undergraduate Organization
address:
12 Hillhouse Ave
New Haven, CT 06520 United States
mission: Splash's mission is to increase students' excitement for learning by introducing them to topics beyond the scope of traditional school. By harnessing the passion and enthusiasm of Yale students, we hope to inspire middle- and high-schoolers to seek out further learning and see education as a fun, inviting process. We want to empower students by giving them full choice regarding their Splash day.

name: Sri Lankans at Yale - an Undergraduate Organization
mission: The mission of our organization is to bring together fellow Sri Lankans at Yale University in order to strengthen our bonds through celebrating our culture and sharing it with our peers.

name: Stand with “Comfort Women”
mission: We are a student organization at Yale united with a passion for women’s rights and justice. In particular, our efforts are focused on shedding light on the “Comfort Women” issue and standing in solidarity with victims of wartime sexual violence all over the world.

name: STEM & Health Equity Advocates
mission: In recognizing the adverse, harmful, and even fatal effects of racism in STEM and healthcare, our mission is to implement anti-racist education for STEM and pre-health students, expand the History of Science, Medicine, and Public Health department, and actively support and collaborate with other student-led efforts to dismantle systemic racism at Yale University.

name: STEM Mentors at Yale - a graduate student organization
mission: Our mission is to encourage local high school students, especially underrepresented groups like women and minorities, to pursue careers related to STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics). To achieve this goal, we provide mentors for students and host a variety of public events throughout the school year. Our mentors help students to explore a variety of career options and to navigate the transition between high school and college.

name: Steppin' Out
mission: Step is an African American dance form developed first by South African miners as an alternative to drumming, a previously banned activity. There is a vibrant step dance tradition in the South, but in the Northeast many people have never even heard of it. Steppin' Out aims to share this great history and culture with the Yale community, both by making the otherwise unknown style visible in the first place and by celebrating the diversity of our membership.

name: Student Accessibility Services
mission:
The primary mission of Student Accessibility Services (SAS) is to facilitate individual accommodations for all students with disabilities throughout the entire University, and by so doing, work to remove physical and attitudinal barriers, which may prevent their full participation in the University community. Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 and the Americans with Disabilities Act guide much of our work. 
Often, the physical barrier is the easiest to remove - the attitudinal barriers are much more difficult. To create a university community, which is truly accessible and inclusive of all persons, including people with disabilities requires the participation of each member of the community. If you have any questions about accessibility or our office, please contact us.

name: Student Affairs Committee (SAC)
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups

name: Student Association of Thais at Yale
mission: The mission of SATAY is to serve as a community for Thai and interested Yale students and to share Thai culture to the broader Yale Community.

name: Student Flying Club at Yale
mission: The mission of the SFCY is to  build an active community of aviation enthusiasts by immersing members in the world of aviation.

name: Student Health Education at Yale Health
address:
55 Lock St, 1st fl (wellness space)
New Haven, CT 06511 United States
mission:
Are you looking for support to make changes towards a healthier lifestyle and better quality of life?
Student Health Education can help with:
-Strengthening your time management skills
-Improving sleep
-Developing stress reduction strategies
-Quitting tobacco
-Changing up your exercise routine
Consider working with Yale Health’s student health educator and health coach, Lauren Horner, M.Ed, CHES. Lauren will partner with you to help you overcome obstacles and enhance your holistic well-being by utilizing your strengths and goal-directed behavior change, while providing motivation, accountability, support, and resources.   
Email Lauren at lauren.horner@yale.edu to schedule an appointment on Zoom. She’s available to work with all students, Monday through Friday.

name: Student Interest Group in Neurology - SIGN
Student National Medical Association/Latino Medical Student Association
Student Partnerships for Global Health
mission: Our aim is to learn about a community and ask: How can we use our skills and resources to address a public health problem in partnership with existing in-country organizations? With collaborative, interdisciplinary student teams, we use any skills we can offer (survey collection, data analysis, education) to assist in addressing a specific public health problem in each community that we’re working with.

name: Student Technology Collaborative (STC) of Yale IT
Students and Alumni of Yale - An Undergraduate Organization
category: Leadership, Pre-Professional, Professional, Service/Volunteering, Social, Student Government
address:
Rose Alumni House232 York Street
New Haven, CT 06511 United States
mission: STAY's mission reaches far beyond New Haven to shared interest groups (SIGs), Yale College classes, Graduate & Professional alumni associations, and regional Yale clubs around the world. Alumni provide the wisdom of educational, job, and life experience. Graduate and professional students offer career guidance to college students and energy to alumni. Undergraduates offer fresh perspectives and enthusiasm. STAY stands at the intersection of these talents and points the way for three Yale communities to form long-lasting, mutually beneficial relationships.
goals: Connect Students with Alumni!

name: Students Demand Action at Yale
mission: Students Demand Action is working with gun violence prevention leaders to bring the power of advocacy, research, and grassroots organizing to communities across the country

name: Students for Carbon Dividends
mission: The mission of S4CD is to catapult a free-market climate solution—specifically the Carbon Dividends Plan—into the national spotlight and open the door to bipartisan climate action.

name: Students for Sensible Drug Policy at Yale
mission: Students for Sensible Drug Policy is an international grassroots organization working to end the global War on Drugs. We provide harm reduction drug education on campus and organize at the university, city, and state levels to fight drug war-era hysteria and move toward policies grounded in evidence, science, compassion, health and human rights.

name: Students of Yiddish at Yale
mission: To provide opportunities for student engagement in Yiddish culture, history and literature with a focus on Yiddish-centered cultural events and meaningful engagement with the Yiddish language.

name: Study Abroad
address:
55 Whitney Ave., 3rd Fl.
New Haven, CT 06510 United States
mission:
Yale Study Abroad is here to guide you through the process of identifying the international experience that fits your goals and interests. Choose from hundreds of study abroad options, including Yale Summer Session Programs Abroad, Non-Yale Summer Abroad, and Year or Term Abroad.
→ studyabroad.yale.edu

name: Stuttering At Yale
mission: Our mission is to create a space on campus to share and celebrate our experiences as people who stutter, build community among stutterers at Yale and raise awareness about speech disfluencies.
goals:
Host monthly meeting where members discuss stuttering-related topics
Invite speaker once a year to hear stuttering-related research and perspectives
Host mixer at least once a year

name: Sube: Yale Latinx Business and Leadership Student Association
mission: Sube is aimed at uniting the Yale Hispanic/Latinx undergraduate community and empowering those in the community to cultivate their professional interests and leadership skills.

name: Supporting Student-Athletes at Yale - an Undergraduate Organization
mission: SSAY aims to support and provide a community for LGBTQIA+ student-athletes at Yale.

name: Sustainability and Finance SIG
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups

name: Sustainable Development in Latin America and the Caribbean Conference (SDLAC) SIG
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups

name: Swiss Students & Affiliates at Yale - Graduate-Professional student division
mission: The Swiss Students and Affiliates at Yale shall promote a sense of cultural belonging and familial friendship among its members at Yale University and other universities in America. Furthermore, the Swiss Students and Affiliates at Yale wants to actively reach out to students who are from Switzerland, or who are interested in Switzerland at American universities to promote cultural exchange across the Atlantic.

name: Symposia--A Yale Undergraduate Research Journal
mission: Symposia aims to profile the diversity of labs and research centers on campus and celebrate original undergraduate scholarship across all disciplines. We intend to expose readers to students and faculty who share a passion for research and cultivate an environment of collaboration and investigation at Yale.
goals: Symposia is a student-run journal dedicated to publishing original undergraduate research. We feature lab profiles and empirical papers often in the form of senior theses, lab write-ups, or independently conducted research projects. Our goals are to recognize outstanding achievements of undergraduates at Yale in any and all research fields, from STEM to humanities and highlight the personal stories of these students.

name: Synth Labyrinth Collective
mission: Synth Labyrinth Collective explores synthesizers, from vintage 1960s instruments used in countless pop song to modular synths buried in basements booming with the most daring noise music. We find the sound of synthesis as beautiful and organic as the sound of thunder produced by lightning. We’re composers, singers, instrumentalists, beatmakers, artists, scientists, astrologers, and sorcerers.

name: Taiwanese American Society
mission: The Taiwanese American Society at Yale (TAS) is dedicated to promoting awareness of Taiwan and Taiwanese American culture while fostering the Asian American community at Yale. Through cultural, political, and social events, we aspire to build a sense of cultural awareness and a spirit of kinship among students. TAS is non-exclusive and embraces with open arms all who are interested in joining the organization. Above all, TAS is a warm and diverse family of friends.

name: Take Action Tuesday
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups

name: The Yale Political Union (Undergraduate)
mission: The Yale Political Union provides students with a non-partisan forum for parliamentary debate, as well as encourages the discussion of matters of public interest by other suitable means.

name: TAMID Group at Yale
mission: TAMID Group is a nonprofit organization that develops the professional skills of undergraduate students through hands-on interaction with the Israeli economy.  TAMID integrates the next generation of entrepreneurs and business professionals with Israel through a comprehensive education curriculum, pro-bono consulting for Israeli startups, capital market investment research, and a summer internship program in Israel. TAMID has no political or religious affiliations.

name: Tangled Up In Blue
mission:
Tangled Up in Blue (TUIB) provides a musical space for students passionate about creating and sharing folk music. Through on-campus performances and tours, TUIB (pronounced twihb) shares that love of folk music with our larger communities, from Yale itself to the towns that members are from. 
Our group has repertoire that ranges from the bluegrass tunes of the Appalachians to traditional Irish ballads, the folk-rock hits of Bob Dylan to the jams of Crosby, Stills, Nash, & Young, and Simon & Garfunkel.  We sing four-part folk harmonies and accompany ourselves on guitar, banjo, fiddle, viola, mandolin, and harmonica.

name: Taps at Yale - A Student Organization
mission: Taps at Yale allows dancers to continue to explore their love of Tap Dance and to share that love with the wider Yale and New Haven communities.

name: Tau Beta Pi Engineering Honor Society
mission: Tau Beta Pi stands for integrity and excellence in engineering. The mission of TBP is to "recognize academic and professional excellence rooted in personal integrity, promote a well-rounded education essential for success, provide opportunities for leadership development and promotes lifelong learning, and cultivate a community of dedicated high achievers."

name: TEDx Yale - An Undergraduate Organization
mission: The purpose of this organization shall be to promote the mission of TED (Technology, Entertainment, Design) at Yale. As the synthesis of two intellectual and creative powerhouses, TEDxYale provides a learning environment for the Yale and surrounding New Haven communities based on the sharing of ideas and stories via the TED format.

name: Teeth Slam Poets
mission: Teeth Slam Poets shall encourage young artists through Pathways for the Humanities and Arts educational programs, increase awareness and appreciation of Spoken-Word Poetry at Yale, and organize poetry performances in both competitive and non-competitive venues. Further, Teeth Slam Poet shall collaborate with other Spoken-Word poetry groups to foster a welcoming and diverse artistic community at Yale.

name: Telltale
mission: Telltale is a group that seeks to bring the Yale community together through storytelling. We host several shows per semester where storytellers tell audiences about true experiences from their lives.

name: Temporary Restraining Order Project
mission: The Temporary Restraining Order Project (TRO Project) staffs an office at the New Haven courthouse to assist individuals seeking temporary restraining orders. Students assist with completing paperwork and follow up to ensure that TROs are served and applicants return for their hearings.

name: The Arthur Liman Center for Public Interest Law
mission: The Liman Center promotes access to justice and the fair treatment of individuals and groups seeking to use the legal system. Through research projects, teaching, fellowships, and colloquia, the Liman Center supports efforts to bring about a more just legal system.

name: The Baker's Dozen
mission: The Baker's Dozen is an all-male undergraduate a Cappella group. In 2010, the Baker's Dozen formalized our commitment to spreading our passion for music by incorporating as a Connecticut non-profit (503(c)(3)) organization.

name: The Black Solidarity Conference at Yale
mission: The Black Solidarity Conference at Yale is a completely student-run annual conference held in February.  BSC is the largest undergraduate conference held at Yale University and it continues to grow each year! BSC invites over 700 undergraduates of of various races, religions, ethnicities, and communities to discuss issues pertaining to the African Diaspora. Through discussions, panels, networking, and social gatherings, students from across the country analyze issues affecting the Black/Afro-Diasporic community and explore solutions that can be implemented on their own college campuses.  In the past, the Conference has hosted Drs. Michael Eric Dyson, Angela Davis, Nikki Giovanni, and Cornel West as keynote speakers. We've also hosted artists such as J. Cole, Big Sean, Vic Mensa, and Phony Ppl as concert performers! In the following pages, you can discover how to register for conference and be a part of this amazing experience!

name: The Boola
mission: The Boola seeks to provide entertainment media catered towards Yale students.

name: The Yale Record - An Undergraduate Publication
mission: Yale's undergraduate humor magazine. Making jokes since 1872.

name: The Connecticut Hospice Advisory Board
type: School of Public Health Student Organizations
mission: To create a lasting, positive relationship between Yale University and The Connecticut Hospice through a diverse team of graduate student consultants. The Board will consist of interested students from all health care or management related graduate programs and will attend to the various strategic planning and administrative needs of The Connecticut Hospice. The Connecticut Hospice will benefit from strategic recommendations and board institutional memory while students will benefit from meaningful project-based work.

name: The Consciousness Colloquium
mission: The mission of The Consciousness Colloquium is to gather ideas from the brightest thinkers on the topic of consciousness and spread them through the Yale community and the world at large. We plan to accomplish this by having meetings, attending conferences, and inviting speakers, whom we plan to video and share those videos in a manner accessible to the public at large.

name: The Conservative Party
mission: The Conservative Party is oriented toward the production of principled and profound leaders.

name: The Control Group
mission: Control Group meets on a regular basis to train and generate content for upcoming work. We draw from techniques and styles that are idiosyncratic to Control Group as well as from the expertise and experience of current members. Control Group is constantly redefining itself to address the interests of current members and the contemporary possibilities and challenges of live performance.

name: The Cucumber
mission: The Cucumber is a place for people of all levels of experience to do stand-up comedy.

name: The Dred Scott Society
mission:
The Dred Scott Society is a pan-affinity group for all students of color (BIPOC & PGM) who identify as being descendants of oppressed, colonized, segregated, and enslaved peoples. It is a space for these students
of color who have felt the consequences of de jure and de facto white supremacy in their own lives, and most importantly who are dedicated to confronting these forces, regardless of their specific race or nationality, in their time during and after law school.

name: The Egalitarian Society
mission: The Egalitarian Society is a space for discussions about egalitarianism that foregrounds imagining a better world. Through weekly close readings, guest lectures and alumni lunches, we hope to parse the intellectual roots of egalitarianism and apply them to real world action. Our goal is to foster community and solidarity, as well as promote education and awareness. We hope to build campus support for egalitarianism through our events, which are open to the entire Yale community.

name: The Elmseed Enterprise Fund
mission:
Founded by enterprising Yale undergraduates in 2001, Elmseed has become a valuable resource for over 500 New Haven businesses. 
Elmseed is staffed entirely by Yale undergraduates dedicated to New Haven small business. We provide motivated entrepreneurs with access to one-on-one personalized consulting, business training, technical assistance, and a network of peer support. In doing so, Elmseed aims to empower entrepreneurs who lack the resources necessary to start or expand small businesses. Elmseed is committed to encouraging and enabling sustainable economic self-reliance in the greater New Haven area.

name: The Episcopal Church at Yale
mission: The Episcopal Church at Yale is worshipping community led by and dedicated to students.  Supported by our chaplain and the partnerships we have formed within Yale and New Haven, ECY exists to spiritually nourish all who attend.  Our mission is to welcome people into being inspired in worship, transformed in community, and impassioned for justice.
goals: ECY's goals for the coming year revolves around addressing the "twin pandemics" present today, COVID-19 and racism's ongoing presence in our society. We are expanding our Undoing Racism team and will be meeting more regularly, as well as re imagining what worship and community looks like with today's restriction. We are also reforming our Congregational Council, with the goal of getting as many undergraduate voices involved in the Episcopal Church at Yale.

name: The Exit Players
mission: We learn and perform dynamic, long form improv. Exit strives to be as inclusive and open as possible, combating a history of comedy as a cis white male space. We are committed to portraying human, three-dimensional characters, not empty stereotypes, and creating on-stage worlds where marginalized voices are empowered, not silenced.

name: The Fifth Humour
mission: We are a sketch comedy group that performs every few months on campus.

name: The Forests Dialogue
mission:
Purpose: To contribute to sustainable land and resource use, the conservation and sustainable management of forests, and improved livelihoods by helping people engage and explore difficult issues, find collaborative solutions, and make positive changes.
Mission: To pursue our purpose through constructive dialogue processes among all key stakeholders, based on mutual trust, enhanced understanding and commitment to change. Our dialogues are designed to build relationships and to spur collaborative action on the highest priority issues facing the world’s forests.

name: The Good Show
mission: To perform Late Night style comedy!

name: The Grant Hagan Society - a Yale Music Department Graduate Student organization
mission: The Grant Hagan Society is a graduate-student led affinity group to support people of color in the Yale Department of Music. We are deeply invested in the racial and ethnic diversity of the students and faculty of the department, as well as diversity broadly construed (gender, sexuality, [dis]ability, class, religion, etc.). The Grant Hagan Society strives to help foster a sense of camaraderie among people of color within the field of music studies, as we believe that belonging to an inclusive community contributes in important ways to a successful career path after graduate school, whether in the academy and beyond.

name: The Independent Party
mission:
The Independent Party of the Yale Political Union is the premier forum for free and authentic student debate at Yale. One of the founding parties of the Yale Political Union, the IP is easily the Union’s largest party and the only one that adheres to no specific ideology or political viewpoint; instead we aim to foster robust, open, and wide-ranging political discourse. 
Our weekly debates are open to the entire Yale community and address challenging political, cultural, and philosophical issues. Our debate format is easily accessible and relies on Robert’s Rules of Order to ensure that all voices are heard and respected. We encourage everyone–the casual visitor and committed member alike–to ask tough questions, give speeches, and actively explore their own convictions. Recently, we have debated some of the following resolutions: Resolved: Kill the Death Penalty; Resolved: Hypocrisy is Not Immoral; Resolved: WikiLeaks is Good for America; Resolved: Go West, Young Man; and Resolved: Defund the Arts 
The Independent Party’s motto is “Hear All Sides,” and this is an imperative by which we live. At our debates, you will find bold expressions of opinions from across the political spectrum. One could say that the IP is home to libertarians, socialists, neo-conservatives, hard-line moderates, and almost everything in between–but in fact, we are a group of students who resist the claustrophobic categories of “liberal” and “conservative” popular in today’s politics and reject the partisan pressures that demand adherence to a mass-produced political platform, in favor of intellectually honest and authentic approaches to forming and evaluating our worldviews. In the Independent Party we believe that openness of mind is the truest mark of genuine intelligence. 
Along with our debates, the Independent Party hosts a wide variety of social events throughout the academic year. Whether watching a movie, arguing over drinks, or toasting at Mory’s, IPsters are always having fun together. As we like to say, we take our ideas seriously, but we don’t take ourselves too seriously. The IP is one of the closest groups of friends you will find at Yale; the friendships formed in the IP stay with us forever. 
We also go to New York City every semester to meet with prominent politicians, journalists, business people, artists, and media personalities. In recent semesters, we have meet with former New York Mayor Ed Koch, Obama Administration health care expert Dr. Ezekiel Emmanuel, Editor-in-Chief of The New Atlantis Eric Cohen, CEO of the New York Public Library Tony Marx, UN Ambassador John Bolton, Historian Eric Foner, and the late William F. Buckley, Jr. 
“Yale,” George Pierson famously said, “is at once a tradition, a company of scholars, a society of friends.” The Independent Party is much the same. Please join us at one of our debates this Fall and learn firsthand what this party is all about.

name: The International Community @ YLS
mission: The International Community @ YLS is a group for all foreign and international students across all academic programs at Yale Law School. The group provides programming centered on career planning, immigration advocacy, and community building.

name: The Jackson Institute for Global Affairs
type: The Jackson Institute for Global Affairs
address:
55 Hillhouse Ave
New Haven, CT 06511 United States
mission: The Jackson Institute for Global Affairs promotes education and scholarship on global affairs at Yale.

name: The Logos
mission: The Logos is a journal of Christian thought published each semester that seeks to stimulate discussion of a Christian worldview in a way that is relevant, accessible, and engaging to the Yale community.

name: The MacMillan Center—News & Events
type: MacMillan Center for International and Area Studies
address:
34 Hillhouse Ave
New Haven, CT 06511 United States

name: The New Blue
mission: The New Blue brings together a diverse group of womxn who make music together and who form lifelong bonds in the process.

name: The Odd Ducks
mission: Our idea is to create a hybrid organization of sketch and standup with an impact not only on campus, but beyond. This is the first of its kind on the Yale campus and provides room for students who can 1) either focus on standup and sketch directly, or 2) try their hat at both and not sacrifice one over the other. In performance, this allows for the set in stone sketches to be (hopefully) funny, while adding room for spontaneity and the unexpected.
goals: Our chief goal is to be an open and welcoming group for anyone who is enthusiastic about comedy, and willing to embarrass themself all in good fun! Also to make as many people laugh on campus as possible. Period.

name: The Office of Sustainability
address:
70 Whitney Avenue
New Haven, CT 06511
mission: The Yale Office of Sustainability is committed to advancing sustainability principles by fostering innovation, helping to streamline operations, and preparing tomorrow’s sustainability leaders.

name: The Opening
mission: We put on stand-up comedy shows and develop our stand-up comedy abilities as a group.
goals: To be funny, to entertain, and to support one another in our stand-up comedy endeavors.

name: The Pocket at Yale - A Student Organization
mission: The Pocket at Yale is an undergraduate organization committed to the facilitation of creative endeavors for Black undergraduate Yale students. The publication’s digital platform serves as a medium for student-submitted comedic media spanning a variety of forms, ranging from video submissions to written works.

name: The Progressive Party
mission:
Originally founded in 1962, the Progressive Party is a forum and community for those across the Left to deepen their understanding of what they believe, why they believe it, and to be able to defend those beliefs.
We host weekly debates and dinners, in addition to other social gatherings and social action events.

name: The Purple Crayon of Yale
mission: We are an improv comedy group that performs long-form improvisational sets sometimes in the form known as the "Harold." Our mission is to laugh and spread laughter.

name: The Society of Orpheus and Bacchus
mission: The Society of Orpheus and Bacchus has been delighting audiences around the world for 80 years with its tight harmonies and inspired arrangements. Although the SOBs rely on frequent rehearsal and a highly talented membership to achieve this musical excellence, we also benefit from an unrivaled songbook. The Society's musical arrangements are recognized by a cappella aficionados on and off campus as exceptionally complex and intriguing, and they have served as the inspiration for a number of other singing groups across the country.
goals: Our goal is to sing great music, make funny jokes (sometimes), and make people smile (always).

name: The University Curlers at Yale Undergraduate Division
mission: This organisation has been formed to create opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students at Yale to jointly curl socially and competitively, to preserve the traditions of curling and to encourage the camaraderie and sportsmanship of the game. All graduate and undergraduate students at Yale University are invited to participate. This club will be an integration of collegiate curling within the USCA with traditional social and competitive aspects of curling which centre around the spirit of curling. The spirit of curling, specifically the canon of respect for others irrespective of their background, beliefs, gender, sexual orientation, disability or race, shall be honoured and actively pursued by all members.

name: The Unorthojocks
mission: The Unorthojocks is an a cappella group designed to accommodate the unique schedules of Yale’s student athletes; the group aims to afford students with passions for athletics and music the opportunity to engage in both.  While this group is geared towards varsity and club undergraduate athletes at Yale, we do not discriminate against non-athletes who wish to audition.

name: The Urban Philanthropic Fund
mission: The UP Fund's mission is to educate Yale students about investment management and its social applications in the context of community development.  In order to accomplish this mission, we also aim to enable nonprofit organizations and social ventures to maintain or expand programs that benefit underserved residents of New Haven.

name: The Viola Question
mission: We are a group of improvisers and friends who aim to make you laugh.

name: The Whaling Crew
mission:
The Whaling Crew’s mission is to build community around Yale Athletics, ultimately enhancing the Yale experience for student athletes and non-athletes alike.
We are a unified, organized student group dedicated to yelling too loud and heckling too obnoxiously at Bulldog athletic events.
goals:
To engage the Yale community by supporting Yale Athletics. This includes:
-- Increasing student turnout at Yale sporting events
-- Increasing the degree to which Yale students are informed about Yale athletics
-- Decreasing the implicit separation between athletes and non-athletes on campus

name: The Whistlepoofs
mission: To act in the creation, production, display, and distribution of whistle based entertainment.  We strive to create an atmosphere of camaraderie and entertainment as we create comedic whistling performances.
goals: To host two live performances a year and create online shareable content.

name: The Women's Network
mission: The Women’s Network at Yale is an intercollegiate organization focused on connecting and empowering women in the professional workplace, and creating a social community of ambitious, hard-working women.  We host career-focused events for women in all areas of study to be directly introduced to successful women in their fields and to hear from them in an open and candid discussion setting. We also host professional training bootcamps, career symposiums, networking events, Q&A panels, social events, and more. As an organization that hosts many large-scale events, we are able to differentiate ourselves by providing our members the opportunity to network across a much more extensive list and in many diverse areas. Our TWN Yale members become part of the greater TWN National organization, where we have over 30,000 members across the country and 142 chapters across college campuses. Ultimately, joining TWN will enable members to meet and connect with high-achieving individuals on both the Yale campus and around the nation, authentically network with powerful industry leaders, gain insight into traditional and unconventional careers, build confidence, gain leadership experience, and access exclusive internship and job opportunities.

name: The Word at Yale
mission: The goal of this preaching group is for students to learn from each other and to think about the process of preaching outside an academic context. It is challenging to get into the intro preaching class, and there are not many preaching opportunities for students who are not third-year MDivs, so this group aims to fill the gap by expanding preaching opportunities and opportunities to talk about preaching at Yale. YDS has a rich abundance of individuals passionate about preaching the Word from a wide array of different Christian traditions, and this groups taps into that by providing a space for preachers to collaborate. The primary event of this group during the 2020-2021 season has been our Word at Nine podcast, which provides YDS students with opportunities to preach a sermon on an episode of the show. The previous year, the group primarily consisted of an event called Preacher’s Hour, which is essentially office hours with fellow students to talk about preaching, either through workshopping sermons that people are currently working on or through discussing topics relevant to preaching in general. Preacher’s Hour has been on pause during the pandemic, but may resume in the future.

name: The Yale Review of Disability Experience: An Undergraduate Journal
mission: The goal of the YRDE is to publish academic articles, opinion pieces, short- and long-form essays, and non-print multimedia submissions of merit that rigorously analyze, insightfully reflect, and/or creatively capture the many dimensions of disability studies, life, and experience.

name: The Yale Socialist Party - a Student Organization
mission: The Socialist Party's mission is to combat political apathy and further Leftist politics on Yale's campus through discussion and action.

name: The Yale Alley Cats - An Undergraduate A Cappella Singing Group
mission: The Yale Alley Cats is an undergraduate a-cappella singing group whose purpose is to sing wonderful music together, to learn to become better musicians through vocal performance and rehearsal, to spread our music to Yale University students and faculty, and to perform for music enthusiasts, both young and old, all around the world. The Yale Alley Cats, Inc. is registered as a non-profit organization, and we are therefore exempt from taxes. Officers include the Business Manager, the Pitchpipe (or Musical Director), the Rush Managers, and the Tour Managers. These officers are appointed unanimously by the members of the current group after a series of presentations and deliberations in the spring. The Alley Cats’ funds are used to cover the necessary expenses of the group, including travel, lodging, album production, publicity, and other basic operating costs. As one of Yale’s oldest and most renowned a-cappella groups (having been established in 1943), The Yale Alley Cats strive to uphold the strong tradition of a-cappella music that has become such a signature of Yale’s student life.

name: The Yale Citations
mission: Using A Cappella as a medium, The Citations hope to foster musical camaraderie and performance opportunities for singers chosen through a competitive audition.

name: The Yale Ethnobotany and Mycology Society (YEMS)
type: Yale School of the Environment Student Groups

name: The Yale Film Society - An Undergraduate Organization
mission: YFS aims to foster an active undergraduate film-viewing culture. Crucial to that are the 8 screenings on 35mm and the preview-screenings of contemporary films that we hold each year. We also host additional, more low-key screenings and get-togethers; these events, like our screenings, are open to all Yale students.

name: The Yale Globalist - An Undergraduate Publication
mission: The Globalist is Yale University’s only undergraduate international affairs quarterly. The Glo is written, edited, and published entirely by students of Yale and is read all over the world. We aim to provide Yale students with international journalism experiences both in New Haven and abroad.

name: The Yale Herald Inc.
address:
305 Crown St.
New Haven, CT 06511 United States
mission: The Yale Herald, a weekly Yale undergraduate publication, is nestled in the sweet spot between magazine and newspaper. Since 1986, the Herald has aimed to provide in-depth, analytical reporting and includes personal essays, interviews and profiles, culture articles, creative writing, reviews, humor, and feature coverage of campus and local happenings. With a circulation of over 2,000, the Herald is the second-highest circulated campus publication and is distributed free of charge throughout the Yale campus and New Haven businesses. Rachel Calcott, BC '22, and Hamzah Jhaveri, TC '23, serve as Editors-in-Chief of the Herald for the 2020-2021 academic year.

name: The Yale Historical Review: An Undergraduate Publication
category: Academic, Advocacy/Policy, Cultural, Leadership, Political, Publication
mission: The Yale Historical Review: An Undergraduate Publication exists to give undergraduates an opportunity to engage in the editorial process and have their exceptional work highlighted. In addition to introducing writers and editors to the peer review process that gives them access to faculty advising, the diverse nature of the Review gives an apt perception of the various experiences Yale history students have.

name: The Yale Journal of Human Rights: An Undergraduate Publication
mission: To encompass the discussions and forums about human rights under the lens of health, economics, identity, politics, historical trends, and technology. We aim to capture these debates about human rights in the past, apply them to current situations, and consider future possibilities.

name: The Yale Layer: An Undergraduate Publication
mission: The Yale Layer is a student run publication dedicated to issues of mental health and student well-being on Yale’s campus. The goal of the publication is to give students a platform on which they feel comfortable voicing their stories.

name: The Yale Literary Review--An Undergraduate Publication
address: New Haven, CT  United States
mission: The Yale Literary Review is a semesterly magazine that publishes reviews of art worth reviewing. We are the only publication at Yale entirely dedicated to writing about all forms of art from anywhere, any time. We welcome everything from traditional book reviews and critical analyses of the latest theater production on campus to gossipy pieces about Jane Austen heroes and impassioned defenses of underrated masterpieces of Tang China; we are an outlet for writers who love art and who wish to get people excited about art.

name: The Yale Phoenix - An Undergraduate Review
mission: We are building an optimistic, humane, futurist magazine. We believe in a good future—one to be found outside of the narrowness of imagination which binds us today.

name: The Yale Politic – an Undergraduate Organization
mission: The mission of The Politic is to provide an outlet for politically-inclined students on campus to participate in political journalism, express political opinions, and be exposed to new political thought.

name: Yale Biology and Biomedical Sciences Diversity and Inclusion Collective (YBDIC) - a Graduate Student Organization
mission: YBDIC is a student organization committed to fostering the intellectual and personal growth of underrepresented minority students in BBS. Our central mission focuses on engaging, empowering, and advancing URM students.

name: The Yale Undergraduate Literary Society
mission: Emulating the seminar format, the Yale Undergraduate Literary Society aims to provide a space for those interested in conversations on topics and issues related to difference, culture, humanity, philosophy, history, and politics considered in mainly literary contexts. We practice articulating complicated ideas on issues members care about and teasing out left-over ideas from classes, events, and news. Speaker events consist of inviting Yale faculty, visiting authors, museum curators, etc. to lead discussions. People from all majors and all backgrounds are encouraged to join!
goals: The Yale Undergraduate Literary Society aims to provide a community for students to reflect aloud on topics they care deeply about, like identity, culture, difference, grief, humanity, etc. It would also serve as a student workshop space for members to read and review one another's papers. The larger impacts of this club are its public events like: open discussions, interviews with authors, film screenings (plus discussion), and literature symposiums. Because of the broad nature of the discipline of comparative literature - the core attitude of this society -  we would easily be able to collaborate with other on-campus culture groups, music groups, art groups, film groups, and literary publications.

name: The Yale Undergraduate Prison Project
address:
ATTN: Yale Undergraduate Prison Project67 High Street
New Haven, CT 06511 United States
mission: YUPP is a student run social justice organization with over 150 members that engages in service and advocacy related to mass incarceration. Our mission is to challenge the structural inequities of the criminal justice system through weekly educational programs for incarcerated and formerly incarcerated individuals, community partnerships, and legislative advocacy.

name: The Yale Women's Center - An Undergraduate Organization
mission:
The Women’s Center works across issues and identities toward collective liberation. Gender and sexuality have historically been central to our work and now serve as one of many points of entry into intersectional struggles and coalition building. 
We seek to foster a self-critical and self-reflective community, intentionally directing our time, resources, and programming toward dismantling systems of oppression through education and action. We aim to provide a physical and intellectual space where all are able to collaborate, learn, and unlearn without judgment. We strive to make our work accessible to everyone who wishes to engage with it, firmly believing that this work cannot and should not be done in isolation. 
The Women’s Center may be spatially enclosed within and funded by Yale, but all work within the university is intertwined with New Haven. We strive to build a deep and long-standing relationship with the city: realizing our mission demands that our community and our efforts extend far beyond our campus.

name: TheNeoCollective
mission: TheNeoCollective is a Black Arts Collective that will run for Black Yale and New Haven Artists. We will encourage art as a community endeavor— art as something that should be easy to do, access and share. Black Artists will be able to submit their work to a wider audience as well as receive feedback in a nuanced way by other Black artists. The format of the collective will be free-flowing. We coordinate events, do community outreach and create online art shows and curate exhibits. We, at the NeoCollective believe that Black Art and Black Narratives should be plentiful.

name: There's Hope in North Korea
mission: ThiNK’s mission is to provide a public platform of actionable discourse for activists and experts, as well as give a voice for defectors. We want to encourage our peers to engage in earnest discussions of how change might be effected. We seek a comprehensive understanding of North Korean issues, driven by a firm belief in the power and value of human rights. We look for avenues to positively engage with and empower the global North Korean community.

name: Thinkspaces
mission:
If you are looking for teammates, simply post whatever you are working on - be it a startup, lab, event, art production, or any other project - and who you need. Then, Thinkspaces members can view your project and connect with you if interested.
If you are looking for a project, explore the Projects pages, find ones that interest you, see if you could be a good fit, and connect with the team.

name: Thomas Swan Barristers Union
mission: The Thomas Swan Barristers’ Union provides students with the opportunity to learn trial advocacy skills in an educational, fun, and competitive environment.
